Flight One paper FROL exam

Questions

As a VFR aircraft, airborne and tracking for a Class C Control Zone to transit, you should:

  1. Call the local Centre/Radar Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  2. Call the associated Military Approach (APP) Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  3. Call the associated Military Airways Clearance Delivery (ACD) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  4. Call the associated Aerodrome Tower (TWR) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Attenuation can be best described as:

  1. A button pressed on the audio panel which attenuates the volume so you can listen to your ipod and monitor the COMS at the same time

  2. The absorption and scattering of some radio waves as a result of water vapour, cloud, dust, etc.

  3. A decrease in the power of radio waves returning to a transceiver as a result of great distance travelled

  4. A decrease in the power of radio waves arriving at a transceiver as a result of great distance travelled

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

If you switch to another ATC unit, wait to find no other transmissions and make your call to find the response: TWO STATIONS IN TOGETHER ON BRISBANE CENTRE. This means:

  1. Your transmission was over transmitted by someone else and you should await their call then make yours

  2. Your transmission was over transmitted by someone else and you should make your call again quickly before the jump on your transmission a second time

  3. Your transmission was made simultaneously with another station and you should wait for the other station to make a call unless yours is of an urgent or distress manner

  4. Your transmission was made simultaneously with another station and you should make your call again quickly, regardless of the nature

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

A cable antenna extending from one extremity of an aircraft to another under a degree of tension is most likely to be for which of the following?

  1. The ADF

  2. The HF Radio

  3. The VHF COM

  4. The VHF NAV

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The NDB/ADF system relies primarily on which of the following types of wave propagation?

  1. Sky waves

  2. Direct waves

  3. Ground waves

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Once you have established two-way COMS with a ATC Unit and you have been **IDENTIFIED**, this means:

  1. You are under radar control

  2. Your transponder is on the correct code and is periodically interrogated by Secondary Surveillance Radar

  3. You are given ATC guided separation from IFR Traffic

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following is/are some or all of the minimum requirements to hold a Radiotelephone Operator Licence?

  1. Pass a written test/examination

  2. Pass a PPL *(should be RPL)* flight test or other suitable practical test

  3. Be at least 16 years of age or older

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

After receiving a report of: READING YOU FIFES. From ATC, you understand that:

  1. On a scale of one to five for clarity and strength, you have five for each

  2. Your radio is only working at half strength and clarity

  3. Your radio is clear but signal is faint

  4. Carrier wave only

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

VHF radio waves propagate as:

  1. Sky waves

  2. Direct waves

  3. Ground waves

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is usually broadcast on an aerodrome's:

  1. Discrete ATIS only frequency where available

  2. VHF NAV frequency where available

  3. NDB frequency where available

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following styles of headphones and microphone combination Jack might you possibly find in a general aviation aircraft?

  1. Two Jacks: one headphone one microphone with straight cables

  2. Two Jacks: one headphone one microphone with coiled cables

  3. 1 Jack: All through one straight cable

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Approaching a Class C control boundary you plan to request clearance having not made two-way COMS with the ATC unit during this sector. The most correct example of an approaching radio call is:

  1. Brisbane Centre, Alpha Bravo Charlie. (to gain two way COMS first before your request)

  2. Brisbane Centre, Alpha Bravo Charlie Cessna 172 is over head Maleny, 4500 feet, tracking for Archerfield Request clearance

  3. Brisbane Centre, Alpha Bravo Charlie Cessna 172 is over head Maleny, 4500 feet, tracking for Archerfield Request Code

  4. Brisbane Centre, Alpha Bravo Charlie, request when ready. (to gain two way COMS first before your request)

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following is not an error associated with VHF NAV Ground stations?

  1. Site Error

  2. Terrain effect

  3. Aggregate Error

  4. Scalloping

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is usually broadcast on an aerodrome's:

  1. Discrete ATIS only frequency where available

  2. HF frequency where available

  3. VHF NAV frequency where available

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

On the radio control panel, is it possible to set up the avionics so that multiple radios are receiving at once?

  1. Yes - but only if it is a Garmin Stack

  2. Yes - select the COM and NAV units desired to be receiving and tune correct frequency

  3. No - no brand is capable of this at this stage

  4. No - you can only select one COM and one NAV at a time

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

A departure report for a VFR aircraft is required when operating at a:

  1. Class C Aerodrome

  2. Class D Aerodrome

  3. Class G Aerodrome

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

When requested by an ATC unit ALPHA BRAVO CHARLIE, BRISBANE CENTRE, RADIO CHECK HOW DO YOU READ? To give a report of very good clarity and strength, you would reply:

  1. Reading you fifes

  2. Reading you fine

  3. Reading you Nines

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The NDB transmits typically within a range of:

  1. 200 to 400

  2. 200 to 430

  3. 100 to 400

  4. 195 to 419

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Where would you find the frequency for the Automatic Enroute Information Service (AERIS) that related to your current position?

  1. A World Aeronautical Chart (WAC)

  2. A Planning Chart Australia (PCA)

  3. A Visual Terminal Chart (VTC)

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The HF Radio relies primarily on which of the following types of wave propagation?

  1. Sky waves

  2. Direct waves

  3. Ground waves

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

What is the purpose of an antenna?

  1. To receive and transmit radio signals

  2. To receive radio signals only

  3. To transmit radio signals only

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

An ATC unit replies to your request as: *Alpha Bravo Charlie, squawk code 3447, QNH 1016*. Your reply should be:

  1. Squawk code 3447, 1016 ALPHA BRAVO CHARLIE

  2. 3447, QNH 1016 ALPHA BRAVO CHARLIE

  3. Squawk code 3447, QNH 1016 ALPHA BRAVO CHARLIE

  4. 3447, 1016 ALPHA BRAVO CHARLIE

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The use of flight radios is limited to

  1. Emergencies only

  2. Aviation related clearances, requests, cancellations

  3. Company communications

  4. All of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The squelch control on your radio can be best described as:

  1. A control to tune slim dusty and other country music during flight

  2. A control for individual headphone volume

  3. A control for overall system volume

  4. A control for pickup sensitivity at a microphone

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

When inside controlled airspace and transiting from one frequency zone to another, you are handed off to make two-way COMS with Brisbane Centre 121.2. Your first call on this frequency should be:

  1. Brisbane Centre 121.2 Alpha Bravo Charlie maintaining 4500

  2. Brisbane Centre 121.2 Alpha Bravo Charlie

  3. Brisbane Centre Alpha Bravo Charlie maintaining 4500

  4. Brisbane Centre Alpha Bravo Charlie

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

As the holder of a FROL, you are authorised to:

  1. Operate a radiotelephone system that is installed in the aircraft only

  2. Operate a radiotelephone system that is carried but not hard wired in the aircraft only

  3. Operate a radiotelephone system that is installed or carried in the aircraft

  4. Not allowed to use the system at all

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

A VHF NAV radio receives in a frequency band of:

  1. 118.00 to 134.95

  2. 117.00 to 133.95

  3. 112.00 to 117.95

  4. 108.00 to 116.95

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following factors may reduce coverage or limit the useful range of a VHF transmitter?

  1. Thunderstorms

  2. Coastal Refraction

  3. Terrain separating transmitter and receiver

  4. Scalloping

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following is an accurate example of a distress call?

  1. MAYDAY MAYDAY MAYDAY, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Attempting Forced Landing near Logan Village, 2 POB.

  2. MAYDAY MAYDAY MAYDAY, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Logan Village, 2 POB.

  3. PAN PAN, PAN PAN, PAN PAN, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Attempting Forced Landing near Logan Village, 2 POB.

  4. PAN PAN, PAN PAN, PAN PAN, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Attempting Forced Landing near Logan Village, 2 POB.

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

The memory verse of TUNE IDENTIFY TEST is to be carried out while using:

  1. VHF NAV

  2. VHF COM

  3. ADF

  4. VHF NAV and ADF

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Approaching the runway on final approach at a controlled aerodrome having conducted the appropriate COM Failure procedure, you look to the tower for confirmation the landing area is safe to land. You see a green light - to acknowledge receipt to the tower you should:

  1. Flash the landing lights

  2. Turn all lights off

  3. Turn all lights on

  4. Manouvre the aircraft in roll to 15deg AOB each way

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Company communications are limited to:

  1. Company discrete frequencies

  2. Pertinent operational information

  3. Discussions relating to company employees

  4. Company discrete frequencies and pertinent operational information

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

When asked by an ATC unit to advise an estimate for a place of destination, you should express the following time as: June 24th 10:52am EST

  1. Estimate XYZ at 06241052

  2. Estimate XYZ at 06241052 ZULU

  3. Estimate XYZ at 1052 ZULU

  4. Estimate XYZ at 0052 ZULU

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Which of the following is a limitation of the NDB/ADF system?

  1. Scalloping

  2. Site Error

  3. Coastal Refraction

  4. Line of sight

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

What would be the transponder code to display in the event of a suspected COMS failure?

  1. 7700

  2. 7600

  3. 7500

  4. 3000

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Some aircraft systems are installed with a coinciding Avionics Master Switch. What is the function of this switch?

  1. It is a way to cut power only from all radios

  2. It is a way to control which power source the radios operate from

  3. Controls power source of all radio equipment

  4. Controls power to communications VHF radios only

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

As a VFR aircraft, airborne and tracking for a Military Restricted Control Zone to transit, you should:

  1. Call the local Civilian Centre Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  2. Call the associated Military Approach (APP) Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  3. Call the associated Military Airways Clearance Delivery (ACD) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  4. Call the associated Military Tower (TWR) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

WILCO means:

  1. Understood

  2. Understood and will comply with requirement

  3. Looking for the traffic

  4. None of the above

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

A VHF COM radio receives in a frequency band of:

  1. 118.00 to 134.95

  2. 117.00 to 133.95

  3. 109.00 to 117.95

  4. 108.00 to 116.95

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

123.6 as a frequency should be read as:

  1. ONE TWO THREE DAYCIMAL SIX

  2. WUN TOO TREE DAYCIMAL SIX

  3. ONE TWO TREE DECIMAL SIX

  4. WUN TOO TREE DAYCIMAL SIIIX

Answer
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Flight One paper FROL exam

Answers

As a VFR aircraft, airborne and tracking for a Class C Control Zone to transit, you should:

  1. Call the local Centre/Radar Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  2. Call the associated Military Approach (APP) Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  3. Call the associated Military Airways Clearance Delivery (ACD) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  4. Call the associated Aerodrome Tower (TWR) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

Call the local Centre/Radar Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  1. A button pressed on the audio panel which attenuates the volume so you can listen to your ipod and monitor the COMS at the same time

  2. The absorption and scattering of some radio waves as a result of water vapour, cloud, dust, etc.

  3. A decrease in the power of radio waves returning to a transceiver as a result of great distance travelled

  4. A decrease in the power of radio waves arriving at a transceiver as a result of great distance travelled

The absorption and scattering of some radio waves as a result of water vapour, cloud, dust, etc.

RPL,Flight One

If you switch to another ATC unit, wait to find no other transmissions and make your call to find the response: TWO STATIONS IN TOGETHER ON BRISBANE CENTRE. This means:

  1. Your transmission was over transmitted by someone else and you should await their call then make yours

  2. Your transmission was over transmitted by someone else and you should make your call again quickly before the jump on your transmission a second time

  3. Your transmission was made simultaneously with another station and you should wait for the other station to make a call unless yours is of an urgent or distress manner

  4. Your transmission was made simultaneously with another station and you should make your call again quickly, regardless of the nature

Your transmission was made simultaneously with another station and you should wait for the other station to make a call unless yours is of an urgent or distress manner

  2. The HF Radio

  3. The VHF COM

  4. The VHF NAV

  3. PAN PAN, PAN PAN, PAN PAN, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Attempting Forced Landing near Logan Village, 2 POB.

  4. PAN PAN, PAN PAN, PAN PAN, Brisbane Radar, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Alpha Bravo Charlie, Cessna 172, Engine Failure, Attempting Forced Landing near Logan Village, 2 POB.

  1. Flash the landing lights

  2. Turn all lights off

  3. Turn all lights on

Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Some aircraft systems are installed with a coinciding Avionics Master Switch. What is the function of this switch?

  1. It is a way to cut power only from all radios

  2. It is a way to control which power source the radios operate from

  3. Controls power source of all radio equipment

  4. Controls power to communications VHF radios only

Controls power source of all radio equipment

Back to question
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

As a VFR aircraft, airborne and tracking for a Military Restricted Control Zone to transit, you should:

  1. Call the local Civilian Centre Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  2. Call the associated Military Approach (APP) Frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  3. Call the associated Military Airways Clearance Delivery (ACD) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

  4. Call the associated Military Tower (TWR) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

Call the associated Military Airways Clearance Delivery (ACD) frequency for a Squawk Code and Clearance

Back to question
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

WILCO means:

  1. Understood

  2. Understood and will comply with requirement

  3. Looking for the traffic

  4. None of the above

Understood and will comply with requirement

Back to question
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

A VHF COM radio receives in a frequency band of:

  1. 118.00 to 134.95

  2. 117.00 to 133.95

  3. 109.00 to 117.95

  4. 108.00 to 116.95

117.00 to 133.95

Back to question
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

123.6 as a frequency should be read as:

  1. ONE TWO THREE DAYCIMAL SIX

  2. WUN TOO TREE DAYCIMAL SIX

  3. ONE TWO TREE DECIMAL SIX

  4. WUN TOO TREE DAYCIMAL SIIIX

WUN TOO TREE DAYCIMAL SIX

Back to question
Flight One paper FROL exam
RPL,Flight One

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6

Questions

Which of the following will always be accompanied by an increase in positive G load?

  1. increased IAS in a dive

  2. any manoeuvre which requires extra power

  3. any manoeuvre which requires the pilot to pull back on the control column

  4. any manoeuvre in which the aircraft's nose is above the horizon

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

In which of the following situations would a normal healthy person be most likely to experience loss of consciousness [G-LOC]?

  1. eight G sustained for two seconds

  2. three G sustained for five seconds

  3. seven G sustained for seven seconds

  4. two G sustained for fifteen seconds

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is an effect of a sustained negative G load?

  1. a slowing of the heart beat

  2. a decreased flow of oxygenated blood to the brain

  3. pooling of blood in the abdomen and legs

  4. an irregular heart beat

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At about which sustained G load will a healthy person be likely to begin to experience grey out?

  1. 1.5G

  2. 2.5G

  3. 3.5G

  4. 4.5G

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At about which sustained G load will a healthy person be likely to begin to experience black out?

  1. 7G

  2. 5G

  3. 3.5G

  4. 2.5G

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would most likely lead to carbon monoxide contamination of the cockpit atmosphere?

  1. excessive use of carburettor heat

  2. an electrical short circuit

  3. flying low in a very thick smoke haze

  4. a leak in the engine exhaust system

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is *not* a symptom of carbon monoxide poisoning?

  1. headache and fatigue

  2. a feeling of euphoria

  3. discomfort in breathing

  4. impairment of vision and mental confusion

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would be suitable treatment for a person suffering from carbon monoxide poisoning?

  1. administer oxygen

  2. give plenty of water

  3. give a sleeping pill

  4. have them re-breathe their exhaled breath from a bag placed over the nose and mouth

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 6
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2

Questions

The relative airflow is always

  1. opposite the direction of motion and faster than the true airspeed

  2. in the same direction as motion and equal to the true airspeed

  3. opposite the direction of motion and equal to the true airspeed

  4. in the same direction as motion and faster to the true airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

All of the aerodynamic forces acting on an aerofoil can be resolved into a single force acting on a single point. This single force is called

  1. lift

  2. drag

  3. the total reaction

  4. total lift

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

The force of lift is

  1. that component of the total reaction acting at right angles to the relative airflow

  2. that component of the total reaction acting parallel to the relative airflow

  3. the combined effect of all forces acting on an aerofoil

  4. that component of the total reaction acting at right angles to the chord line

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

The angle of attack of an aerofoil is the angle between

  1. the relative airflow and the bottom surface of the wing

  2. the nose of the aircraft and the horizon

  3. the chord line and the horizon

  4. the chord line and the direction of the relative airflow

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

The magnitude of the total aerodynamic reaction on an aerofoil depends upon

  1. the speed of the relative airflow only

  2. the angle of attack only

  3. both the angle of attack of the aerofoil and the speed of the relative airflow

  4. the forward speed of the aerofoil only

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

To maintain level flight at a lower airspeed

  1. the aircraft must fly at a higher nose attitude and an increased angle of attack

  2. the aircraft must fly at a lower nose attitude and an increased angle of attack

  3. the aircraft must fly at a higher nose attitude and an decreased angle of attack

  4. the aircraft must fly at a lower nose attitude and an decreased angle of attack

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

Once the stalling angle has been reached, any further increase in angle of attack will result in

  1. more lift and less drag

  2. more lift and more drag

  3. less lift and less drag

  4. less lift and more drag

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

Level flight is not possible at speeds below the stalling speed because

  1. the maximum lift available is less than weight

  2. there is no lift available

  3. drag becomes greater than lift

  4. the air flowing over the control surfaces produces no reaction

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

For any given airspeed, the stalling angle of attack at which

  1. drag reaches its maximum value

  2. lift reaches its minimum value

  3. drag reaches its minimum value

  4. lift reaches its maximum value

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

As the angle of attack is increased from zero to beyond the stalling angle at a constant airspeed, the magnitude of the force of lift

  1. increases continuously

  2. increases then decreases

  3. decreases continuously

  4. decreases then increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A2

Answers

The relative airflow is always

  1. opposite the direction of motion and faster than the true airspeed

  2. in the same direction as motion and equal to the true airspeed

  3. opposite the direction of motion and equal to the true airspeed

  4. in the same direction as motion and faster to the true airspeed

opposite the direction of motion and equal to the true airspeed

  1. lift

  2. drag

Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made

Questions

What are the privileges and limitations of the recreational pilot licence with aeroplane category rating?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the drug and alcohol regulations?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the VFR aircraft instrument requirements?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the emergency equipment requirements?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What emergency procedures must the passengers be briefed on *[CAO20.11(14)]*?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the fuel and oil requirements for flight?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are cargo and passenger loading requirements?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the privileges and limitations of the single engine aeroplane class rating?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What requirement applies to take-off and landing distances?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What documents must be carried?

Answer
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made

Answers

What are the privileges and limitations of the recreational pilot licence with aeroplane category rating?

  • can carry passengers if at least 3 take-offs and landings within previous 90 days *[CASR61.395]*

  • pilot holds and carries *[CASR61.420(b)]* class 1 or 2 medical certificate or RAMCP under conditions in subparagraph 2 *[CASR61.405]*

  • pilot must carry documents; licence, medical certificate, maintenance release, pilot operating handbook

  • must have English proficiency assessment *[CASR61.422]*

  • pilot only registered aircraft *[CASR61.425]*

  • airspace within 25nm of departure aerodrome, within flight training area and direct between departure aerodrome and flight training area *[CASR61.427]*

  • single-engine aircraft, MTOW <= 1500kg, day VFR, private operation or flight training *[CASR61.460]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the drug and alcohol regulations?

  • 8 hours from consumption of alcohol to departure *[CASR99]*

  • not intoxicated; 0.02 grams per 210 litres of breath *[CASR99]*

  • crew will not consume while on board *[CASR99]*

  • consult DAME regarding use of drugs *[CASR99]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the VFR aircraft instrument requirements?

  • airspeed indicator *[CAO20.18(10) and CAO20.18(Appendix 1)]*

  • altimeter *[CAO20.18(10) and CAO20.18(Appendix 1)]*

  • direct or remote magnetic compass *[CAO20.18(10) and CAO20.18(Appendix 1)]*

  • timepiece with hours, minutes, seconds *[CAO20.18(10) and CAO20.18(Appendix 1)]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the emergency equipment requirements?

  • life jackets when over water and out of glide *[CAO20.11(5.1)]*

  • sufficient life raft(s) when minimum of (30 minutes cruise) and (100nm) *[CAO20.11(5.2.1)]*

  • if life raft required, 1 ELT and pyro distress signals *[CAO20.11(6.1)]*

  • if more than one life raft required, then >= 2 (approved ELT under reg 252A) transmitters 121.5MHz and 243MHz and stowed ready for use *[CAO20.11(6.1)]*

  • single-engine, over water, not equipped with radio or incapable of air-to-ground radio, not required to carry a life raft, shall carry ELT (121.5MHz and 243MHz approved under reg 252A) *[CAO20.11(6.2)]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What emergency procedures must the passengers be briefed on *[CAO20.11(14)]*?

  • smoking requirements *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • use of seat belts *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • location of emergency exits *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • use of oxygen where applicable *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • use of floatation devices where applicable *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • stowage of luggage *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

  • onboard survival equipment *[CAO20.11(14.1.1)]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the fuel and oil requirements for flight?

  • PiC must take steps to ensure sufficient fuel and oil *[CAR1988(234)]*

  • Fixed fuel reserve for VFR, aeroplane, piston-engine: 45 minutes *[CAAP 234-1(1)]*

  • 5-8 quarts of oil *[Cessna 172 PoH Section 8 CAPACITY OF ENGINE SUMP]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are cargo and passenger loading requirements?

  • cargo on or above floor shall be restrained *[CAO20.16.2(3)]*

  • cargo shall not obstruct flight controls *[CAO20.16.2(4.1)]*, emergency exits *[CAO20.16.2(4.2)]*

  • cargo on a passenger seat shall evenly distribute weight, not exceeding 77kg *[CAO20.16.2(5.1)]* and restrained *[CAO20.16.2(5.2)]*

  • cargo on unoccupied control seat shall not exceed 77kg *[CAO20.16.2(6.2)]*, restrained *[CAO20.16.2(6.4)]*, flight controls removed if easy *[CAO20.16.2(6.3.1)]*, not interfere with aircraft operation *[CAO20.16.2(6.3)]*

  • seat belts during take-off, landing, < 1000ft AGL, turbulence *[CAO20.16.3(4.1)]*

  • one pilot crew wearing seat belt at all times *[CAO20.16.3(4.2)]*

  • seats upright during take-off and landing *[CAO20.16.3(5.1)]*

  • passenger in control seat must be given instruction, no interfere with flight controls *[CAO20.16.3(11.1)]*

  • two infants (<=3 years of age) may be carried on one seat with total weight <= 77kg *[CAO20.16.3(13.1)]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What are the privileges and limitations of the single engine aeroplane class rating?

  • pilot licence must demonstrate competency of part 61 MoS *[CASR61.400]*

  • flight review every 24 months, within 3 months of expiry, and valid to the end of that month *[CASR61.745]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What requirement applies to take-off and landing distances?

Add 15% to all take-off and landing distances for MTOW <= 2000kg *[CAO20.7.4(6.1)]*

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

What documents must be carried?

  • Maintenance release

  • Pilot Operating Handbook

  • Aviation Medical Certificate

  • Pilot Licence

Back to question
Form 61-1486 and 61-1495 self-made
RPL,Self-made

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP

Questions

An aircraft with this loading system has 200lbs on the rear seats. The moment index generated by this weight would be closest to

  1. 30

  2. 25.2

  3. 12.5

  4. 33

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP
RPL,Bob Tait

The combined weight of the pilot and front passenger in an aircraft with this loading system is 340lbs. The moment index generated by this weight would be closest to

  1. 3

  2. 309

  3. 134

  4. 31

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP
RPL,Bob Tait

An aircraft which uses this loading system is loaded as follows. Basic empty weight, 1240lb, 100.80 moment index. Row 1, Pilot and passenger 339lbs. Row 2, empty. Baggage, 50lbs. Fuel at take-off 37 US gal.

  1. This aircraft WILL remain within balance limits at all stages of the flight

  2. This aircraft WILL NOT remain within balance limits at all stages of the flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP
RPL,Bob Tait

An aircraft with this loading system is loaded so that its gross weight is 1950lbs and the total moment index is 170 index units. The position of the centre of gravity with this load configuration in inches aft of the datum is closest to

  1. 87 inches aft of the datum

  2. 67 inches aft of the datum

  3. 101 inches aft of the datum

  4. 120 inches aft of the datum

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP
RPL,Bob Tait

An aircraft with this loading system has been loaded so that its take-off totals are as follows. Gross Weight=2100lbs. Total moment index 196. If the baggage compartment is full, what is the minimum weight which must be removed to ensure that the aircraft is within balance limits for take-off?

  1. none

  2. 25lbs

  3. 50lbs

  4. 100lbs

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision BAP

Answers

  1. 30

  2. 25.2

  3. 12.5

  4. 33

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2

Questions

The period of validity of a medical certificate for a pilot over forty years of age, unless otherwise cancelled or suspended is

  1. 2 years for student and private pilot licences and 1 year for commercial licences

  2. 2 years for student and 1 year for private pilot licences and commercial licences

  3. 1 year for student and 2 years for private pilot licences and commercial licences

  4. 2 years for all classes of licence

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hyperventilation is likely to result in

  1. a change in the acidity of the blood caused by a drop in carbon dioxide levels

  2. severe headaches and vomiting

  3. sinus pain and discomfort in the middle ear

  4. lightheadedness associated with an increase in carbon dioxide levels

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Abdominal pain caused by the expansion of gases within the body is most likely to be associated with

  1. a rapid climb in a high performance unpressurised aircraft

  2. a rapid descent in a high performance unpressurised aircraft

  3. a rapid climb in a high performance pressurised aircraft

  4. a rapid descent in a high performance pressurised aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At an altitude of 18000ft the ambient atmospheric pressure is approximately

  1. one third of its sea-level value

  2. one half of its sea-level value

  3. two thirds of its sea-level value

  4. one tenth of its sea-level value

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At a depth of about 30 feet, the underwater pressure is closest to

  1. one and a half times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  2. two times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  3. three times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  4. one half of normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Decompression sickness or the 'bends' is caused by

  1. difficulty experienced in breathing under the high ambient pressure which occurs in deep water

  2. the excess oxygen which dissolves in the blood during a deep dive

  3. the release of dissolved nitrogen from the blood during a rapid ascent from deep water

  4. cramps caused by the low ambient temperature which occurs in deep water

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

A SCUBA diver has just completed a dive which did require decompression stops but was of less than four hours duration. The minimum recommended period which should be allowed before flying is

  1. 4 hours

  2. 12 hours

  3. 24 hours

  4. 48 hours

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would be an appropriate way to combat the effects of hyperventilation?

  1. breathe more rapidly

  2. make a conscious effort to slow down the breathing rate

  3. take a deep breath and hold it

  4. breathe more deeply

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hyperventilation is caused by

  1. too much carbon monoxide in the air

  2. too much carbon dioxide in the air

  3. breathing too fast and/or too deep for the body's requirements

  4. holding the breath too long

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Alcohol can still be detected in the blood for

  1. 14 hours after ingestion

  2. 14 hours after the blood alcohol level has reached .05

  3. 24 hours after ingestion

  4. 24 hours after the blood alcohol level has reached .05

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would be an appropriate remedy for a person who is suffering the effects of hyperventilation?

  1. hold the breath for about 40 seconds

  2. breathe into a paper bag

  3. increase the rate and depth of breathing

  4. use a nasal decongestant

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

If it becomes necessary to take sleeping tablets, how much time should be allowed before flying?

  1. 12 hours

  2. 24 hours

  3. none if they provided a good night's sleep

  4. 8 hours

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

If a pilot completed a SCUBA dive which required decompression stops during ascent and was more than 4 hours duration, which of the following would apply?

  1. a rest at sea-level of at least 24 hours is requred before flying

  2. a rest at sea-level of at least 48 hours is requred before flying

  3. a rest at sea-level of at least 12 hours is requred before flying

  4. a rest at sea-level of at least 6 hours is requred before flying

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2

Answers

The period of validity of a medical certificate for a pilot over forty years of age, unless otherwise cancelled or suspended is

  1. 2 years for student and private pilot licences and 1 year for commercial licences

  2. 2 years for student and 1 year for private pilot licences and commercial licences

  3. 1 year for student and 2 years for private pilot licences and commercial licences

  4. 2 years for all classes of licence

2 years for student and private pilot licences and 1 year for commercial licences

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hyperventilation is likely to result in

  1. a change in the acidity of the blood caused by a drop in carbon dioxide levels

  2. severe headaches and vomiting

  3. sinus pain and discomfort in the middle ear

  4. lightheadedness associated with an increase in carbon dioxide levels

a change in the acidity of the blood caused by a drop in carbon dioxide levels

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Abdominal pain caused by the expansion of gases within the body is most likely to be associated with

  1. a rapid climb in a high performance unpressurised aircraft

  2. a rapid descent in a high performance unpressurised aircraft

  3. a rapid climb in a high performance pressurised aircraft

  4. a rapid descent in a high performance pressurised aircraft

a rapid climb in a high performance unpressurised aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At an altitude of 18000ft the ambient atmospheric pressure is approximately

  1. one third of its sea-level value

  2. one half of its sea-level value

  3. two thirds of its sea-level value

  4. one tenth of its sea-level value

one half of its sea-level value

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

At a depth of about 30 feet, the underwater pressure is closest to

  1. one and a half times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  2. two times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  3. three times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

  4. one half of normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

two times normal sea-level atmospheric pressure

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Decompression sickness or the 'bends' is caused by

  1. difficulty experienced in breathing under the high ambient pressure which occurs in deep water

  2. the excess oxygen which dissolves in the blood during a deep dive

  3. the release of dissolved nitrogen from the blood during a rapid ascent from deep water

  4. cramps caused by the low ambient temperature which occurs in deep water

the release of dissolved nitrogen from the blood during a rapid ascent from deep water

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 2
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

A SCUBA diver has just completed a dive which did require decompression stops but was of less than four hours duration. The minimum recommended period which should be allowed before flying is

  1. 4 hours

  2. 12 hours

  3. 24 hours

  4. 48 hours

12 hours

Back to question

  4. breathe more deeply

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5

Questions

During an approach, what is the effect of a sudden decrease in headwind component on IAS and rate of descent?

  1. IAS and rate of descent would both increase

  2. IAS and rate of descent would both decrease

  3. IAS would decrease and rate of descent would increase

  4. IAS would increase and rate of descent would decrease

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Partial extension of flap in a glide at constant indicated air speed will result in

  1. an increase in rate and angle of descent

  2. a decrease in rate and angle of descent

  3. an increase in rate of descent and a decrease in angle of descent

  4. an increase in angle of descent and a decrease in rate of descent

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

A wind shear on final approach which produces a sudden drop in headwind component will result in

  1. a drop in IAS and a decrease in lift

  2. a rise in IAS and a decrease in lift

  3. a drop in IAS and an increase in lift

  4. a rise in IAS and an increase in lift

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Extension of flap in a glide at a constant indicated air speed will result in

  1. less drag and a steeper approach path

  2. less drag and a shallower approach path

  3. more drag and a steeper approach path

  4. more drag and a shallower approach path

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

If the pilot maintains the same IAS, which of the following would produce the steepest angle of descent?

  1. an increase in power and an increase in flap extension

  2. a decrease in power and an increase in flap extension

  3. an increase in power and a decrease in flap extension

  4. a decrease in power and a decrease in flap extension

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would cause climb performance to decrease?

  1. a reduction in aircraft weight

  2. an increase in thrust available

  3. a turn during the climb

  4. an increase in headwind component

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following describes the effect of a headwind on a descent at constant IAS?

  1. the angle of descent remains the same but the rate of descent increases

  2. the angle of descent decreases but the rate of descent remains the same

  3. the angle of descent increases but the rate of descent increases

  4. the angle of descent increases but the rate of descent remains the same

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

An aircraft is trimmed to cruise in straight and level flight with no flap extended. Which of the following would result if 20deg flap is extended and the aircraft is re-trimmed to maintain straight and level flight with no change in power?

  1. the cruising IAS will increase and the nose attitude will be lower

  2. the cruising IAS will decrease and the nose attitude will be lower

  3. the cruising IAS will increase and the nose attitude will be higher

  4. the cruising IAS will decrease and the nose attitude will be higher

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Compared to nil wind conditions, which of the following effects will be noticed when climbing into a headwind?

  1. both the rate and angle of climb will increase

  2. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will decrease

  3. both the rate and angle of climb will decrease

  4. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will remain unaltered

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

The recommended IAS to achieve the maximum angle of climb at sea-level is 60kt for a particular aircraft. Which of the following would reduce the angle of climb?

  1. a decrease in IAS

  2. a headwind

  3. an increase in air density

  4. a reduction in take-off weight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

If nose attitude and power are kept constant, which of the following would have the effect of decreasing the angle of climb?

  1. an increased headwind component

  2. a decrease in aircraft weight

  3. an increase in air temperature

  4. a decrease in density height

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Comparing the best rate of climb speed to the best angle of climb speed. The best rate of climb occurs

  1. at a lower nose attitude and higher airspeed

  2. at a higher nose attitude and higher airspeed

  3. at a lower nose attitude and lower airspeed

  4. at a higher nose attitude and lower airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would produce the highest reading on the vertical speed indicator?

  1. climbing at the IAS for best angle of climb?

  2. climbing at the IAS lower than that recommended for the best angle of climb?

  3. climbing at the IAS for best rate of climb?

  4. climbing at the IAS lower than that recommended for the best rate of climb?

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following describes the effect of a tailwind on climb performance?

  1. angle of climb is lower and rate of climb is higher

  2. angle of climb is higher and rate of climb is higher

  3. angle of climb is lower and rate of climb is unchanged

  4. angle of climb is higher and rate of climb is unchanged

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following combination of factors would require highest nose attitude in level flight?

  1. an increase in weight and a decrease in airspeed

  2. a decrease in weight and a decrease in airspeed

  3. an increase in weight and an increase in airspeed

  4. a decrease in weight and an increase in airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A5

Answers

During an approach, what is the effect of a sudden decrease in headwind component on IAS and rate of descent?

  1. IAS and rate of descent would both increase

  2. IAS and rate of descent would both decrease

  3. IAS would decrease and rate of descent would increase

  4. IAS would increase and rate of descent would decrease

IAS would decrease and rate of descent would increase

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5

Questions

The limitation imposed by CARs on turns on to the final approach is that the turn shall:

  1. Not be commenced below 500ft. AGL.

  2. Be completed by 500ft. AGL.

  3. Permit a straight-in approach of at least 1,000m from the runway threshold.

  4. Permit a straight-in approach of at least 500m from the perimeter of the aerodrome.

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If climbing after take-off to A085 when should you change from local QNH to Area QNH:

  1. At top of climb

  2. When climbing through 3000 ft

  3. At 1000 ft above the departure aerodrome

  4. When climbing through 5000 ft

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which condition applies to flights within Restricted Area:

  1. Flight within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

  2. Flights within these areas are not permitted under any circumstances

  3. Flights by civil aircraft within these areas is not permitted

  4. Prior approval to enter these areas is not necessary, but flights must proceed in accordance with specific procedures

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are flying home with your friend and his dog. As pilot in command what are your legal responsibilities regarding the carriage of this dog:

  1. The dog must be crated and kept in the baggage compartment

  2. You are not responsible for the animal as it belongs to your friend.

  3. If carried in the passenger compartment, the dog must be restrained, muzzled and sitting on a moisture-absorbent mat

  4. The dog must be restrained and tied next to your passenger.

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Who is responsible for declaring a bush fire evacuation flight as a mercy flight:

  1. The local police

  2. The head of the local fire department

  3. The Pilot in Command

  4. The owner of the aircraft

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The highest obstacle along an unpopulated route segment is 1500 ft AMSL. The minimum altitude at which a VFR aircraft may normally overfly the obstacle is:

  1. 3000 ft

  2. 500 ft

  3. 2000 ft

  4. 1000 ft

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A steady red light signal directed at an aircraft in flight signifies to the pilot that the:

  1. Aircraft should give way to other aircraft and continue circling

  2. Aerodrome is unsafe for landing

  3. Aircraft should climb above the circuit height and orbit the aerodrome

  4. Aircraft's undercarriage is not fully down - Go round

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At what stage of a flight should you change from Area QNH to local QNH (if available) when descending from A075:

  1. At top of descent

  2. In the circuit area

  3. When passing through 5000 ft

  4. Within 3 nm of destination

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A threat that is not immediately obvious to the pilot, such as an undercarriage lever situated adjacent to a flap lever, or manifold pressure and RMP gauges widely separated, is best described as:

  1. A latent threat

  2. An external threat

  3. An anticipated threat

  4. An internal threat

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following restrictions applies to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by pilots:

  1. It may be consumed immediately prior to commencement of duty provided the capacity to act is not impaired

  2. It may not be consumed at any time.

  3. It may be consumed up to, but no within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

  4. It may not be consumed in the 12 hours immediately preceding flight departure.

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A SIGMET is transmitted to a pilot in flight advising of reported mountain wave activity. Select the description which best describes the category of this threat.:

  1. External, unexpected, organisational

  2. Internal, anticipated, environmental

  3. External, anticipated, environmental

  4. Organisational, anticipated, latent

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The holder of a pilot licence may not act as pilot in command of an aeroplane engaged in spinning practice unless:

  1. Accompanied by a suitably qualified flight instructor.

  2. Accompanied by a safety pilot who is the holder of a commercial or higher class licence.

  3. The aeroplane is fitted with fully functional dual controls.

  4. Certified by a suitably qualified flight instructor as being competent to recover from fully developed spins.

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Figure 4 (page 7, Work Booklet). Given the following details: * Runway = 15/33 * Landing distance available = 1300 metres * Slope = 2% down to the SE * Pressure height = 3000 ft * Wind = 150/15 kts * Temperature = +20 Degrees C The Landing distance required is closest to:

  1. 720 metres

  2. 500 metres

  3. 540 metres

  4. 630 metres

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Figure 4 (page 7, Work Booklet). Given the following details: * Runway = 09/27 * Landing distance available = 1400 metres * Slope = Level * Pressure height = 5000 ft * Wind = 270/10 kts * Temperature = +15 Degrees C The landing distance required under the conditions given is closest to:

  1. 670 metres

  2. 600 metres

  3. 630 metres

  4. 700 metres

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to loading system ALPHA (pages 10 and 11, Work Booklet). Given: * Basic index units = -190 * Basic empty weight = 1016 kg * Row 1 (pilot and passenger) = 160 kg * Row (forward facing passengers) = 110 kg * Baggage (total weight) = 95 kg * Baggage will not fit in the rear compartment, so may be loaded in Row 3 or the nose compartment. The maximum weight of fuel, in kg, that may be carried at take-off is closest to:

  1. 252kg

  2. 210 kg

  3. 223 kg

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Take-off distance required will increase if there is an increase in:

  1. Surface air temperature

  2. Air density

  3. Percentage down-slope

  4. Headwind component

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 550 metres

  2. 610 metres

  3. 520 metres

  4. 500 metres

  2. 20, 22, 41

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At 2347 UTC you pinpoint your position over a minor road 5 nm northeast of MUNGINDI township (approximately 60 nm SE YSGE). You have been maintaining a constant HDG since WEE WAA township.   1. 16 degrees left

  2. 07 degrees left

  3. 05 degrees left

  4. 12 degrees left

  4. 04 degrees left

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During a full power check before take-off, at an aerodrome with a high density altitude, some engine roughness is detected. The roughness disappears as the mixture is leaned slightly. Under these circumstances the take-off should:

  1. Be made with full rich mixture, and throttle retarded to the point of smooth running

  2. Not be attempted until a LAME has rectified the problem

  3. Be made with full throttle, full rich mixture, and the roughness accepted for the take-off run

  4. Be made with full throttle, and the mixture leaned to the point of smooth running

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. The battery is being overcharged and may boil

  2. Although the reading is unusual, the electrical system will be unaffected

  3. Instruments requiring electrical power will overread slightly

  4. The alternator has failed and the battery is powering the electrical system

  1. Air pressure below the wing is less than the pressure above the wing

  2. Air pressure above the wing exceeds atmospheric pressure

  3. Lift decreases and drag increases

  4. The wing no longer produces any lift

  4. Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

In the vicinity of an aerodrome within an ADIZ an aircraft is intercepted and is directed to land at the aerodrome. To show that this is understood and will be complied with the pilot of the intercepted aircraft should, by day:

  1. Activate the aircrafts transponder identification function.

  2. Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft.

  3. Raise the aircraft landing gear while passing over the runway at a height of between 1000 and 2000 ft. and circle the aerodrome

  4. Rock the aircrafts wings and follow the intercepting aircraft.

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5

Answers

The limitation imposed by CARs on turns on to the final approach is that the turn shall:

  1. Not be commenced below 500ft. AGL.

  2. Be completed by 500ft. AGL.

  3. Permit a straight-in approach of at least 1,000m from the runway threshold.

  4. Permit a straight-in approach of at least 500m from the perimeter of the aerodrome.

Permit a straight-in approach of at least 500m from the perimeter of the aerodrome.

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If climbing after take-off to A085 when should you change from local QNH to Area QNH:

  1. At top of climb

  2. When climbing through 3000 ft

  3. At 1000 ft above the departure aerodrome

  4. When climbing through 5000 ft

At top of climb

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which condition applies to flights within Restricted Area:

  1. Flight within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

  2. Flights within these areas are not permitted under any circumstances

  3. Flights by civil aircraft within these areas is not permitted

  4. Prior approval to enter these areas is not necessary, but flights must proceed in accordance with specific procedures

Flight within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are flying home with your friend and his dog. As pilot in command what are your legal responsibilities regarding the carriage of this dog:

  1. The dog must be crated and kept in the baggage compartment

  2. You are not responsible for the animal as it belongs to your friend.

  3. If carried in the passenger compartment, the dog must be restrained, muzzled and sitting on a moisture-absorbent mat

  4. The dog must be restrained and tied next to your passenger.

The dog must be crated and kept in the baggage compartment

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Who is responsible for declaring a bush fire evacuation flight as a mercy flight:

  1. The local police

  2. The head of the local fire department

  3. The Pilot in Command

  4. The owner of the aircraft

The Pilot in Command

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The highest obstacle along an unpopulated route segment is 1500 ft AMSL. The minimum altitude at which a VFR aircraft may normally overfly the obstacle is:

  1. 3000 ft

  2. 500 ft

  3. 2000 ft

  4. 1000 ft

2000 ft

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A steady red light signal directed at an aircraft in flight signifies to the pilot that the:

  1. Aircraft should give way to other aircraft and continue circling

  2. Aerodrome is unsafe for landing

  3. Aircraft should climb above the circuit height and orbit the aerodrome

  4. Aircraft's undercarriage is not fully down - Go round

Aircraft should give way to other aircraft and continue circling

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At what stage of a flight should you change from Area QNH to local QNH (if available) when descending from A075:

  1. At top of descent

  2. In the circuit area

  3. When passing through 5000 ft

  4. Within 3 nm of destination

At top of descent

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A threat that is not immediately obvious to the pilot, such as an undercarriage lever situated adjacent to a flap lever, or manifold pressure and RMP gauges widely separated, is best described as:

  1. A latent threat

  2. An external threat

  3. An anticipated threat

  4. An internal threat

A latent threat

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following restrictions applies to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by pilots:

  1. It may be consumed immediately prior to commencement of duty provided the capacity to act is not impaired

  2. It may not be consumed at any time.

  3. It may be consumed up to, but no within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

  4. It may not be consumed in the 12 hours immediately preceding flight departure.

It may be consumed up to, but no within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A SIGMET is transmitted to a pilot in flight advising of reported mountain wave activity. Select the description which best describes the category of this threat.:

  1. External, unexpected, organisational

  2. Internal, anticipated, environmental

  3. External, anticipated, environmental

  4. Organisational, anticipated, latent

External, anticipated, environmental

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The holder of a pilot licence may not act as pilot in command of an aeroplane engaged in spinning practice unless:

  1. Accompanied by a suitably qualified flight instructor.

  2. Accompanied by a safety pilot who is the holder of a commercial or higher class licence.

  3. The aeroplane is fitted with fully functional dual controls.

  4. Certified by a suitably qualified flight instructor as being competent to recover from fully developed spins.

Certified by a suitably qualified flight instructor as being competent to recover from fully developed spins.

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 720 metres

  2. 500 metres

  3. 540 metres

  4. 630 metres

630 metres

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer loading system BRAVO (pages 12 and 13, Work Booklet). Given: * Aircraft empty weight = 1265 lbs with a moment of 101.5 * Oil = 15 lbs with a moment of 0.5 * Pilot = 170 lbs * Co-pilot = 155 lbs * Fuel = 110 litres * Baggage = Maximum permitted The maximum permitted weight of passengers in the rear seats is closest to:

  1. 402 lbs

  2. 369 lbs

  3. 302 lbs

302 lbs

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given: * Pressure height = 6000 feet * OAT = +20 degrees C * CAS = 120 kts Determine the TAS:

  1. 125 kts

  2. 130 kts

  3. 106 kts

  4. 135 kts

135 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Your planned TR is 140 degrees (M). Your planned HDG is 135 degrees (M). Your departure aerodrome has a NDB. If you maintain HDG 135 degrees (M), which "fixed card" ADF indication would confirm that you are on TR:

  1. 185

  2. 180

  3. 175

  4. 315

  5. 135

185

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If the ETA at destination falls within the forecast periods of that aerodrome's TAF with the following conditions, which of condition would ALWAYS require you to nominate an alternate:

  1. PROVISIONAL

  2. PROB

  3. TEMPO

  4. INTER

PROVISIONAL

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You plan to fly NARRABRI (NSW) (3019S 14950E) to ST GEORGE (QLD) (2803S 14807E). For the total flight, which ARFORS are required:

  1. 20, 22, 40

  2. 20, 22, 41

  3. 20, 21, 22

  4. 20, 40, 41

20, 22, 41

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (BOURKE) WAC 3356 (page 30, Work Booklet). You are flying over WEE WAA township, approximately 20 nm WNW of NARRABRI (YNBR) (3019S 14950E), direct to ST GEORGE (YSGE) 2803S 14836E). At 2347 UTC you pinpoint your position over a minor road 5 nm northeast of MUNGINDI township (approximately 60 nm SE YSGE). You have been maintaining a constant HDG since WEE WAA township. The alteration of HDG required to track from the 2347 UTC position to YSGE is closest to:

  1. 16 degrees left

  2. 07 degrees left

  3. 05 degrees left

  4. 12 degrees left

12 degrees left

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At 0255 UTC you pinpoint your position left of track over WOODVALE homestead and alter HDG 10 degrees right. At 0315 UTC you pinpoint your position over MUNGINDI township. The alteration of HDG required to track to YSGE from the 0315 UTC position is closest to:

  1. 15 degrees left

  2. 10 degrees left

  3. 19 degrees left

  4. 04 degrees left

19 degrees left

Back to question

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 135 nm

  2. 210 nm

  3. 305 nm

  4. 365 nm

305 nm

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 28 nm

  2. 16 nm

  3. 13 nm

  4. 21 nm

16 nm

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 273 (M), 138 kts

  2. 293 (M), 110 kts

  3. 294 (M), 115 kts

  4. 292 (M), 140 kts

292 (M), 140 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The following message was issued during a pre-flight briefing: METAR YMLT 2300UTC 0001 25004KT 9999 SCT025 SCT035 18/12 Q 1020. The message is:

  1. A routine aerodrome meteorological report

  2. An aerodrome forecast

  3. A trend type forecast

  4. An aerodrome report issued when conditions have deteriorated below specified limits

A routine aerodrome meteorological report

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The purpose of establishing take-off safety speed is to:

  1. Ensure the greatest rate of climb following take-off

  2. Ensure the greatest climb gradient (angle of climb) following take-off

  3. Ensure that adequate control is available if engine failure occurs following take-off

  4. Provide the lowest speed at which the aeroplane may become airborne

Ensure that adequate control is available if engine failure occurs following take-off

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given an elevation of 1500 feet, a QNH of 1028 hPa, and an air temperature of +35 degrees C, the density height will be closest to:

  1. 2200 ft

  2. 4300 ft

  3. 3700 ft

  4. 4800 ft

3700 ft

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The take-off distance will be decreased with an increase in:

  1. Tailwind component

  2. Stalling speed

  3. Atmospheric pressure

  4. Density height

Atmospheric pressure

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Soon after lifting off from the runway at the take-off safety speed an aeroplane experiences a sudden loss of both lift and airspeed. This could be caused by:

  1. Entering ground effect

  2. Climbing out of ground effect

  3. A sudden increase in headwind component

  4. A sudden decrease in headwind component

A sudden decrease in headwind component

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 190 kts

  2. 195 kts

  3. 202 kts

  4. 152 kts

190 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given: * W/V = 250(M)/30 kts * Runways available = 03/21 and 09/27 Which runway has the greatest headwind component for landing:

  1. 21

  2. 27

  3. 09

  4. 03

27

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer figure 30 (page 36, Work Booklet). Where "D" = 30 nm, Track error = 8 degrees. If a constant HDG has been maintained since 0100 (at "A") and the pilot alters HDG 12 degrees right at time 0112 (at "B"), what time should the pilot expect to intercept track:

  1. 0130

  2. 0136

  3. 0148

  4. 0124

0136

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During winter in Australia, in what direction from the departure aerodrome will the end of daylight (in LMT) be earlier:

  1. South

  2. West

  3. East

  4. North

South

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During summer in Australia, in what direction from the departure aerodrome will the end of daylight (in LMT) be earlier:

  1. West

  2. North

  3. South

  4. East

North

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 280 Deg (M), 30 kts

  2. 340 Deg (M), 40 kts

  3. 280 Deg (M), 30 kts reducing to zero

  4. 280 Deg (T), 30 kts

  5. 340 Deg (T), 40 kts

340 Deg (T), 40 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation
