  1. 290 Deg (T), 15 kts

  2. 260 Deg (T), 25 kts

  3. 290 Deg (M), 15 kts

  4. 280 Deg (T), 10 kts

  5. 260 Deg (M), 25 kts

290 Deg (T), 15 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is an example of a latent threat:

  1. Committing a check list to memory

  2. A poorly written checklist

  3. Engine failure in flight

  4. An encounter with rime ice

A poorly written checklist

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Stalling speed is increased by an increase in:

  1. Angle of attack

  2. Power

  3. Flap setting

  4. Load factor

Load factor

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

What effect will a headwind have on the rate of climb:

  1. Rate of climb increases

  2. Rate of climb decreases

  3. Rate of climb remains unchanged

Rate of climb remains unchanged

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A type of threat which is best managed by maintaining a high skill level through practice and training is:

  1. An anticipated threat

  2. A latent threat

  3. An unexpected threat

  4. An organisational threat

An unexpected threat

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Climbing an aeroplane at a higher speed than that recommended for best rate of climb will result in:

  1. An increases rate and decreased angle of climb

  2. An increased rate and angle of climb

  3. A decreased rate and angle of climb

  4. A decreased rate and increased angle of climb

A decreased rate and angle of climb

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following would be best described as an internal threat:

  1. Flight into a high traffic density area

  2. An air traffic controller with a heavy foreign accent

  3. A pilot with a tendency to be over confident

  4. A maintenance release that is incorrectly filled in

A pilot with a tendency to be over confident

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Fig 48 (page 44 Work Booklet) The line J K (just to the east of Melbourne) indicates the position of a:

  1. Cold Front

  2. Stationary Front

  3. Warm Front

  4. Occluded Front

Cold Front

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Fig 49 (page 44 Work Booklet) The pressure pattern about the point B (east of Brisbane QLD) is known as a:

  1. Ridge

  2. High

  3. Col

  4. Low

High

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Flying conditions above a layer of small cumulus clouds are likely to be:

  1. Smooth

  2. Bumpy

  3. Very Turbulent

  4. Smooth but with strong updraughts

Smooth

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following procedures would be most effective in rectifying a high cylinder head temperature indication:

  1. Maintain power setting, enrich the mixture

  2. Decrease power setting, enrich the mixture

  3. Maintain the power setting, lean the mixture

  4. Decrease power setting, lean the mixture

Decrease power setting, enrich the mixture

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During a full power check before take-off, at an aerodrome with a high density altitude, some engine roughness is detected. The roughness disappears as the mixture is leaned slightly. Under these circumstances the take-off should:

  1. Be made with full rich mixture, and throttle retarded to the point of smooth running

  2. Not be attempted until a LAME has rectified the problem

  3. Be made with full throttle, full rich mixture, and the roughness accepted for the take-off run

  4. Be made with full throttle, and the mixture leaned to the point of smooth running

Be made with full throttle, and the mixture leaned to the point of smooth running

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During flight, a centre-zero ammeter shows an abnormally high positive reading for an extended period of time. The correct interpretation of this is that:

  1. The battery is being overcharged and may boil

  2. Although the reading is unusual, the electrical system will be unaffected

  3. Instruments requiring electrical power will overread slightly

  4. The alternator has failed and the battery is powering the electrical system

The battery is being overcharged and may boil

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aerofoil is said to be its stalling angle if any increase or decrease in angle of attack results in:

  1. Less lift and less drag

  2. More drag

  3. Less lift

  4. A lower L/D ratio

Less lift

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A result of exceeding the stalling angle is that:

  1. Air pressure below the wing is less than the pressure above the wing

  2. Air pressure above the wing exceeds atmospheric pressure

  3. Lift decreases and drag increases

  4. The wing no longer produces any lift

Lift decreases and drag increases

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following effects will result from moving the centre of gravity aft:

  1. The indicated stalling speed will increase

  2. Greater elevator deflection is required to achieve a given change in attitude

  3. The stalling angle will increase

  4. Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At which IAS should a piston-engine aeroplane be flown to achieve maximum endurance in level flight:

  1. The speed which gives the best lift-drag ratio

  2. The speed requiring minimum power

  3. The lowest possible speed

  4. The speed requiring minimum thrust

The speed requiring minimum power

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

From the list below, select the variable, which would result in an increase in the rate of climb:

  1. Lowering take-off flap

  2. A reduction in gross weight

  3. An increase in headwind component

  4. A decrease in Air density

A reduction in gross weight

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is a likely reason for a yaw to the right during the take-off roll in a single-engine aeroplane fitted with an engine, which rotates in a clockwise direction when viewed from the cockpit:

  1. A crosswind from the left

  2. Slipstream effect

  3. A crosswind from the right

  4. Torque effect

A crosswind from the right

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During flight, drag always acts parallel to the:

  1. Thrust line

  2. Relative airflow

  3. Wing chord

  4. Longitudinal axis

Relative airflow

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

What effect will a headwind have on the angle and rate of climb:

  1. The angle and rate will both increase

  2. The angle will decrease and the rate will increase

  3. The angle will increase and the rate will remain unchanged

  4. The angle will increase and the rate will decrease

The angle will increase and the rate will remain unchanged

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An increase in which of the parameters listed below will always result in an increase in Induced Drag:

  1. Aspect ratio

  2. L/D ratio

  3. IAS

  4. Angle of attack

Angle of attack

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer: to the L/D ratio graph at Fig 42 (page 40 Work Booklet) At what speed would an aeroplane be operating if flying at angle of attack X:

  1. The maximum level flight speed

  2. The minimum level flight speed

  3. The speed for maximum glide range

  4. The speed for maximum angle of climb

The speed for maximum glide range

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If the indicated stalling speed of an aircraft is 60kt in straight and level flight what is the indicated stalling speed in a balanced 60 degree turn:

  1. 75 kts

  2. 60 kts

  3. 70 kts

  4. 85 kts

85 kts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which hazard is normally associated with mountain waves:

  1. Turbulence

  2. Icing

  3. Duststorms

  4. Hail

Turbulence

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following conditions is most likely to result in thunderstorms:

  1. High relative humidity at the surface, a lifting mechanism and conditional instability

  2. High relative humidity at the surface, subsidence and a neutral atmosphere

  3. Low relative humidity at the surface, a lifting mechanism and instability

  4. High relative humidity at the surface, a lifting mechanism and a stable atmosphere

High relative humidity at the surface, a lifting mechanism and conditional instability

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The cloud type which is indicative of mountain waves, when seen above a mountain range is

  1. Cumulus

  2. Lenticular

  3. Stratus

  4. Cirrus

Lenticular

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilots susceptibility to visual illusions during approaches will be increased by:

  1. The amount and nature of the pilots flying experience

  2. Fatigue

  3. Good night adaptation

  4. The presence of good glideslpoe guidance

Fatigue

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Regarding drugs, which can be taken without the approval of a DAME:

  1. Only prescription drugs are permitted

  2. Only non-prescription are permitted

  3. Only legal drugs are permitted

  4. No drugs are permitted

No drugs are permitted

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Hyperventilation may be caused by:

  1. Overbreathing

  2. Underbreathing

  3. Breathing too much carbon dioxide

  4. Breathing too much carbon monoxide

Overbreathing

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The ARFOR indicates that there will be BROKEN stratus with the cloud top at 3000 feet AMSL along your planned route OCTA. You plan VFR using radio navigation aids along this route. Your planned track is 085 Deg (M). To maintain VMC and conform to the Table of Cruising Levels what is the lowest altitude that you can plan:

  1. A035.

  2. A030.

  3. A050.

  4. A055.

A055.

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If you observe that the cloud amount is significantly greater than that is forecast, the type of report you should submit is called a:

  1. SIGMET

  2. TRENT

  3. SPECI

  4. SHORT AIREP

SHORT AIREP

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the vicinity of an aerodrome within an ADIZ an aircraft is intercepted and is directed to land at the aerodrome. To show that this is understood and will be complied with the pilot of the intercepted aircraft should, by day:

  1. Activate the aircrafts transponder identification function.

  2. Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft.

  3. Raise the aircraft landing gear while passing over the runway at a height of between 1000 and 2000 ft. and circle the aerodrome

  4. Rock the aircrafts wings and follow the intercepting aircraft.

Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft.

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot is put under pressure from his employer to get back to base before his tour of duty expires. This is an example of:

  1. An external threat

  2. An anticipated threat

  3. An environmental threat

  4. A latent threat

A latent threat

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aircraft piston engine will experience severe detonation when operated with:

  1. Maximum continuous power in level flight

  2. A mixture of AVGAS and ATUR fuel

  3. An over rich mixture during climb

  4. A low power setting and carburettor heat full on

A mixture of AVGAS and ATUR fuel

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Optical illusions such as black hole effect and sloping runways are examples of:

  1. An internal threat

  2. An anticipated threat

  3. A latent environmental threat

  4. A latent internal threat

A latent environmental threat

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An increase in headwind component, while gliding at the recommended best gliding speed, would result in:

  1. A decrease in the rate of descent

  2. An increase in the glide range

  3. An increase in the rate of descent

  4. A decrease in the glide range

A decrease in the glide range

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 5
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3

Questions

Drag is that component of the total reaction which acts

  1. at right angles to the relative airflow

  2. opposite to the direction of motion and parallel to the relative airflow

  3. at right angles to the chord line

  4. in the same direction as motion and parallel to the relative airflow

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The chief source of drag on an aircraft flying level at low airspeed is

  1. lift is no longer acting at right angles to the relative airflow

  2. air spilling over the wingtips producing vortices and eddies

  3. the angle of attack being lower than at normal cruising speed

  4. the elevator requiring a large degree of deflection

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The form of drag which predominates at low airspeed is called

  1. parasite drag

  2. total drag

  3. airflow drag

  4. induced drag

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The form of drag which predominates at high airspeed is called

  1. parasite drag

  2. total drag

  3. airflow drag

  4. induced drag

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

As airspeed is increased in level flight from just above stalling speed to maximum speed, the induced drag acting

  1. increases continuously

  2. decreases continuously

  3. increases then decreases

  4. decreases then increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

As airspeed is increased in level flight from just above stalling speed to maximum speed, the parasite drag acting

  1. increases continuously

  2. decreases continuously

  3. increases then decreases

  4. decreases then increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The combined effect of induced drag and parasite drag gives rise to total drag. The *least* total drag occurs

  1. at low airspeed when parasite drag is lowest

  2. at high airspeed when parasite drag is lowest

  3. at an intermediate airspeed when both induced and parasite drag are fairly low

  4. at the stalling speed when the speed of the relative airflow is lowest

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

As speed is reduced in level flight from maximum speed to the stalling speed, the total drag acting

  1. increases continuously

  2. decreases continuously

  3. increases then decreases

  4. decreases then increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

A wing enjoys its maximum efficiency in level flight when

  1. airspeed is highest

  2. airspeed is lowest

  3. total drag is least

  4. lift is greatest

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The best lift/drag ratio occurs

  1. at the stalling angle where maximum lift is being produced

  2. at the smallest possible angle of attack where minimum drag is being produced

  3. at a medium angle of attack where the required lift is accompanied by least drag

  4. at the lowest airspeed where the least disturbance to the airflow occurs

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3

Answers

Drag is that component of the total reaction which acts

  1. at right angles to the relative airflow

  2. opposite to the direction of motion and parallel to the relative airflow

  3. at right angles to the chord line

  4. in the same direction as motion and parallel to the relative airflow

opposite to the direction of motion and parallel to the relative airflow

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The chief source of drag on an aircraft flying level at low airspeed is

  1. lift is no longer acting at right angles to the relative airflow

  2. air spilling over the wingtips producing vortices and eddies

  3. the angle of attack being lower than at normal cruising speed

  4. the elevator requiring a large degree of deflection

air spilling over the wingtips producing vortices and eddies

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3

  1. parasite drag

  2. total drag

  3. airflow drag

  4. induced drag

induced drag

  1. parasite drag

  2. total drag

  3. airflow drag

  4. induced drag

parasite drag

  3. increases then decreases

  4. decreases then increases

  1. increases continuously

  2. decreases continuously

  3. increases then decreases

  4. decreases then increases

increases continuously

  4. at the stalling speed when the speed of the relative airflow is lowest

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

A wing enjoys its maximum efficiency in level flight when

  1. airspeed is highest

  2. airspeed is lowest

  3. total drag is least

  4. lift is greatest

total drag is least

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

The best lift/drag ratio occurs

  1. at the stalling angle where maximum lift is being produced

  2. at the smallest possible angle of attack where minimum drag is being produced

  3. at a medium angle of attack where the required lift is accompanied by least drag

  4. at the lowest airspeed where the least disturbance to the airflow occurs

at a medium angle of attack where the required lift is accompanied by least drag

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A3
RPL,Bob Tait

Flight Radio Operator Licence

Questions

*Initial contact* ARCHER TOWER. Callsign AFR

Answer
Flight Radio Operator Licence
RPL,Flight Radio Operator Licence

*Readback* Delta Alpha November cleared to land runway two eight right

Answer
Flight Radio Operator Licence
RPL,Flight Radio Operator Licence

*Readback* India Echo Sierra descend to and maintain three thousand five hundred

Answer
Flight Radio Operator Licence
RPL,Flight Radio Operator Licence

*Readback* Oscar Romeo Echo squawk two thousand

Flight Radio Operator Licence
RPL,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Archer Tower Alpha Foxtrot Romeo

three thousand five hundred India Echo Sierra

Flight Radio Operator Licence
RPL,Flight Radio Operator Licence

*Readback* Oscar Romeo Echo squawk two thousand

two thousand Oscar Romeo Echo [transponder to 2000]

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1

Questions

The onset of detonation in an engine is indicated by

  1. vibration, rising temperatures and reduced indicated air speed

  2. vibration, falling temperatures and reduced indicated air speed

  3. vibration, rising temperatures and increased indicated air speed

  4. vibration, falling temperatures and increased indicated air speed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

Applying carburettor heat when ice is present in the carburettor is accompanied by

  1. a drop in engine RPM with no further change

  2. a drop in engine RPM followed by a rise

  3. an immediate rise in engine RPM

  4. an initial rise in engine RPM followed by a drop

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The application of carburettor heat when no ice is present in the carburettor is accompanied by

  1. a drop in engine RPM with no further change

  2. a drop in engine RPM followed by a rise

  3. an immediate rise in engine RPM

  4. an initial rise in engine RPM followed by a drop

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The reason for filling the tanks of an aircraft which is left parked over night in cold weather is

  1. to prevent water from collecting in the tank due to condensation

  2. to increase the weight of the aircraft in case of strong wind gusts

  3. to ensure you don't get caught if the price of fuel goes up overnight

  4. to prevent contamination from entering the tank through the vent

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The pressure exerted on the piston during the power stroke increases as the amount of gas induced

  1. increases and combustion temperature increases

  2. decreases and combustion temperature increases

  3. increases and combustion temperature decreases

  4. decreases and combustion temperature decreases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

As the throttle is moved towards the fully open position

  1. manifold pressure increases and gas flow decreases

  2. manifold pressure decreases and gas flow increases

  3. manifold pressure increases and gas flow increases

  4. manifold pressure decreases and gas flow decreases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The best action to take at the onset of detonation in an engine is

  1. lean the mixture and reduce the power

  2. lean the mixture and increase the power

  3. decrease the indicated air speed and maintain the power

  4. select mixture fully rich and decrease the power

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The colour of 100 octane low lead [100 LL] aviation fuel is

  1. green

  2. red

  3. blue

  4. clear

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following is the correct sequence for the four strokes of a four-stroke internal combustion engine?

  1. induction, compression, exhaust and power

  2. induction, power, compression and exhaust

  3. induction, exhaust, compression and power

  4. induction, compression, power and exhaust

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

If AVTUR was misidentified as AVGAS and added to the tanks of a piston engine aircraft, which of the following would be the most likely result?

  1. engine damage due to the extra power generated at take-off

  2. reduced power output and low engine temperature

  3. increased power output and high engine temperature

  4. reduced power output due to severe detonation

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

If a blockage in a fuel tank vent in a gravity fed system is not discovered and removed before flight

  1. there will be no effect providing the aircraft remains at low level

  2. the engine will not start

  3. fuel is likely to be lost overboard during flight

  4. the engine may fail completely due to fuel starvation

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

The octane rating of a fuel is a measure of

  1. its specific gravity

  2. its resistance to detonation

  3. its resistance to vaporisation

  4. its anti-misting properties in the event of fire

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision General Knowledge 1
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors

Questions

Select the item which best describes an external threat

  1. a noisy intoxicated passenger

  2. a pilot suffering from the effects of a hangover

  3. another aircraft entering the runway while you are on late final

  4. difficulty in understanding the transmission of a foreign pilot

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Select the item which best describes an indesired aircraft state

  1. arrival over the threshold too high and too fast on a landing approach

  2. failing to notice a damaged tyre during a daily inspection

  3. failure to realise that a destination aerodrome requires an alternate

  4. aircraft overdue for its annual inspection

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

An example of an expected threat is

  1. thunderstorms forecast on the TAF

  2. engine failure in flight

  3. becoming lost in flight

  4. being diverted in flight by ATC

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

For the flight crew, the three basic components in the TEM model are

  1. threats, errors and undesired aircraft states

  2. threats, errors and anticipated aircraft states

  3. threats, flight crew human resources and aircraft states

  4. errors, flight crew human resources and undesired aircraft states

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would be classified as an external threat

  1. pressure to meet timetables

  2. pilot fatigue

  3. health and fitness

  4. lack of familiarity with other crew members

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

An example of a latent threat is

  1. undercarriage will not retract in flight

  2. wind gusts exceeding the aircraft's cross wind limitations for landing

  3. poor aircraft equipment design

  4. unexpected high traffic volume in the terminal area

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Entering the incorrect way-point data while operating in a stressful cockpit environment is an example of

  1. an environmental threat leading to a configuration error

  2. an organisational threat leading to a committed error

  3. an expected threat leading to an unexpected error

  4. an unexpected threat leading to an expected error

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The three primary categories of error in the TEM model are

  1. loss of heading control, loss of attitude control and loss of airspeed control

  2. navigational error, radio frequency error and navigation aid error

  3. crew resource error, airtrafffic control error and ground handling error

  4. aircraft handling errors, procedural errors and communication errors

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Undesired aircraft states are categorised by the TEM model as

  1. aircraft handling, ground handling and incorrect aircraft configuration

  2. aircraft ground handling, vertical navigation and incorrect inflight configuration

  3. vertical navigation, ground handling and inflight navigation

  4. aircraft configuration, ground handling and inflight aircraft handling

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Track and speed deviation are examples of

  1. ground navigation state

  2. aircraft handling state

  3. horizontal navigation state

  4. aircraft configuration state

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Unauthorised penetration of controlled airspace is an example of an undesired

  1. ground navigation state

  2. aircraft handling state

  3. air navigation state

  4. navigation configuration state

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Being positioned at the incorrect holding point prior to take-off is an example of an undesired

  1. aircraft handling state

  2. aircraft ground configuration state

  3. situational awareness state

  4. ground navigation state

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Incorrect navigation aid setting is an example of

  1. ground navigation state

  2. aircraft navigation state

  3. horizontal navigation state

  4. situational awareness state

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

With regard to TEM, the use of a checklist prior to take-off is an example of

  1. a desirable aircraft state

  2. a safety state

  3. a countermeasure

  4. a safety tactic

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

When considering the risk any threat imposes you should consider

  1. the probability of encountering the threat irrespective of the consequences

  2. the seriousness of the consequences irrespective of the probability of encountering the threat

  3. the probability of encountering the threat and the seriousness of the consequences

  4. the probability of encountering the threat at any stage during the flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

When an undesired aircraft state is identified the primary task should be

  1. identify the error which led to the undesired aircraft state

  2. identify and correct the error which led to the undesired aircraft state

  3. deal with the undesired aircraft state and return to controlled stabilised flight

  4. advise ATC of the undesired aircraft state

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

One measure of the effectiveness of actions taken by a crew to manage threats is

  1. the accuracy of the crew's recall of events during de-briefing

  2. the speed with which the crew acted to manage the threat

  3. whether the threat was detected in time for the crew to respond appropriately

  4. whether an undesired aircraft state was avoided

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The most proactive option in thread management is to

  1. anticipate the recovery action required if the threat occurs

  2. anticipate and avoid the threat altogether

  3. take corrective action once the threat has occurred

  4. concentrate on management of any undesired aircraft state that may result

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Mismanaged threats usually lead to

  1. errors which are then linked to undesired aircraft states

  2. undesired aircraft states which are then linked to errors

  3. aircraft handling errors which then lead to environmental errors

  4. diversion from standard operating procedures

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

With regard to TEM, a cockpit systems failure warning light is an example of

  1. a proactive decision making process

  2. a systemic-based countermeasure

  3. an undesired aircraft state management device

  4. a handling error countermeasure

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance Threats and Errors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3

Questions

Which of the following is a function of the middle ear?

  1. to protect the eardrum from the intrusion of foreign bodies

  2. to amplify the vibrations arriving at the eardrum and transfer them to the cochlea

  3. to convert the mechanical energy of vibrations to nerve impulses

  4. to assist in maintaining the sense of balance

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is a function of the inner ear?

  1. to protect the eardrum from the intrusion of foreign bodies

  2. to amplify the vibrations arriving at the eardrum and transfer them to the cochlea

  3. to convert the mechanical energy of vibrations to nerve impulses and assist in maintaining the sense of balance

  4. to equalise the pressure on either side of the eardrum

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following mediates the sense of balance?

  1. the cochlea

  2. the semicircular canals

  3. the hammer, anvil and stirrup

  4. the eustachian tube

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Deterioration of hearing caused by exposure to loud noise usually occurs first

  1. in the high frequency range, above normal speech

  2. in the frequency range of normal speech, 300 to 5000Hz

  3. in the frequency range below normal speech

  4. across the whole range of audible frequencies

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is the minimum noise level that would mark the onset of temporary or permanent deafness after prolonged exposure?

  1. 85dB

  2. 110dB

  3. 140dB

  4. 160dB

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is the function of the eustachian tube in the human respiratory system?

  1. it connects the middle ear to the outer ear

  2. it connects the middle ear to the inner ear

  3. it connects the middle ear to the throat cavity

  4. it connects the inner ear to the throat cavity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hearing loss due to long-term exposure to high noise levels is usually first noticed in the loss of sensitivity to

  1. high frequency sounds

  2. low frequency sounds

  3. medium frequency sounds

  4. all frequencies of sound

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which part of the ear is most affected by pressure differences when the eustachian tube is blocked?

  1. the outer ear

  2. the middle ear

  3. the inner ear

  4. the ear lobe

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3

Answers

Which of the following is a function of the middle ear?

  1. to protect the eardrum from the intrusion of foreign bodies

  2. to amplify the vibrations arriving at the eardrum and transfer them to the cochlea

  3. to convert the mechanical energy of vibrations to nerve impulses

  4. to assist in maintaining the sense of balance

to amplify the vibrations arriving at the eardrum and transfer them to the cochlea

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is a function of the inner ear?

  1. to protect the eardrum from the intrusion of foreign bodies

  2. to amplify the vibrations arriving at the eardrum and transfer them to the cochlea

  3. to convert the mechanical energy of vibrations to nerve impulses and assist in maintaining the sense of balance

  4. to equalise the pressure on either side of the eardrum

to convert the mechanical energy of vibrations to nerve impulses and assist in maintaining the sense of balance

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following mediates the sense of balance?

  1. the cochlea

  2. the semicircular canals

  3. the hammer, anvil and stirrup

  4. the eustachian tube

the semicircular canals

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Deterioration of hearing caused by exposure to loud noise usually occurs first

  1. in the high frequency range, above normal speech

  2. in the frequency range of normal speech, 300 to 5000Hz

  3. in the frequency range below normal speech

  4. across the whole range of audible frequencies

in the high frequency range, above normal speech

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is the minimum noise level that would mark the onset of temporary or permanent deafness after prolonged exposure?

  1. 85dB

  2. 110dB

  3. 140dB

  4. 160dB

85dB

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is the function of the eustachian tube in the human respiratory system?

  1. it connects the middle ear to the outer ear

  2. it connects the middle ear to the inner ear

  3. it connects the middle ear to the throat cavity

  4. it connects the inner ear to the throat cavity

it connects the middle ear to the throat cavity

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hearing loss due to long-term exposure to high noise levels is usually first noticed in the loss of sensitivity to

  1. high frequency sounds

  2. low frequency sounds

  3. medium frequency sounds

  4. all frequencies of sound

high frequency sounds

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which part of the ear is most affected by pressure differences when the eustachian tube is blocked?

  1. the outer ear

  2. the middle ear

  3. the inner ear

  4. the ear lobe

the middle ear

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 3
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4

Questions

The application of high power with low airspeed is accompanied by

  1. engine torque producing a roll

  2. a reduction in elevator effectiveness

  3. engine torque producing a yaw

  4. slipstream effect producing a roll

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

The effect of propellor slipstream on a single-engine aeroplane is to

  1. produce a yaw at low IAS and high power

  2. produce a roll at low IAS and high power

  3. produce a yaw at high IAS and low power

  4. product a nose-down pitch at low IAS and high power

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

The effect of a strong crosswind from the left while taxiing on level ground is

  1. the aircraft will tend to yaw to the left

  2. the aircraft will tend to yaw to the right

  3. the aircraft will tend to roll to the left

  4. the aircraft will tend to roll and yaw to the right

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Consider an aircraft flying at 5,500ft in a headwind. Under these conditions

  1. IAS would be higher than TAS which would be higher than GS

  2. GS would be higher than TAS which would be higher than IAS

  3. IAS would be higher than TAS which would be lower than GS

  4. IAS would be lower than TAS which would be higher than GS

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would be most effective in reducing induced drag?

  1. fitting wheel fairings

  2. streamlining all surfaces exposed to the airflow

  3. fitting wing root fairings

  4. increasing the aspect ratio of the wing

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

If airspeed is kept constant, which of the following is an effect of extending flap during level flight?

  1. lift increases and drag decreases

  2. lift increases and drag increases

  3. lift decreases and drag decreases

  4. lift decreases and drag increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following is an effect of lowering full flap during a glide?

  1. a steeper descent path may be flown at the same airspeed

  2. the extra lift will produce a flatter descent path

  3. the aircraft will be able to fly down the same descent path at a lower airspeed

  4. forward visibility will be reduced

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Under what circumstances should flap be used for take-off?

  1. flap should never be used for take-off under any circumstances

  2. flap should be used only as specified by the manufacturer

  3. full flap should be used if the field is of marginal length

  4. flap should be used during the take-off roll if the pilot feels it is necessary

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

If airspeed is kept constant, which of the following is an effect of extending flap during level flight?

  1. a higher nose attitude is required to maintain lift

  2. it is possible to fly level with a lower nose attitude

  3. less power is required to maintain a given airspeed

  4. the elevator and rudder controls will become more effective

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

If all other factors remain the same, what effect will a decrease in air density have on the take off distance required?

  1. the distance required increases

  2. the distance required remains the same unless weight is increased

  3. the distance required decreases because of reduced drag

  4. the distance required remains the same providing full power is used

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the figures below correctly shows the relative positions of the tailplane, elevator and trim tab on an aircraft which has been trimmed for level flight at low airspeed?

  1. elevator deflecting upward from aerofoil, trim tab deflecting downward from elevator

  2. elevator deflecting downward from aerofoil, trim tab deflecting downward from elevator

  3. elevator deflecting downward from aerofoil, trim tab deflecting upward from elevator

  4. elevator deflecting upward from aerofoil, trim tab deflecting upward from elevator

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Compared to nil wind conditions, a tailwind component during take-off will result in

  1. a decrease in the distance required for take-off

  2. an increase in the distance required for take-off

  3. a decrease in the IAS required for take-off

  4. an increase in the IAS required for take-off

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following combination of factors would have the most detrimental effect on the take-off performance of an aeroplane?

  1. high temperature, high airfield elevation and a high pressure system

  2. high temperature, high airfield elevation and a low pressure system

  3. low temperature, low airfield elevation and a low pressure system

  4. high temperature, low airfield elevation and a low pressure system

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

If frost forms on the wings of an aircraft overnight and is not removed before flight

  1. the acceleration during the take-off run will be less than normal

  2. the stalling angle will be higher than normal

  3. the take-off distance could be greatly increased

  4. there will be an increase in stalling speed and stalling angle

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

The purpose of aerodynamic balancing of control surfaces is to

  1. lighten the in-flight loads on the control column

  2. prevent the control surface from fluttering

  3. to increase the rate at which the aircraft responds to control inputs

  4. ensure the aircraft will be controllable at low airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A4
RPL,Bob Tait

RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you acknowledge the following instruction from air control: *Delta Romeo Yankee, squawk 4162*?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you acknowledge the following: *Delta Romeo Yankee, squawk normal*?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If you squawk on code 7600, what does it mean?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In an emergency, what code would you select?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3

Answers

Radio transmissions fall into three categories: reports, broadcasts and calls. Explain these.

Reports are made to a specific air traffic services unit i.e. air traffic control or FLIGHTWATCH, as appropriate. Broadcasts are mandatory or voluntary traffic advisory transmissions prefixed with "all stations". Calls are made to specfic stations, e.g. when requesting information from air traffic services or FLIGHTWATCH or when contacting another aircraft direct to arrange mutual separation.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In general terms, what should you transmit when establishing radio contact?

The name of the station you are calling plus your callsign.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If you were in VH-POW, how would you establish contact with Cairns Tower?

Cairns Tower, Papa Oscar Whisky.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Having established radio contact on a particular frequency and there is no danger of confusion with another aircraft or another ground station, what procedure is adopted for subsequent transmissions?

The callsign of the addressed station is dropped.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How should you acknowledge calls directed at your aircraft?

With your callsign.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Which of the following is/are required to be read back? (a) Clear to taxi. (b) Clearance to track via the Westgate Bridge, one thousand five hundred. (c) Line up. (d) Cleared for takeoff. (e) Amended route track via the city, eight thousand. (f) Cleared to land.

All clearances from (a) to (f).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Does the pilot need to read back any item notified in an airways clearance as *amended*?

Yes.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Should cruise levels specified in an airways clearance granted to you by air traffic control for flight in controlled airspace be read back?

Yes, they should.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What standard phrase would you include when making a radio check call on the ground prior to starting up for a flight?

Radio check (and if you want, add "how do you read?")

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you reply to a perfectly readable check call?

[Callsign], reading you five.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you respond to a check call that was readable, but with difficulty?

[Callsign], reading you three.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If a response to your signal check inflight is *reading you four*, how would you interpret this?

Readable, but not perfect.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

You are the pilot of VH-DRY. How would air traffic control tell you to turn the transponder on?

Delta Romeo Yankee, squawk normal.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What is meant by *squawk ident*?

Press the transponder ident button.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What is meant by *squawk standby*?

Select standby on the transponder.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you acknowledge the following instruction from air control: *Delta Romeo Yankee, squawk 4162*?

Four one six two, Delta Romeo Yankee.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you acknowledge the following: *Delta Romeo Yankee, squawk normal*?

Delta Romeo Yankee.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If you squawk on code 7600, what does it mean?

A radio failure.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In an emergency, what code would you select?

Code 7700.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 3
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology

Questions

Which conditions are most likely to produce radiation fog?

  1. thin overcast with no wind

  2. broken cloud with no wind

  3. nil cloud and light wind

  4. scattered cumulus with light wind

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

During what stage of a thunderstorm would lightning be most frequent?

  1. before any precipitation

  2. during the most rapid growth

  3. at the mature stage

  4. during the dissipating stage

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The lifting of fog may be caused by

  1. a fall of temperature

  2. the formation of upper cloud

  3. an increase in wind strength

  4. an increase in humidity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Which phenomena in a thunderstorm causes low level wind shear at some distance away from the cell?

  1. updraft

  2. downdraft

  3. hail

  4. turbulence

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Where are tornadoes most likely to be encountered?

  1. over hot desert country

  2. with mountain waves

  3. strong low pressure systems

  4. wide spread severe thunderstorm activity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Which process is involved in the formation of hoar frost?

  1. accumulation of ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere

  2. liquid water freezing on impact with the aircraft surface

  3. deposition of ice directly from the water vapour mixed with the air

  4. freezing of large supercooled water droplets

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The condition most likely to produce advection fog is

  1. cold air passing over a cold surface

  2. warm air passing over a warm surface

  3. cold air passing over a warm surface

  4. warm air passing over a cold surface

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

One of the prerequisites for the formation of a thunderstorm is

  1. the presence of moist air through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

  2. a rapid drop in surface temperature with an increase in wind strength

  3. a gradual increase in cloud cover above 20000ft

  4. a cold isothermal layer through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Advection fog forms when

  1. cold air passing over a cold surface

  2. warm air passing over a warm surface

  3. cold air passing over a warm surface

  4. warm air passing over a cold surface

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Dust storms are most likely to produce which of the following hazards?

  1. severe visibility restriction in a localised area below 10000ft

  2. severe visibility restriction over a widespread area below 10000ft

  3. severe visibility restriction over a localised area to heights above 10000ft

  4. severe visibility restriction over a widespread area to heights above 10000ft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The most dangerous effect of a mature thunderstorm is

  1. turbulence

  2. lightning

  3. hail

  4. icing

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Slant visibility in fog causes

  1. reduced visibility towards the sun

  2. the runway is visible from 'over the top' but not in the circuit area or on final

  3. better visibility looking up than down

  4. runway visual range is less than meteorological visibility

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The runway at a coastal aerodrome runs parallel to the coast. When would the crosswind component be likely to be strongest?

  1. early in the morning

  2. late at night

  3. in the early afternoon

  4. at sunset

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology

Answers

Which conditions are most likely to produce radiation fog?

  1. thin overcast with no wind

  2. broken cloud with no wind

  3. nil cloud and light wind

  4. scattered cumulus with light wind

nil cloud and light wind

  2. during the most rapid growth

  3. at the mature stage

  4. during the dissipating stage

  4. wide spread severe thunderstorm activity

wide spread severe thunderstorm activity

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Which process is involved in the formation of hoar frost?

  1. accumulation of ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere

  2. liquid water freezing on impact with the aircraft surface

  3. deposition of ice directly from the water vapour mixed with the air

  4. freezing of large supercooled water droplets

deposition of ice directly from the water vapour mixed with the air

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The condition most likely to produce advection fog is

  1. cold air passing over a cold surface

  2. warm air passing over a warm surface

  3. cold air passing over a warm surface

  4. warm air passing over a cold surface

warm air passing over a cold surface

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

One of the prerequisites for the formation of a thunderstorm is

  1. the presence of moist air through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

  2. a rapid drop in surface temperature with an increase in wind strength

  3. a gradual increase in cloud cover above 20000ft

  4. a cold isothermal layer through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

the presence of moist air through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Advection fog forms when

  1. cold air passing over a cold surface

  2. warm air passing over a warm surface

  3. cold air passing over a warm surface

  4. warm air passing over a cold surface

warm air passing over a cold surface

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Dust storms are most likely to produce which of the following hazards?

  1. severe visibility restriction in a localised area below 10000ft

  2. severe visibility restriction over a widespread area below 10000ft

  3. severe visibility restriction over a localised area to heights above 10000ft

  4. severe visibility restriction over a widespread area to heights above 10000ft

severe visibility restriction over a widespread area to heights above 10000ft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The most dangerous effect of a mature thunderstorm is

  1. turbulence

  2. lightning

  3. hail

  4. icing

turbulence

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Slant visibility in fog causes

  1. reduced visibility towards the sun

  2. the runway is visible from 'over the top' but not in the circuit area or on final

  3. better visibility looking up than down

  4. runway visual range is less than meteorological visibility

the runway is visible from 'over the top' but not in the circuit area or on final

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The runway at a coastal aerodrome runs parallel to the coast. When would the crosswind component be likely to be strongest?

  1. early in the morning

  2. late at night

  3. in the early afternoon

  4. at sunset

in the early afternoon

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Part 13 Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7

Questions

What transponder code should you select if you suffer a VHF-COM radio failure?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where can you find the format of the distress (mayday) radio call?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Write down the pattern of a Mayday call. (You must get this right!)

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

As further support for a Mayday call, when operating in a radar environment in an aircraft that is fitted with a transponder, what code should you squawk?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Write down the pattern of a Pan-pan call.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where would you find the procedures to follow in the event of a radio communications failure?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When are you required to carry an emergency locator transmitter?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7

Answers

What transponder code should you select if you suffer a VHF-COM radio failure?

7600.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where can you find the format of the distress (mayday) radio call?

In the EMERG section of ERSA.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Write down the pattern of a Mayday call. (You must get this right!)

**Mayday mayday mayday [aircraft callsign] [position and time] [heading] [airspeed] [altitude] [aircraft type] [nature of distress] [captain's intentions] [any other information that may facilitate the rescue].**

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

As further support for a Mayday call, when operating in a radar environment in an aircraft that is fitted with a transponder, what code should you squawk?

7700.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Write down the pattern of a Pan-pan call.

**Pan-pan pan-pan pan-pan [callsign of a specific station or 'all stations'] [aircraft callsign] [request for bearing, course or position, if required] [position and time] [heading] [airspeed] [altitude] [aircraft type] [available flight time] [nature of emergency] [captain's intentions].**

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where would you find the procedures to follow in the event of a radio communications failure?

ERSA EMERG.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When are you required to carry an emergency locator transmitter?

On all flights for which carriage of life rafts is required, and on such over water flights as may be specified, and through designated remote areas if HF radio is not carried.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 7
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5

Questions

In sensing the orientation of the body in space, the brain assigns the highest priority to information coming from

  1. the eyes

  2. the inner ear

  3. the middle ear

  4. the proprioceptive system

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is the most likely cause of disorientation?

  1. a change in the information coming from the inner ear

  2. a conflict or ambiguity in the information coming from visual, vestibular and postural cues

  3. poor lighting reducing the amount of visual information received

  4. a rapid transition from level flight to a steep climb

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

In the absence of reliable visual information, which of the following states of motion would be most difficult to differentiate?

  1. a steep turn and a rapid deceleration in level flight

  2. a rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a dive

  3. a rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

  4. a rapid deceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

You are making an approach by day into a runway where the terrain slopes up from the threshold of intended landing. The most likely misjudgment during this approach would be

  1. an overestimate of your height above the runway threshold

  2. an underestimate of your height above the runway threshold

  3. an underestimate of your speed during the approach

  4. an overestimate of the length of the runway

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following organs mediates the sense of balance?

  1. eustachian tube

  2. the eardrum

  3. the semicircular canals

  4. the cochlea

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The susceptibility to disorientation is increased if the pilot is suffering from anxiety, stress or mental fatigue

  1. this statement is false

  2. this statement is true

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 5

  1. the eyes

  2. the inner ear

  3. the middle ear

  4. the proprioceptive system

the eyes

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8

Questions

During which period of the day will the average person find it most difficult to stay awake?

  1. midday to 2 pm

  2. 10 pm to 2 am

  3. 3 am to 5 am

  4. 9 am to midday

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is true regarding transmeridian dyschronism [jet lag].

  1. flying east requires the body's rhythms to advance

  2. flying west requires the body's rhythms to advance

  3. flying east requires the body's rhythms to delay

  4. flying north in summer requires the body's rhythms to advance

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following would be most vulnerable to fatigue?

  1. clear thinking

  2. hovering a helicopter

  3. seeing and hearing clearlythe attention span

  4. speaking clearly

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The lapse in performance standards which occurs daily in mid afternoon is known as

  1. the post-meridian depression

  2. the post-prandial dip

  3. the siesta syndrome

  4. the afternoon lapse phase

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following describes the effect of excess stress on the attention span?

  1. the attention span is reduced

  2. the attention span is increased

  3. the attention span is not affected by excess stress

  4. the attention span reduces initially but soon returns to normal

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Chronic fatigue differs from acute fatigue in that

  1. it can usually be relieved by a good night's sleep

  2. it is always the result of overexertion

  3. it is easily treated by sleeping pills

  4. it is usually life-style related and the cause may not be obvious

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is true of acute stress?

  1. it always has a negative effect on performance and should be avoided at all costs

  2. it has no affect on performance

  3. moderate levels of stress can enhance the dynamics of coping with a particular situation

  4. the higher the stress levels, the better the performance becomes

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

A common source of human error is the false hypothesis. Under certain conditions this is more or less likely than at other times. From the following list, select the situation *least likely* to result in a person arriving at a false hypothesis.

  1. when expectancy of an event is high

  2. after a period of intense concentration

  3. during a period of preoccupation with another problem

  4. in the event of an engine failure

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The illustration at left serves to illustrate the perceptual error known as

  1. the Coriolis illusion

  2. the autokinetic illusion

  3. somatogravic illusion

  4. mind set

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 8

  1. midday to 2 pm

  2. 10 pm to 2 am

  3. 3 am to 5 am

  4. 9 am to midday

airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology

Questions

A wind in a terminal area forecast expressed as VRB30G45 would:

  1. Always be associated with closely spaced isobars around a trough

  2. Be improbable, since variable wind directions are only associated with light winds and high pressure systems

  3. Probably be associated with a thunderstorm

  4. Always be associated with closely spaced isobars around a ridge

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

The validity of a METAR is:

  1. 3 hours

  2. 6 hours

  3. 30 hours

  4. Not applicable

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

The wind direction is given in degrees:

  1. Magnetic in both area and aerodrome forecasts

  2. Magnetic in an area forecast, and true in an aerodrome forecast

  3. True in both area and aerodrome forecasts

  4. True in an area forecast, and magnetic in an aerodrome forecast

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

In a METAR for YAAA, the figures quoted immediately before the QNH read 9/8, and at YBBB they read 10/8. This means that, at place YAAA, the dry bulb is 9C and the:

  1. Dew point is 8C and fog is closer to forming at YAAA than YBBB

  2. Wet bulb is 8C and fog is closer to forming at YAAA than YBBB

  3. Dew point is 8C and fog is closer to forming at YBBB than YAAA

  4. Wet bulb is 8C and fog is closer to forming at YBBB than YAAA

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

A TAF includes the following: > INTER 0710/0714 2000 -SHSN This forecasts, between the times indicated:

  1. Showers and snow of expected duration 30 to 60 minutes

  2. Showers of snow of expected duration 30 to 60 minutes

  3. Showers and snow of expected duration less than 30 minutes

  4. Showers of snow of expected duration less than 30 minutes

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

The validity period of an aerodrome forecast is from 0000Z on the 1st to 0600Z on the 2nd. In the forecast this is written:

  1. 0100/0206

  2. 010006

  3. 0100/06

  4. 01000206

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

In a TAF, the term FU VV030 means:

  1. Smoke and a visibility of 3,000 metres

  2. Smoke and a vertical visibility of 3,000 feet

  3. Fumes and a visibility of 3.000 metres

  4. Fumes and a vertical visibility of 3,000 feet

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

Observed intermediate QNH values are rounded:

  1. Down so that the altimeter reading is from a pressure level slightly lower than MSL

  2. Down so that the altimeter reading is from a pressure level slightly higher than MSL

  3. Up so that the altimeter reading is from a pressure level slightly lower than MSL

  4. Up so that the altimeter reading is from a pressure level slightly higher than MSL

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

When cruising below the transition layer (10,000') you can set a local QNH of a station along the route provided it is within:

  1. 10NM of the aircraft

  2. 50NM of the aircraft

  3. 100NM of the aircraft

  4. 200NM of the aircraft

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

A TAF commences and finishes as follows: > TAF YCOM 070635Z 0708/0720 ... Q 1020 1021 1019 1018 The forecast QNH for time 071320 is:

  1. 1020

  2. 1021

  3. 1019

  4. 1018

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Airborne Aviation

airborne-aviation.com.au Meteorology

Answers

A wind in a terminal area forecast expressed as VRB30G45 would:

  1. Always be associated with closely spaced isobars around a trough

  2. Be improbable, since variable wind directions are only associated with light winds and high pressure systems

  3. Probably be associated with a thunderstorm

  4. Always be associated with closely spaced isobars around a ridge

Probably be associated with a thunderstorm
