Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1

Questions

Deflection of the elevators in flight cause the aeroplane to

  1. pitch about its normal axis

  2. pitch about its lateral axis

  3. yaw about its normal axis

  4. pitch about its longitudinal axis

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following correctly associates the control surface, type of motion involved and the axis about which that motion occurs?

  1. rudder, yaw, longitudinal

  2. elevator, pitch, normal

  3. aileron, roll, longitudinal

  4. rudder, pitch, normal

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

The centre of gravity of an aircraft is a point

  1. halfway along the longitudinal axis

  2. in the centre of the wing

  3. at which all three axes intersect

  4. directly above the wheels

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

The best indication of nose attitude is obtained when the pilot

  1. looks to the side and notes the position of the wing tips in relation to the horizon

  2. looks to the front and notes the position of the horizon in the aircraft's windscreen

  3. looks at the instrument panel and notes the aircraft's present height and speed

  4. looks to the right and asks the instructor to point it out

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When the control column is turned to the left during flight

  1. the right aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the right

  2. the left aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the left

  3. the right aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the left

  4. the left aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the right

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When the right rudder pedal is depressed during flight

  1. the rudder moves to the left and the aircraft yaws to the left

  2. the rudder moves to the left and the aircraft yaws to the right

  3. the rudder moves to the right and the aircraft yaws to the left

  4. the rudder moves to the right and the aircraft yaws to the right

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When a back pressure is applied to the control column during straight and level flight

  1. the elevator is deflected up and the aircraft adopts a higher nose attitude

  2. the elevator is deflected up and the aircraft adopts a lower nose attitude

  3. the elevator is deflected down and the aircraft adopts a lower nose attitude

  4. the elevator is deflected down and the aircraft adopts a higher nose attitude

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

If no control input is made by the pilot, which of the following types of aircraft motion will always occur simultaneously?

  1. pitch and yaw

  2. pitch and roll

  3. pitch, yaw and roll

  4. yaw and roll

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Which is the most appropriate recovery action if an aircraft is allowed to enter a spiral dive?

  1. pull back firmly on the control column

  2. apply full rudder against the direction of turn

  3. apply opposite aileron to level the wings

  4. apply aileron in the direction of turn until the wings are level

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

A single-engine aircraft is climbing with high power applied and low airspeed. Which of the following will be true concerning the effectiveness of the flying controls?

  1. the ailerons and rudder will be more effective than the elevator

  2. the ailerons will be less effective than the elevator or rudder

  3. the ailerons will be more effective than the elevator or rudder

  4. the ailerons and elevator will be more effective than the rudder

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1

Answers

Deflection of the elevators in flight cause the aeroplane to

  1. pitch about its normal axis

  2. pitch about its lateral axis

  3. yaw about its normal axis

  4. pitch about its longitudinal axis

pitch about its lateral axis

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following correctly associates the control surface, type of motion involved and the axis about which that motion occurs?

  1. rudder, yaw, longitudinal

  2. elevator, pitch, normal

  3. aileron, roll, longitudinal

  4. rudder, pitch, normal

aileron, roll, longitudinal

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

The centre of gravity of an aircraft is a point

  1. halfway along the longitudinal axis

  2. in the centre of the wing

  3. at which all three axes intersect

  4. directly above the wheels

at which all three axes intersect

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

The best indication of nose attitude is obtained when the pilot

  1. looks to the side and notes the position of the wing tips in relation to the horizon

  2. looks to the front and notes the position of the horizon in the aircraft's windscreen

  3. looks at the instrument panel and notes the aircraft's present height and speed

  4. looks to the right and asks the instructor to point it out

looks to the front and notes the position of the horizon in the aircraft's windscreen

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When the control column is turned to the left during flight

  1. the right aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the right

  2. the left aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the left

  3. the right aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the left

  4. the left aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the right

the left aileron is raised and the aircraft rolls to the left

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When the right rudder pedal is depressed during flight

  1. the rudder moves to the left and the aircraft yaws to the left

  2. the rudder moves to the left and the aircraft yaws to the right

  3. the rudder moves to the right and the aircraft yaws to the left

  4. the rudder moves to the right and the aircraft yaws to the right

the rudder moves to the right and the aircraft yaws to the right

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

When a back pressure is applied to the control column during straight and level flight

  1. the elevator is deflected up and the aircraft adopts a higher nose attitude

  2. the elevator is deflected up and the aircraft adopts a lower nose attitude

  3. the elevator is deflected down and the aircraft adopts a lower nose attitude

  4. the elevator is deflected down and the aircraft adopts a higher nose attitude

the elevator is deflected up and the aircraft adopts a higher nose attitude

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

If no control input is made by the pilot, which of the following types of aircraft motion will always occur simultaneously?

  1. pitch and yaw

  2. pitch and roll

  3. pitch, yaw and roll

  4. yaw and roll

yaw and roll

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Which is the most appropriate recovery action if an aircraft is allowed to enter a spiral dive?

  1. pull back firmly on the control column

  2. apply full rudder against the direction of turn

  3. apply opposite aileron to level the wings

  4. apply aileron in the direction of turn until the wings are level

apply opposite aileron to level the wings

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

A single-engine aircraft is climbing with high power applied and low airspeed. Which of the following will be true concerning the effectiveness of the flying controls?

  1. the ailerons and rudder will be more effective than the elevator

  2. the ailerons will be less effective than the elevator or rudder

  3. the ailerons will be more effective than the elevator or rudder

  4. the ailerons and elevator will be more effective than the rudder

the ailerons will be less effective than the elevator or rudder

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A1
RPL,Bob Tait

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2

Answers

Write out and say the phonetic alphabet that is used to transmit letters.

Refer to table 2-1, page 23.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would transmit the number 59?

Five nine (pronounced FIFE NINer).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you transmit the number 8,500?

Eight thousand five hundred (pronounced AIT TOU-SAND FIFE HUN-dred).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What word or phrase would you use to express "yes" or "that is correct"?

Affirm.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What word or phrase means "no"?

Negative.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you transmit the callsign of an aircraft registered VH-RQT?

Romeo Quebec Tango (pronounced ROW-me-oh Keh-BECK TANG-go).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you transmit the callsign of VH-UVP?

Uniform Victor Papa (pronounced YOU-nee-form VIK-tah Pah-PAH).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

How would you transmit the hours and minutes of 0835 UTC?

Zero eight three five (pronounced ZE-RO AIT TREE FIFE).

UTC.

0840 UTC.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

UTC is ... hours (ahead of/behind) Western Standard Time.

8, behind

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

2000 WST is ... UTC.

1200 UTC.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

0030 UTC is ... EST.

1030 EST.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

0800 EST ... UTC.

2200 UTC the previous day.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

0700 WST is ... UTC.

2300 UTC the previous day.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 2
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4

Questions

An item of passenger briefing which is mandatory before take-off is:

  1. The location of the emergency exits

  2. The location of the fire extinguishers

  3. The pilot actions in the event of an engine failure after take-off

  4. The position of the body in the event of an emergency landing

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A PAN-PAN call should be made if the pilot:

  1. Is unable to comply with an ATC instruction

  2. Has an intermittent transponder

  3. Is lost and experiencing difficulty in navigation

  4. Is unable to raise flap after take-off at a CTAF aerodrome

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You must not undertake a mercy flight if:

  1. You are likely to operate in marginal VMC

  2. You cannot comply with relevant regulations

  3. Your aircraft is not radio-equipped

  4. There is an alternative means of achieving the same relief

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A prohibited area is defined as airspace in which flight by civil aircraft:

  1. Is not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

  2. Is not permitted during daylight hours

  3. Is not permitted without prior approval

  4. Is not permitted between the hours of 10pm and 6 am

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

For all flights, the pilot in command of an aircraft shall test the flight controls to the full limit of their travel:

  1. Immediately before engine start

  2. Immediately before starting to taxi

  3. Immediately before take-off

  4. At the completion of the flight

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A steady red light signal directed at an aircraft in flight signifies to the pilot that the:

  1. Aerodrome is unsafe for landing

  2. Aircraft should climb above circuit height & orbit the aerodrome

  3. Aircrafts undercarriage is not fully down Go round

  4. Aircraft should give way to other aircraft & continue circling

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Select the option below which could best be described as an organisational threat

  1. A flight into a high density traffic area

  2. An air traffic controller whose speech is too fast to understand easily

  3. Pilot proficiency degraded by lack of recent experience

  4. Provision of an instrument approach chart that is out of date

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A quantity of fuel likely to create a fire hazard has been spilled within 15 m of an aircraft. Fuelling of the aircraft may continue only after:

  1. Two fire extinguishers have been positioned within 15m of the aircraft

  2. Ground fuelling equipment is removed to more than 15m of the aircraft

  3. The spilled fuel is removed

  4. All passengers have left the aircraft

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A requirement for dropping operations is that:

  1. A dispatcher must be provided with a seat

  2. Continuous sight of ground or water is maintained

  3. All persons on board remain seated

  4. There is no risk of articles falling outside the drop site

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following restrictions applies to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by pilots:

  1. It may not be consumed at any time

  2. It may be consumed immediately prior to commencement of duty provided the capacity to act is not impaired

  3. It may be consumed up to, but not within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

  4. It may be consumed in the 12 hours immediately preceding departure

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The ARFOR indicates that there will be BROKEN stratus with the cloud top at 3000 ft AMSL along your planned route OCTA. You plan VFR using radio navigation aids along this route. Your planned track is 067 degrees (M). To maintain VMC and conform to the Table of Cruising Levels which of the following altitudes is the lowest that you can plan:

  1. A030

  2. A035

  3. A040

  4. A050

  5. A055

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At a non-controlled aerodrome in Class G airspace, the latest position at which an aircraft is permitted to join the circuit is the:

  1. Upwind leg

  2. Crosswind leg

  3. Downwind leg

  4. Base leg

  5. Final leg

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You and three friends plan a shooting trip in a hired aircraft that you will pilot as a private flight. Which of the following conditions apply to the carriage of firearms:

  1. Unloaded firearms may be carried if correctly packaged

  2. Unloaded firearms may be carried in a luggage locker

  3. Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

  4. Firearms may be carried provided they are licensed and you obtain permission from the aircraft owner or operator

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When overflying a VOR station one cockpit indication you should expect is that:

  1. A reciprocal track will be displayed in the course window

  2. The flag will change from TO to FROM

  3. The TO flag will remain on until you set the reciprocal track

  4. The station ident will change to a continuous audio signal

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

This question relates to a VFR flight by day proceeding more than 50 nm from the departure aerodrome. The maximum permitted crosswind component in an aeroplanes flight manual is 15 kts. Which of the following weather conditions forecast for the destination at the ETA would necessitate the provision of an alternate:

  1. 15 kts steady crosswind

  2. Visibility of 8 km

  3. SCT cloud with a 1400 ft ceiling

  4. 30% probability of visibility restricted to 7 km

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer Figure 5 (page 8, Work Booklet). Given the following details: * Runway = 08/26 * Take-off distance available = 1200 metres * Surface = short wet grass * Slope = level * Pressure height = 4000 ft * Wind = 080/05 kts * Temperature = +28 Degrees C The heaviest take-off weight permitted under the conditions given is closest to:

  1. 880 kg

  2. 1030 kg

  3. 1055 kg

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During summer in Australia, in what direction from the departure aerodrome will the end of daylight (in LMT) be earlier:

  1. West

  2. North

  3. South

  4. East

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (BOURKE) WAC 3356 (page 30, Work Booklet). You are on a flight from ST GEORGE (YSGE) (2803S 14836E) to WALGETT (YWLG) (3002S 14807E). You departed YSGE at 0308UTC. At 0324UTC you crossed the railway line (approximately 35nm SE YSGE) and fixed your position between Bonathorne railway station and NOONDOO township. Using track error lines you estimate that the track error from YSGE to the 0324UTC position is 8 degrees right. You now alter HDG 16 degrees left to intercept the planned TR. At what time should the aircraft intercept the (planned) YSGE YWLG track:

  1. 0332 UTC

  2. 0340 UTC

  3. 0356 UTC

  4. 0337 UTC

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Wind information given in aerodrome forecasts indicates the direction:

  1. From which the wind is blowing in degrees magnetic

  2. To which the wind is blowing in degrees magnetic

  3. From which the wind is blowing in degrees true

  4. To which the wind is blowing in degrees true

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (TOWNSVILLE) WAC 3219 (page 27, Work Booklet). At 0120UTC you depart SPRING CREEK (1838S 14433E) to track direct to REID RIVER (1916S 14650E). At 0135UTC your position is on track north of Lucky Downs homestead (approximately 30nm from SPRING CREEK). From this position a HDG of 110(M) is maintained until you obtain a pinpoint at 0150UTC over Blue Range homestead (Approximately 60nm from SPRING CREEK). The HDG (M) required to track direct to REID RIVER from this position is closest to:

  1. 103(M)

  2. 106 M)

  3. 121(M)

  4. 099(M)

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4

  1. 1.0%

  2. 3.2%

  3. 4.5%

  4. 6.0%

MERIMBULA (YMER) TAF YMER 092300Z 0012 29015KT 8000 RASH SCT010 SCT040 FM04 26025KT 9999 BKN035 Depart YSWG 0000 YSCB Arrive YMER 0200 The Forecast wind velocity for arrival in the circuit area YMER is:

  1. 280 Deg (T), 10 kts

  2. 280 Deg (M), 25 kts

  3. 260 Deg (T), 25 kts

  4. 290 Deg (M), 15 kts

  5. 290 Deg (T), 15 kts

  1. 25 Litres

  2. 13 Litres

  3. 19 Litres

  4. 22 Litres

  1. Maximum structural cruising speed

  2. Manoeuvring speed

  3. Turbulence penetration speed

  4. Maximum flap lowering speed

  1. As overcast cloud over the whole area

  2. As individual cells

  3. Occasionally up to 28000 feet

  4. As well separated cells

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (BOURKE) WAC 3356 (page 30, Work Booklet). You plan to fly from ST GEORGE (YSGE) (2803S 14836E) to WALGETT (YWLG) (3002S 14807E). Your track YSGE to YWLG is 181 Degrees (M). The ARFOR indicates that there will be more that 4 oktas cloud with a base of 10,000 ft along the route. The highest altitude at which you may cruise VFR in accordance with the Table of Cruising Levels is:

  1. A075

  2. A095

  3. A085

  4. A080

  5. A090

PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following forecast conditions for a destination aerodrome will warrant the provision of an alternate for a VFR Day flight in an aeroplane:

  1. Cloud exceeding 4 Oktas at 2000 ft AMSL

  2. Visibility 9999

  3. TAF is endorsed with a 30% probability of dust which restricts visibility to 9 km

  4. Cross-wind component exceed the maximum allowed by the aeroplanes flight manual

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

If uncertain of position how can you track to an aerodrome with a VOR? Tune and indemnify the station; turn OBS till the:

  1. CDI is centred and flag shows FROM. Keep CDI centred by flying towards the needle if it wanders off centre

  2. CDI is centred and flag shows TO. Keep CDI centred by flying towards the needle if it wanders off centre

  3. Course window indicates 000 and flag shows TO. Maintain 000 in the course window and the CDI central

  4. Course window indicates 000. Turn the aircraft till the CDI centred and fly towards the needle if it wanders off centre

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. 5 to 8 OKTAS

  2. 3 to 4 OKTAS

  3. 4 to 7 OKTAS

  4. 2 to 5 OKTAS

  5. 5 to 7 OKTAS

Given: * Aircraft basic index units = -190 * Aircraft basic empty weight = 1018 kg * Row 1 pilot and passenger = 200 kg * Row 2 passenger, forward facing = 50 kg * Baggage rear compartment = 40 kg * Fuel = Full The maximum weight of baggage, in Kg that may be carried in the nose compartment at take-off is closest to:

  1. 10 kg

  2. 35 kg

  3. 45 kg

  4. 20 kg

If other conditions remain the same, what effect will an increase in surface air temperature have on take-off distance required:

  1. Distance required increases

  2. Distance required is unchanged

  3. Distance required is unchanged but take-off roll is increased

  4. Distance required decreases

PPL,Curtis Aviation

The following details pertain to a direct flight from BATHURST (YBTH) (3325S 14939E) to DUBBO (YSDU) (3213S 14834E): ATD YBTH at 2305UTC, 2317UTC over HILL END town (approximately 25 nm from YBTH), constant HDG maintained since departure YBTH.   1. 10 degrees Left

  2. 16 degrees Left

  3. 16 degrees Right

  4. 10 degrees Left

  1. Scalloping

  2. Bending

  3. Line-of-sight range

  4. Thunderstorm interference

  3. 130 Degrees and 120 kt

Express in UTC - Six (6) PM Western Standard:

  2. 0800 UTC

The following code refers to a layer of cloud as forecast in a TAF FEW030. What is the amount of cloud in the layer:

  1. 2 to 3 OKTAS

  2. 0 to 2 OKTAS

  3. 1 to 2 OKTAS

  4. 5 to 7 OKTAS

  5. 3 to 4 OKTAS

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4

  2. 252 kg

  3. Less lift

  4. More drag

The condition most likely to produce advection fog is:

  1. A cold air mass passing another cold surface

  2. A cold air mass passing over a relatively warm surface

  3. A warm air mass passing over another warm surface

  4. A warm air mass passing over a relatively cold surface

  3. Approach angle flattens

  4. Hazardous, because it can lock the aerodynamic controls

  4. Initially increase the lift by increasing the camber

  4. May seriously affect performance and should always be removed before flight

  2. Lift will decrease and drag will increase

  3. Lift and drag will both increase

  4. Lift and drag will both decrease

The most significant effect on an aeroplanes flight characteristics of NOT clearing frost from the wings prior to flight is that:

  1. There is a marked deterioration in acceleration during the take-off run

  2. The stalling angle will increase

  3. The indicated stalling speed will increase

  4. Both the indicated stalling speed and stalling angle will increase

  1. On the horizon and maintaining a constant position in your windscreen

  2. Below the horizon and moving closer to the centre of your windscreen

  3. On the horizon and moving away from the centre of your windscreen

  4. On the horizon

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The most effective way to scan the sky for other aircraft during level flight is to:

  1. Move the head in a continuous arc from side to side

  2. Keep the head still & move the eyes continuously from side to side

  3. Do not look anywhere but straight ahead unless you detect movement

  4. Move the head about 20deg to 30deg at a time, pausing after each movement to allow the peripheral vision to detect any movement

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the absence of reliable visual information, which of the following states of motion would be most difficult to differentiate:

  1. A steep turn and a rapid deceleration in level flight

  2. A rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a dive

  3. A rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

  4. A rapid deceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

  1. Headache and fatigue

  2. A feeling of euphoria

  3. Discomfort in breathing

  4. Impairment of vision and mental confusion

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Hypoxia may be caused by:

  1. Flying with a head cold

  2. Flying at an altitude where the partial pressure of oxygen is too low

  3. Breathing too quickly and/or too deeply for the requirements of the body

  4. Flying after a period of underwater diving

  4. Errors, fight crew human resources and undesired aircraft states

  1. Thunderstorms forecast on the TAF

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4

Answers

An item of passenger briefing which is mandatory before take-off is:

  1. The location of the emergency exits

  2. The location of the fire extinguishers

  3. The pilot actions in the event of an engine failure after take-off

  4. The position of the body in the event of an emergency landing

The location of the emergency exits

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A PAN-PAN call should be made if the pilot:

  1. Is unable to comply with an ATC instruction

  2. Has an intermittent transponder

  3. Is lost and experiencing difficulty in navigation

  4. Is unable to raise flap after take-off at a CTAF aerodrome

Is lost and experiencing difficulty in navigation

PPL,Curtis Aviation

You must not undertake a mercy flight if:

  1. You are likely to operate in marginal VMC

  2. You cannot comply with relevant regulations

  3. Your aircraft is not radio-equipped

  4. There is an alternative means of achieving the same relief

There is an alternative means of achieving the same relief

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. Is not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

  2. Is not permitted during daylight hours

  3. Is not permitted without prior approval

  4. Is not permitted between the hours of 10pm and 6 am

Is not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

For all flights, the pilot in command of an aircraft shall test the flight controls to the full limit of their travel:

  1. Immediately before engine start

  2. Immediately before starting to taxi

  3. Immediately before take-off

  4. At the completion of the flight

Immediately before take-off

PPL,Curtis Aviation

A steady red light signal directed at an aircraft in flight signifies to the pilot that the:

  1. Aerodrome is unsafe for landing

  2. Aircraft should climb above circuit height & orbit the aerodrome

  3. Aircrafts undercarriage is not fully down Go round

  4. Aircraft should give way to other aircraft & continue circling

Aircraft should give way to other aircraft & continue circling

  1. A flight into a high density traffic area

Provision of an instrument approach chart that is out of date

PPL,Curtis Aviation

A quantity of fuel likely to create a fire hazard has been spilled within 15 m of an aircraft. Fuelling of the aircraft may continue only after:

  1. Two fire extinguishers have been positioned within 15m of the aircraft

  2. Ground fuelling equipment is removed to more than 15m of the aircraft

  3. The spilled fuel is removed

  4. All passengers have left the aircraft

The spilled fuel is removed

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. A dispatcher must be provided with a seat

  2. Continuous sight of ground or water is maintained

  3. All persons on board remain seated

  4. There is no risk of articles falling outside the drop site

Continuous sight of ground or water is maintained

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following restrictions applies to the consumption of alcoholic liquor by pilots:

  1. It may not be consumed at any time

  2. It may be consumed immediately prior to commencement of duty provided the capacity to act is not impaired

  3. It may be consumed up to, but not within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

  4. It may be consumed in the 12 hours immediately preceding departure

It may be consumed up to, but not within, the 8 hours immediately preceding departure

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. A030

  2. A035

  3. A040

  4. A050

  5. A055

A055

PPL,Curtis Aviation

At a non-controlled aerodrome in Class G airspace, the latest position at which an aircraft is permitted to join the circuit is the:

  1. Upwind leg

  2. Crosswind leg

  3. Downwind leg

  4. Base leg

  5. Final leg

Downwind leg

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You and three friends plan a shooting trip in a hired aircraft that you will pilot as a private flight. Which of the following conditions apply to the carriage of firearms:

  1. Unloaded firearms may be carried if correctly packaged

  2. Unloaded firearms may be carried in a luggage locker

  3. Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

  4. Firearms may be carried provided they are licensed and you obtain permission from the aircraft owner or operator

Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When overflying a VOR station one cockpit indication you should expect is that:

  1. A reciprocal track will be displayed in the course window

  2. The flag will change from TO to FROM

  3. The TO flag will remain on until you set the reciprocal track

  4. The station ident will change to a continuous audio signal

The flag will change from TO to FROM

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  2. Visibility of 8 km

  3. SCT cloud with a 1400 ft ceiling

  4. 30% probability of visibility restricted to 7 km

30% probability of visibility restricted to 7 km

PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (BOURKE) WAC 3356 (page 30, Work Booklet). You are on a flight from ST GEORGE (YSGE) (2803S 14836E) to WALGETT (YWLG) (3002S 14807E). You departed YSGE at 0308UTC. At 0324UTC you crossed the railway line (approximately 35nm SE YSGE) and fixed your position between Bonathorne railway station and NOONDOO township. Using track error lines you estimate that the track error from YSGE to the 0324UTC position is 8 degrees right. You now alter HDG 16 degrees left to intercept the planned TR. At what time should the aircraft intercept the (planned) YSGE YWLG track:

  1. 0332 UTC

  2. 0340 UTC

  3. 0356 UTC

  4. 0337 UTC

0340 UTC

  2. To which the wind is blowing in degrees magnetic

  3. From which the wind is blowing in degrees true

  4. To which the wind is blowing in degrees true

From which the wind is blowing in degrees true

  3. 121(M)

099(M)

6.0%

Turbulence penetration speed

PPL,Curtis Aviation

If uncertain of position how can you track to an aerodrome with a VOR? Tune and indemnify the station; turn OBS till the:

  1. CDI is centred and flag shows FROM. Keep CDI centred by flying towards the needle if it wanders off centre

  2. CDI is centred and flag shows TO. Keep CDI centred by flying towards the needle if it wanders off centre

  3. Course window indicates 000 and flag shows TO. Maintain 000 in the course window and the CDI central

  4. Course window indicates 000. Turn the aircraft till the CDI centred and fly towards the needle if it wanders off centre

CDI is centred and flag shows TO. Keep CDI centred by flying towards the needle if it wanders off centre

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The following code refers to a layer of cloud as forecast in a TAF. BKN030 What is the amount of cloud in the layer:

  1. 5 to 8 OKTAS

  2. 3 to 4 OKTAS

  3. 4 to 7 OKTAS

  4. 2 to 5 OKTAS

  5. 5 to 7 OKTAS

5 to 7 OKTAS

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  2. 19 03S 146 23E

  3. 19 30S 146 52E

19 03S 146 23E

  3. 45 kg

10 kg

  3. Distance required is unchanged but take-off roll is increased

  4. Distance required decreases

Distance required increases

  4. Elevator effectiveness is reduced

Elevator effectiveness is reduced

An aerofoil is said to be at its stalling angle if any increase or decrease in angle of attack results in:

  1. Less lift and less drag

  2. A lower L/D ratio

  3. Less lift

  4. More drag

Less lift

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The condition most likely to produce advection fog is:

  1. A cold air mass passing another cold surface

  2. A cold air mass passing over a relatively warm surface

  3. A warm air mass passing over another warm surface

  4. A warm air mass passing over a relatively cold surface

A warm air mass passing over a relatively cold surface

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aircraft is on a glide approach at 65 kts. The pilot lowers full flap and maintains 65 kts. What is the effect on approach angle:

  1. There is no effect on approach angle

  2. Approach angle steepens

  3. Approach angle flattens

Approach angle steepens

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

After take-off, what will be the effect on airspeed if you encounter wind shear where the headwind component increases:

  1. An increase in airspeed and then it returns to normal

  2. An increase in airspeed and then it remains higher

  3. A loss of airspeed and then it returns to normal

  4. No effect on airspeed

An increase in airspeed and then it returns to normal

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. Maximum still air range

  2. Minimum rate of descent

  3. Best endurance

  4. Maximum rate of climb

Maximum still air range

PPL,Curtis Aviation

If the indicated airspeed of an aeroplane is progressively reduced whilst maintaining level flight, induced drag will:

  1. Decrease progressively

  2. Decrease then increase

  3. Increase progressively

  4. Increase then decrease

Increase progressively

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The maximum rate of climb speed will normally be achieved at:

  1. The same as the speed giving the maximum angle of climb

  2. Greater than the speed giving maximum angle of climb

  3. Greater than that recommended for normal climb

  4. Less that the speed giving maximum angle of climb

Greater than the speed giving maximum angle of climb

A reduction in gross weight

Engine overheating

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aircraft piston engine will experience severe detonation when operated with:

  1. A mixture of AVGAS and Aviation Turbine fuel

  2. A Low power setting and carburettor heat full on

  3. An over rich mixture during climb

  4. Maximum continuous power in level flight

A mixture of AVGAS and Aviation Turbine fuel

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The effect of hoar frost forming on the wings of an aeroplane is:

  1. Hazardous, because it can substantially increase stalling speed

  2. Negligible, because it does not alter the aerodynamic shape

  3. Negligible, because hoar frost weighs very little

  4. Hazardous, because it can lock the aerodynamic controls

Hazardous, because it can substantially increase stalling speed

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. High

  2. Col

  3. Trough

  4. Low

Low

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In comparison to a stall in straight and level flight, how will a sudden pull out from a dive affect the stall IAS and the stalling angle:

  1. Stall IAS will increase; stalling angle will be less

  2. Stall IAS and stalling angle will both increase

  3. Stall IAS will increase; stalling angle will remain constant

  4. Stall IAS will remain constant; stalling angle will be less

Stall IAS will increase; stalling angle will remain constant

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A thin coating of clear ice on the leading edge of an aerofoil of an aircraft in flight will:

  1. Initially increase the efficiency of the aerofoil by reducing drag

  2. Has no appreciable effect as the decrease in lift is balanced by a corresponding decrease in drag

  3. Decrease lift and increase drag by changing the aerofoil characteristics

  4. Initially increase the lift by increasing the camber

Decrease lift and increase drag by changing the aerofoil characteristics

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is a likely reason for yaw to the right during the take-off roll in a single-engine aeroplane fitted with an engine, which rotates in a clockwise direction when viewed from the cockpit:

  1. Torque effect

  2. A crosswind from the right

  3. Slipstream effect

  4. A crosswind from the left

A crosswind from the right

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  2. Ridge

Trough

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Hoar frost, which has formed on an aircraft, parked in the open overnight:

  1. Does not affect performance

  2. Will not affect performance sufficiently to cause any hazard

  3. Will not affect performance, but may lock the controls solid

  4. May seriously affect performance and should always be removed before flight

May seriously affect performance and should always be removed before flight

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

How will an increase in altitude affect the stall characteristics of an aeroplane:

  1. The stalling angle will increase

  2. The stall IAS will increase

  3. The stall IAS will remain the same

  4. The stall angle will decrease

The stall IAS will remain the same

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

How will lift and darg vary if the angle of attach of an aerofoil is increased from 4 degrees up to the stalling angle:

  1. Lift will increase and drag will decrease

  2. Lift will decrease and drag will increase

  3. Lift and drag will both increase

  4. Lift and drag will both decrease

Lift and drag will both increase

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The most significant effect on an aeroplanes flight characteristics of NOT clearing frost from the wings prior to flight is that:

  1. There is a marked deterioration in acceleration during the take-off run

  2. The stalling angle will increase

  3. The indicated stalling speed will increase

  4. Both the indicated stalling speed and stalling angle will increase

The indicated stalling speed will increase

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A characteristics of Rime Ice, which may be hazardous to aircraft, is that it:

  1. Is likely to lock the control surfaces

  2. May block the pitot tube

  3. Is the most difficult type of ice to remove

  4. Spreads back over most of the aerofoil section

May block the pitot tube

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Unauthorised penetration of controlled airspace is an example of an undesired

  1. Ground navigation state

  2. Aircraft handling state

  3. Air navigation state

  4. Navigation configuration state

Aircraft handling state

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aeroplane takes off in calm conditions and climbs through a wind shear where it encounters a strong tail wind. What initial effect will this change in W/V have on IAS and flight path:

  1. IAS will decrease; flight path will be shallower

  2. IAS will decrease; flight path will be steeper

  3. IAS will increase; flight path will be shallower

  4. IAS will increase; flight path will be steeper

IAS will decrease; flight path will be shallower

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Flying conditions above a layer of small cumulus clouds are likely to be:

  1. Bumpy

  2. Smooth but strong updraughts

  3. Smooth

  4. Very turbulent

Smooth

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot is landing at a coastal aerodrome orientated east west, with the sea to the south, on a hot summer afternoon. What is the most likely wind direction at the aerodrome:

  1. Northerly

  2. Light and Variable

  3. Southerly

  4. Westerly

Southerly

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which hazard is normally associated with mountain waves:

  1. Turbulence

  2. Dust storms

  3. Icing

  4. Hail

Turbulence

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following indications would positively confirm that an aeroplane is established in a spin and is not in a spiral dive:

  1. Nose attitude

  2. High rate of turn

  3. Increasing airspeed

  4. Low airspeed

Low airspeed

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The colour of 100LL aviation gasoline is:

  1. Green

  2. Pale Yellow

  3. Red

  4. Blue

Blue

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The symptoms of dehydration include which of the following:

  1. Profuse sweating

  2. Drying of nasal passages and a prickly sensation in the eyes

  3. Runny eyes and nose

  4. Stomach cramps and a high temperature

Drying of nasal passages and a prickly sensation in the eyes

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following would be an appropriate remedy for a person who is suffering the effects of hyperventilation:

  1. Hold the breath for about 40 seconds

  2. Breathe into a paper bag

  3. Increase the rate and depth of breathing

  4. Use a nasal decongestant

Breathe into a paper bag

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Deterioration of hearing caused by exposure to loud noise usually occurs first:

  1. In the high frequency range, above normal speech

  2. In the frequency range of normal speech, 300 to 5000 Hz

  3. In the frequency range below normal speech

  4. Across the whole range of audible frequencies

In the high frequency range, above normal speech

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In level flight, a collision risk exists if a converging aircraft viewed from the cockpit appears to be:

  1. On the horizon and maintaining a constant position in your windscreen

  2. Below the horizon and moving closer to the centre of your windscreen

  3. On the horizon and moving away from the centre of your windscreen

  4. On the horizon

On the horizon and maintaining a constant position in your windscreen

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The most effective way to scan the sky for other aircraft during level flight is to:

  1. Move the head in a continuous arc from side to side

  2. Keep the head still & move the eyes continuously from side to side

  3. Do not look anywhere but straight ahead unless you detect movement

  4. Move the head about 20deg to 30deg at a time, pausing after each movement to allow the peripheral vision to detect any movement

Move the head about 20deg to 30deg at a time, pausing after each movement to allow the peripheral vision to detect any movement

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the absence of reliable visual information, which of the following states of motion would be most difficult to differentiate:

  1. A steep turn and a rapid deceleration in level flight

  2. A rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a dive

  3. A rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

  4. A rapid deceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

A rapid acceleration in level flight and a transition from level flight to a climb

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is NOT a symptom of carbon monoxide poisoning:

  1. Headache and fatigue

  2. A feeling of euphoria

  3. Discomfort in breathing

  4. Impairment of vision and mental confusion

A feeling of euphoria

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Hypoxia may be caused by:

  1. Flying with a head cold

  2. Flying at an altitude where the partial pressure of oxygen is too low

  3. Breathing too quickly and/or too deeply for the requirements of the body

  4. Flying after a period of underwater diving

Flying at an altitude where the partial pressure of oxygen is too low

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

For the flight crew, the three basic components in the TEM model are

  1. Threats, errors and undesired aircraft state

  2. Threats, errors, and anticipated aircraft states

  3. Threats, flight crew human resources and aircraft states

  4. Errors, fight crew human resources and undesired aircraft states

Threats, errors and undesired aircraft state

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An example of an unexpected threat is

  1. Thunderstorms forecast on the TAF

  2. Engine failure in flight

  3. Becoming lost in flight

  4. Being diverted in flight by ATC

Engine failure in flight

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 4
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6

Questions

An aerofoil is said to be at its stalling angle if any increase or decrease in angle of attack

  1. produces less lift and less drag

  2. produces a lower lift/drag ratio

  3. produces less lift

  4. produces more drag

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If angle of attack is increased from zero to beyond the stalling angle at constant indicated air speed, the magnitude of the force of drag

  1. increases then decreases

  2. decreases continuously

  3. decreases then increases

  4. increases continuously

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Any increase in the angle of attack of an aerofoil up to the stalling angle, at constant indicated air speed causes

  1. lift to increase and drag to increase

  2. lift to increase and drag to decrease

  3. lift to decrease and drag to increase

  4. lift to decrease and drag to decrease

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

A pilot must maintain a back pressure on the control column during a level balanced turn. This is necessary to

  1. increase the angle of attack

  2. create extra drag to slow the aircraft down during the turn

  3. allow the elevators to help turn the aircraft in the desired direction

  4. improve the visibility in the direction of the turn

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If an aircraft is slipping during a level turn, a remedy would be

  1. apply more rudder in the direction of turn

  2. apply less rudder in the direction of turn

  3. apply more bank in the direction of turn

  4. apply greater back pressure on control column

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would be the best definition of the stalling speed?

  1. the speed which requires the lowest angle of attack in level flight

  2. the speed which requires the stalling angle to produce the necessary lift

  3. the speed at which the aircraft should become airborne during take-off

  4. the speed which produces the best angle of climb after take-off

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would decrease the IAS at which the stall occurred?

  1. an increase in angle of bank during a turn

  2. an increase in flap extension during level flight

  3. a decrease in engine power

  4. a strong headwind

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If the aircraft suffers a wing-drop at the point of stall due to turbulent conditions, the correct control input to safely recover would be to

  1. maintain strong back pressure and apply full opposite aileron

  2. maintain strong back pressure and apply opposite rudder

  3. relax the back pressure and apply full opposite aileron

  4. relax the back pressure and apply opposite rudder

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

You are about to take off from a runway immediately after a heavy jet has taken off from the same runway. Which of the following actions would give the best change of avoiding its wake turbulence?

  1. taking off beyond its lift-point, using a shallower angle of climb and maintaining runway heading

  2. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and turning to remain down wind of its flight path

  3. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and maintaining runway heading

  4. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and turning to remain up wind of its flight path

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Compared to nil wind conditions, which of the following effects will be noticed when climbing into a headwind?

  1. both the rate and angle of climb will increase

  2. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will decrease

  3. both the rate and angle of climb will decrease

  4. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will remain unaltered

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Wingtip vortices in level flight will be strongest when

  1. weight is increased and speed is increased

  2. weight is increased and speed is decreased

  3. weight is decreased and speed is decreased

  4. weight is decreased and speed is increased

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

You are about to take off from a runway immediately after a heavy jet aircraft has taken off from the same runway. Which of the following is the most dangerous hazard that could affect your take-off?

  1. difficulty in directional control caused by the blast of the jet engine exhaust

  2. turbulence after lift-off caused by the wing-tip vortices of the larger aircraft

  3. difficulty in directional control during the take-off run caused by the wing-tip vortices of the jet

  4. reduction in engine power because of the heated air behind the departing jet

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

As the angle of bank in a level turn is increased, the load factor

  1. increases and the stalling speed decreases

  2. increases and the stalling speed increases

  3. decreases and the stalling speed decreases

  4. decreases and the stalling speed increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

During a 60deg bank level turn, the load factor will be

  1. the same as in level flight

  2. twice that in level flight

  3. 40% greater than in level flight

  4. 40% less than in level flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

During a 60deg level turn, the stalling speed will be

  1. the same as in level flight

  2. twice that in level flight

  3. 40% greater than in level flight

  4. 40% less than in level flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

When turning at low level on a very windy day a pilot may notice

  1. an illusion of slipping or skidding when turning cross wind

  2. an increased rate of turn when turning upwind

  3. difficulty balancing the turn

  4. a tendency to overbank

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

One result of the application of abrupt back pressure on the control column during a dive would be

  1. a decrease in the angle of attack and less lift

  2. a decrease in the angle of attack and more lift

  3. an increase in the angle of attack and possibly a stall

  4. an decrease in the angle of attack and possibly a stall

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Wake turbulence would be most severe behind

  1. a heavy aircraft flying slowly

  2. a light aircraft flying slowly

  3. a heavy aircraft flying fast

  4. a light aircraft flying fast

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6

Answers

An aerofoil is said to be at its stalling angle if any increase or decrease in angle of attack

  1. produces less lift and less drag

  2. produces a lower lift/drag ratio

  3. produces less lift

  4. produces more drag

produces less lift

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If angle of attack is increased from zero to beyond the stalling angle at constant indicated air speed, the magnitude of the force of drag

  1. increases then decreases

  2. decreases continuously

  3. decreases then increases

  4. increases continuously

increases continuously

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Any increase in the angle of attack of an aerofoil up to the stalling angle, at constant indicated air speed causes

  1. lift to increase and drag to increase

  2. lift to increase and drag to decrease

  3. lift to decrease and drag to increase

  4. lift to decrease and drag to decrease

lift to increase and drag to increase

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

A pilot must maintain a back pressure on the control column during a level balanced turn. This is necessary to

  1. increase the angle of attack

  2. create extra drag to slow the aircraft down during the turn

  3. allow the elevators to help turn the aircraft in the desired direction

  4. improve the visibility in the direction of the turn

increase the angle of attack

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If an aircraft is slipping during a level turn, a remedy would be

  1. apply more rudder in the direction of turn

  2. apply less rudder in the direction of turn

  3. apply more bank in the direction of turn

  4. apply greater back pressure on control column

apply more rudder in the direction of turn

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would be the best definition of the stalling speed?

  1. the speed which requires the lowest angle of attack in level flight

  2. the speed which requires the stalling angle to produce the necessary lift

  3. the speed at which the aircraft should become airborne during take-off

  4. the speed which produces the best angle of climb after take-off

the speed which requires the stalling angle to produce the necessary lift

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Which of the following would decrease the IAS at which the stall occurred?

  1. an increase in angle of bank during a turn

  2. an increase in flap extension during level flight

  3. a decrease in engine power

  4. a strong headwind

an increase in flap extension during level flight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

If the aircraft suffers a wing-drop at the point of stall due to turbulent conditions, the correct control input to safely recover would be to

  1. maintain strong back pressure and apply full opposite aileron

  2. maintain strong back pressure and apply opposite rudder

  3. relax the back pressure and apply full opposite aileron

  4. relax the back pressure and apply opposite rudder

relax the back pressure and apply opposite rudder

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

You are about to take off from a runway immediately after a heavy jet has taken off from the same runway. Which of the following actions would give the best change of avoiding its wake turbulence?

  1. taking off beyond its lift-point, using a shallower angle of climb and maintaining runway heading

  2. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and turning to remain down wind of its flight path

  3. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and maintaining runway heading

  4. taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and turning to remain up wind of its flight path

taking off before its lift-off point, using a steeper angle of climb and turning to remain up wind of its flight path

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Compared to nil wind conditions, which of the following effects will be noticed when climbing into a headwind?

  1. both the rate and angle of climb will increase

  2. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will decrease

  3. both the rate and angle of climb will decrease

  4. angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will remain unaltered

angle of climb will increase and rate of climb will remain unaltered

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Wingtip vortices in level flight will be strongest when

  1. weight is increased and speed is increased

  2. weight is increased and speed is decreased

  3. weight is decreased and speed is decreased

  4. weight is decreased and speed is increased

weight is increased and speed is decreased

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

You are about to take off from a runway immediately after a heavy jet aircraft has taken off from the same runway. Which of the following is the most dangerous hazard that could affect your take-off?

  1. difficulty in directional control caused by the blast of the jet engine exhaust

  2. turbulence after lift-off caused by the wing-tip vortices of the larger aircraft

  3. difficulty in directional control during the take-off run caused by the wing-tip vortices of the jet

  4. reduction in engine power because of the heated air behind the departing jet

turbulence after lift-off caused by the wing-tip vortices of the larger aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

As the angle of bank in a level turn is increased, the load factor

  1. increases and the stalling speed decreases

  2. increases and the stalling speed increases

  3. decreases and the stalling speed decreases

  4. decreases and the stalling speed increases

increases and the stalling speed increases

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

During a 60deg bank level turn, the load factor will be

  1. the same as in level flight

  2. twice that in level flight

  3. 40% greater than in level flight

  4. 40% less than in level flight

twice that in level flight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

During a 60deg level turn, the stalling speed will be

  1. the same as in level flight

  2. twice that in level flight

  3. 40% greater than in level flight

  4. 40% less than in level flight

40% greater than in level flight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

When turning at low level on a very windy day a pilot may notice

  1. an illusion of slipping or skidding when turning cross wind

  2. an increased rate of turn when turning upwind

  3. difficulty balancing the turn

  4. a tendency to overbank

an illusion of slipping or skidding when turning cross wind

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

One result of the application of abrupt back pressure on the control column during a dive would be

  1. a decrease in the angle of attack and less lift

  2. a decrease in the angle of attack and more lift

  3. an increase in the angle of attack and possibly a stall

  4. an decrease in the angle of attack and possibly a stall

an increase in the angle of attack and possibly a stall

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Wake turbulence would be most severe behind

  1. a heavy aircraft flying slowly

  2. a light aircraft flying slowly

  3. a heavy aircraft flying fast

  4. a light aircraft flying fast

a heavy aircraft flying slowly

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision A6
RPL,Bob Tait

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo

Questions

The point about which pitch, roll and yaw occur during flight is the

  1. centre of pressure

  2. wing roots

  3. the mid point between the nose and the tail

  4. the centre of gravity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The location of the centre of gravity of an aeroplane

  1. is a fixed point determined by the manufacturer

  2. depends upon the load distribution within the aircraft

  3. remains constant during any one flight

  4. moves forward if weight is added to the rear

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The induced drag acting on aircraft in straight and level flight is

  1. greatest when speed is low and the aircraft is heavy

  2. greatest when speed is high and the aircraft is heavy

  3. greatest when speed is low and the aircraft is light

  4. greatest when speed is high and the aircraft is light

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following would increase the parasite drag on an aircraft?

  1. raising the flaps

  2. retracting the undercarriage

  3. increasing the IAS

  4. decreasing the IAS

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The least amount of total drag in level flight occurs

  1. at the high end of the speed range at about cruising speed

  2. when the aircraft is flying as slowly as possible

  3. at a speed about equal to the best gliding speed, with the flaps retracted

  4. at a speed about equal to the best gliding speed, with the flaps extended

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The IAS which produces the best gliding performance in still air is

  1. the IAS which produces maximum lift

  2. the IAS which produces the best lift/drag ratio

  3. the IAS which requires least control deflection

  4. the IAS which results from a level nose attitude

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If flap is lowered while maintaining level flight at constant power

  1. the nose attitude will be lower and the resulting IAS will be lower

  2. the nose attitude will be higher and the resulting IAS will be lower

  3. the nose attitude will be lower and the resulting IAS will be higher

  4. the nose attitude will be higher and the resulting IAS will be higher

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If two aircraft identical in every respect except for weight are flying at the same height and IAS,

  1. the heavier aircraft will require a higher nose attitude and more power

  2. the heavier aircraft will require a lower nose attitude and more power

  3. the heavier aircraft will require a lower nose attitude and less power

  4. both aircraft will require the same nose attitude and power

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following factors will increase the angle of climb of an aircraft?

  1. an increase in weight

  2. an increase in headwind

  3. the use of full flap

  4. climbing at the slowest possible speed will full power

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

To achieve the best rate of climb in any given wind the climb should be made

  1. at an IAS lower than that required for best angle with full power applied

  2. at the same IAS as is required for best angle, but with less than full power

  3. at an IAS higher than that required for best angle, but with less than full power

  4. at an IAS higher than that required for best angle with full power applied

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What effect will turning have on climb performance?

  1. the angle of climb will decrease but the rate of climb will increase

  2. both angle and rate of climb will decrease

  3. both angle and rate of climb will increase

  4. the angle of climb will increase but the rate of climb will decrease

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is flying level at 5000 feet at constant power setting in a tail wind. Which of the following is true?

  1. the IAS is less than the TAS

  2. the IAS is higher than the TAS

  3. the IAS is greater than the GS

  4. the TAS is higher than the GS

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is carrying out a level balanced turn at 60 degrees angle of bank. Which of the following would be correct?

  1. lift is equal to weight

  2. lift is twice the weight

  3. lift is three times weight

  4. lift is 1.4 times weight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft stalls at 50 KIAS in level flight at a particular weight and power setting. At the same weight and power setting, in a 60 degree bank level turn the stalling speed would be closest to

  1. 70 KIAS

  2. 50 KIAS

  3. 60 KIAS

  4. 100 KIAS

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The elevator control is abruptly pulled to the fully aft position to induce a stall

  1. the stall will occur at a higher speed than normal

  2. the stall will occur at a lower speed than normal

  3. the stall will occur at the same speed but a higher angle of attack than normal

  4. the stall will occur at the same speed and same angle of attack as normal

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following factors has no effect on the stalling IAS of an aircraft?

  1. weight

  2. load factor

  3. power

  4. height

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Where in relation to a heavy aircraft will wake turbulence be worst?

  1. behind and above the heavy aircraft

  2. behind and below the heavy aircraft

  3. in front of and below the heavy aircraft

  4. in front of anf above the heavy aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following control difficulties is most likely to be associated with an encounter with wake turbulence?

  1. a violent pitch

  2. a violent pitch and yaw

  3. a violent yaw

  4. a violent roll

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The best way to avoid the wake turbulence behind a heavy aircraft which has just landed is to

  1. aim to touch down at point before the touch-down point of the heavy aircraft

  2. aim to touch down at the same point as the heavy aircraft

  3. aim to touch down at a point ahead of the touch-down point of the heavy aircraft

  4. aim to touch down behind the heavy aircraft but on one side of the runway

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following would result in a decrease in the rate of climb?

  1. a reduction in engine power output

  2. an increase in headwind component

  3. a decrease in headwind component

  4. a reduction in gross weight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The purpose of a carburettor is

  1. to mix the correct amount of air with fuel to ensure efficient combustion

  2. to remove any dust particles from the air on its way to the engine

  3. to remove any water from the fuel before it can get to the engine

  4. to cool the air on its way to the engine to prevent detonation

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Under what circumstances can carburettor ice form?

  1. only when the outside air temperature is below zero

  2. only if the aircraft is flying in rain or drizzle

  3. only at low power settings in cold moist air

  4. over a very wide range of temperatures, both inside and outside of cloud

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Under which of the following circumstances would carburettor ice be difficult to detect?

  1. at full power during take-off

  2. during a long climb

  3. during a long descent at low power

  4. during cruise just below a cloud base

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What is the correct method of using carburettor heat during a long power-off glide?

  1. carburettor heat should be applied only if carburettor ice is suspected

  2. carburettor heat should be applied before the throttle is closed and it should be left on during the glide

  3. carburettor heat should be applied just before power is re-applied at the end of the glide

  4. carburettor heat should be applied regularly for brief intervals during the glide

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Carburettor icing during cruise will be indicated to the pilot by

  1. a drop in RPM, a reduction in cruise speed and rough running

  2. no change in RPM, but a reduction in cruise speed and a height loss

  3. the engine back firing when power is increased

  4. increasing RPM even though there has been no change in the throttle position

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If an aircraft fitted with a carburettor and a gravity feed fuel system has a blockage in the fuel tank vent

  1. there will be less power available during take-off

  2. the engine will be very difficult to start

  3. the engine may fail during flight due to fuel starvation

  4. the engine may run roughly due to an excessively rich mixture

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Detonation in an aircraft engine is most likely when

  1. both the engine and fuel are hot and high power is applied

  2. full power is applied during take-off with the mixture fully rich

  3. the throttle is opened after a long descent

  4. the aircraft is cruising at high power for a long period of time

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If detonation is suspected during a long climb you should

  1. reduce the power and raise the nose to climb at a lower speed

  2. increase the power and raise the nose to climb at the same airspeed

  3. reduce the power and raise the nose to increase rate of climb

  4. reduce the power, check that the mixture is fully rich and lower the nose to climb at a higher airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following instruments would be affected by a failure of the vacuum pump?

  1. the altimeter

  2. the vertical speed indicator

  3. the airspeed indicator

  4. the artificial horizon

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the altimeter fails to indicate any height change after take-off the most likely cause is

  1. the vacuum pump has failed

  2. the pitot tube is blocked

  3. the static vent is blocked

  4. the incorrect QNH was set before take-off

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If your aircraft was accidentally refuelled with jet fuel [AVTUR] instead of the correct type of fuel

  1. you would notice a big increase in power during take-off

  2. you would experience a significant power loss accompanied by rough running, detonation and high engine temperatures

  3. there would be no particular effect as long as the tank contains less than half AVTUR

  4. there would be a slight reduction in power but you could continue with the proposed flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If you take off from an uncontrolled airstrip which has left hand circuits, what is the earliest point after take-off at which you may turn right?

  1. 500 feet AGL

  2. 500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

  3. 1000 feet AGL

  4. 1500 feet AGL or 3 nautical miles from the aerodrome boundary

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The lowest height at which you may fly in the training area is

  1. 1000 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 500ft

  2. 1500 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 500ft

  3. 500 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 1000ft

  4. 200 ft provided you are practising forced landings

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

With regard to the end of daylight, you must leave the training area in time to land

  1. 30 minutes before the end of daylight

  2. 10 minutes before the end of daylight

  3. by the end of daylight

  4. 5 minutes after the end of daylight

  1. skidding out

  2. slipping in

  3. overbanking

  4. underbanking
