Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo

Answers

The point about which pitch, roll and yaw occur during flight is the

  1. centre of pressure

  2. wing roots

  3. the mid point between the nose and the tail

  4. the centre of gravity

the centre of gravity

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The location of the centre of gravity of an aeroplane

  1. is a fixed point determined by the manufacturer

  2. depends upon the load distribution within the aircraft

  3. remains constant during any one flight

  4. moves forward if weight is added to the rear

depends upon the load distribution within the aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The induced drag acting on aircraft in straight and level flight is

  1. greatest when speed is low and the aircraft is heavy

  2. greatest when speed is high and the aircraft is heavy

  3. greatest when speed is low and the aircraft is light

  4. greatest when speed is high and the aircraft is light

greatest when speed is low and the aircraft is heavy

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following would increase the parasite drag on an aircraft?

  1. raising the flaps

  2. retracting the undercarriage

  3. increasing the IAS

  4. decreasing the IAS

increasing the IAS

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The least amount of total drag in level flight occurs

  1. at the high end of the speed range at about cruising speed

  2. when the aircraft is flying as slowly as possible

  3. at a speed about equal to the best gliding speed, with the flaps retracted

  4. at a speed about equal to the best gliding speed, with the flaps extended

at a speed about equal to the best gliding speed, with the flaps retracted

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The IAS which produces the best gliding performance in still air is

  1. the IAS which produces maximum lift

  2. the IAS which produces the best lift/drag ratio

  3. the IAS which requires least control deflection

  4. the IAS which results from a level nose attitude

the IAS which produces the best lift/drag ratio

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If flap is lowered while maintaining level flight at constant power

  1. the nose attitude will be lower and the resulting IAS will be lower

  2. the nose attitude will be higher and the resulting IAS will be lower

  3. the nose attitude will be lower and the resulting IAS will be higher

  4. the nose attitude will be higher and the resulting IAS will be higher

the nose attitude will be lower and the resulting IAS will be lower

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If two aircraft identical in every respect except for weight are flying at the same height and IAS,

  1. the heavier aircraft will require a higher nose attitude and more power

  2. the heavier aircraft will require a lower nose attitude and more power

  3. the heavier aircraft will require a lower nose attitude and less power

  4. both aircraft will require the same nose attitude and power

the heavier aircraft will require a higher nose attitude and more power

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following factors will increase the angle of climb of an aircraft?

  1. an increase in weight

  2. an increase in headwind

  3. the use of full flap

  4. climbing at the slowest possible speed will full power

an increase in headwind

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

To achieve the best rate of climb in any given wind the climb should be made

  1. at an IAS lower than that required for best angle with full power applied

  2. at the same IAS as is required for best angle, but with less than full power

  3. at an IAS higher than that required for best angle, but with less than full power

  4. at an IAS higher than that required for best angle with full power applied

at an IAS higher than that required for best angle with full power applied

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What effect will turning have on climb performance?

  1. the angle of climb will decrease but the rate of climb will increase

  2. both angle and rate of climb will decrease

  3. both angle and rate of climb will increase

  4. the angle of climb will increase but the rate of climb will decrease

both angle and rate of climb will decrease

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is flying level at 5000 feet at constant power setting in a tail wind. Which of the following is true?

  1. the IAS is less than the TAS

  2. the IAS is higher than the TAS

  3. the IAS is greater than the GS

  4. the TAS is higher than the GS

the IAS is less than the TAS

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is carrying out a level balanced turn at 60 degrees angle of bank. Which of the following would be correct?

  1. lift is equal to weight

  2. lift is twice the weight

  3. lift is three times weight

  4. lift is 1.4 times weight

lift is twice the weight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft stalls at 50 KIAS in level flight at a particular weight and power setting. At the same weight and power setting, in a 60 degree bank level turn the stalling speed would be closest to

  1. 70 KIAS

  2. 50 KIAS

  3. 60 KIAS

  4. 100 KIAS

70 KIAS

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The elevator control is abruptly pulled to the fully aft position to induce a stall

  1. the stall will occur at a higher speed than normal

  2. the stall will occur at a lower speed than normal

  3. the stall will occur at the same speed but a higher angle of attack than normal

  4. the stall will occur at the same speed and same angle of attack as normal

the stall will occur at a higher speed than normal

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following factors has no effect on the stalling IAS of an aircraft?

  1. weight

  2. load factor

  3. power

  4. height

height

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Where in relation to a heavy aircraft will wake turbulence be worst?

  1. behind and above the heavy aircraft

  2. behind and below the heavy aircraft

  3. in front of and below the heavy aircraft

  4. in front of anf above the heavy aircraft

behind and below the heavy aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following control difficulties is most likely to be associated with an encounter with wake turbulence?

  1. a violent pitch

  2. a violent pitch and yaw

  3. a violent yaw

  4. a violent roll

a violent roll

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The best way to avoid the wake turbulence behind a heavy aircraft which has just landed is to

  1. aim to touch down at point before the touch-down point of the heavy aircraft

  2. aim to touch down at the same point as the heavy aircraft

  3. aim to touch down at a point ahead of the touch-down point of the heavy aircraft

  4. aim to touch down behind the heavy aircraft but on one side of the runway

aim to touch down at a point ahead of the touch-down point of the heavy aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following would result in a decrease in the rate of climb?

  1. a reduction in engine power output

  2. an increase in headwind component

  3. a decrease in headwind component

  4. a reduction in gross weight

a reduction in engine power output

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The purpose of a carburettor is

  1. to mix the correct amount of air with fuel to ensure efficient combustion

  2. to remove any dust particles from the air on its way to the engine

  3. to remove any water from the fuel before it can get to the engine

  4. to cool the air on its way to the engine to prevent detonation

to mix the correct amount of air with fuel to ensure efficient combustion

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Under what circumstances can carburettor ice form?

  1. only when the outside air temperature is below zero

  2. only if the aircraft is flying in rain or drizzle

  3. only at low power settings in cold moist air

  4. over a very wide range of temperatures, both inside and outside of cloud

only at low power settings in cold moist air

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Under which of the following circumstances would carburettor ice be difficult to detect?

  1. at full power during take-off

  2. during a long climb

  3. during a long descent at low power

  4. during cruise just below a cloud base

during a long descent at low power

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What is the correct method of using carburettor heat during a long power-off glide?

  1. carburettor heat should be applied only if carburettor ice is suspected

  2. carburettor heat should be applied before the throttle is closed and it should be left on during the glide

  3. carburettor heat should be applied just before power is re-applied at the end of the glide

  4. carburettor heat should be applied regularly for brief intervals during the glide

carburettor heat should be applied before the throttle is closed and it should be left on during the glide

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Carburettor icing during cruise will be indicated to the pilot by

  1. a drop in RPM, a reduction in cruise speed and rough running

  2. no change in RPM, but a reduction in cruise speed and a height loss

  3. the engine back firing when power is increased

  4. increasing RPM even though there has been no change in the throttle position

a drop in RPM, a reduction in cruise speed and rough running

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If an aircraft fitted with a carburettor and a gravity feed fuel system has a blockage in the fuel tank vent

  1. there will be less power available during take-off

  2. the engine will be very difficult to start

  3. the engine may fail during flight due to fuel starvation

  4. the engine may run roughly due to an excessively rich mixture

the engine may fail during flight due to fuel starvation

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Detonation in an aircraft engine is most likely when

  1. both the engine and fuel are hot and high power is applied

  2. full power is applied during take-off with the mixture fully rich

  3. the throttle is opened after a long descent

  4. the aircraft is cruising at high power for a long period of time

both the engine and fuel are hot and high power is applied

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If detonation is suspected during a long climb you should

  1. reduce the power and raise the nose to climb at a lower speed

  2. increase the power and raise the nose to climb at the same airspeed

  3. reduce the power and raise the nose to increase rate of climb

  4. reduce the power, check that the mixture is fully rich and lower the nose to climb at a higher airspeed

reduce the power, check that the mixture is fully rich and lower the nose to climb at a higher airspeed

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following instruments would be affected by a failure of the vacuum pump?

  1. the altimeter

  2. the vertical speed indicator

  3. the airspeed indicator

  4. the artificial horizon

the artificial horizon

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the altimeter fails to indicate any height change after take-off the most likely cause is

  1. the vacuum pump has failed

  2. the pitot tube is blocked

  3. the static vent is blocked

  4. the incorrect QNH was set before take-off

the static vent is blocked

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If your aircraft was accidentally refuelled with jet fuel [AVTUR] instead of the correct type of fuel

  1. you would notice a big increase in power during take-off

  2. you would experience a significant power loss accompanied by rough running, detonation and high engine temperatures

  3. there would be no particular effect as long as the tank contains less than half AVTUR

  4. there would be a slight reduction in power but you could continue with the proposed flight

you would experience a significant power loss accompanied by rough running, detonation and high engine temperatures

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If you take off from an uncontrolled airstrip which has left hand circuits, what is the earliest point after take-off at which you may turn right?

  1. 500 feet AGL

  2. 500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

  3. 1000 feet AGL

  4. 1500 feet AGL or 3 nautical miles from the aerodrome boundary

1500 feet AGL or 3 nautical miles from the aerodrome boundary

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The lowest height at which you may fly in the training area is

  1. 1000 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 500ft

  2. 1500 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 500ft

  3. 500 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 1000ft

  4. 200 ft provided you are practising forced landings

1000 ft over a town or populous area otherwise 500ft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

With regard to the end of daylight, you must leave the training area in time to land

  1. 30 minutes before the end of daylight

  2. 10 minutes before the end of daylight

  3. by the end of daylight

  4. 5 minutes after the end of daylight

10 minutes before the end of daylight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

When turning from upwind to downwind at low level on a very windy day, you may experience the illusion of

  1. skidding out

  2. slipping in

  3. overbanking

  4. underbanking

slipping in

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Area Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Where may a student pilot **not** fly solo?

  1. beyond the circuit area of the aerodrome

  2. beyond circuit area of the aerodrome or beyond the associated training area

  3. within the training area

  4. flying the most direct route between the training area and the aerodrome

beyond circuit area of the aerodrome or beyond the associated training area

What is the maximum number of consecutive solo hours that a student pilot may fly?

  1. 2

  2. 10

  3. 3

  4. 5

3

  2. after each refuelling

  3. before the first flight of each day

  4. after each refuelling and before the first flight of the day

after each refuelling and before the first flight of the day

When operating at 2000 ft AMSL in your local training area, which of the following would be the minimum requirement for maintaining VMC?

  2. 500 ft below the cloud base and visibility of 5 km

  3. clear of cloud and visibility of 5 km

  4. clear of cloud with no special requirement for visibility

clear of cloud and visibility of 5 km

  2. 30 days

  3. 90 days

  4. 14 days

14 days

Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo

Questions

Seat belts/safety harnesses must be worn, at all stages of flight, by:

  1. the pilot when he/she is the sole pilot.

  2. the occupants of both control seats.

  3. all on board during climb and descent.

  4. two children when they occupy a single seat.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

Civil Aviation Regulations require that turns onto final approach must:

  1. commence not below 500ft AGL.

  2. be completed not closer than 500 metres from the threshold.

  3. be completed not closer than 500 metres from the aerodrome perimeter.

  4. be completed not closer than 500 metres away from any displaced threshold.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A pilot in command shall not consume any alcoholic liquor:

  1. 12 hours before the departure of the flight.

  2. 24 hours before reporting for duty.

  3. 8 hours before reporting for duty.

  4. 8 hours before the departure of the flight.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

The minimum horizontal distance from cloud for a fixed-wing aircraft, operating in Class G airspace, is:

  1. 1,500 metres.

  2. 1,500ft.

  3. 1,000ft.

  4. clear of cloud.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

The fuel system in an aircraft must be checked for water contamination:

  1. before each flight.

  2. before the first flight of the day and after each refuelling.

  3. before the first flight of the day and after the last flight of the day.

  4. at least once a day.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

One restriction placed on VFR aircraft, operating at or below 2,000ft, is:

  1. minimum horizontal distance from cloud is 2,000 metres.

  2. minimum flight visibility is 6 km.

  3. navigation must be by visual reference to the ground or water.

  4. minimum vertical distance from cloud is 1,000ft.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A student pilot is not permitted to carry passengers unless:

  1. he/she has completed 2 hours as pilot in command.

  2. he/she has passed the General Flying Progress Test and flies within the student pilot area limits.

  3. he/she has completed 5 hours of cross-country flying.

  4. he/she has had a dual flight within the last 30 days.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

With local QNH set on a subscale, an altimeter will always read:

  1. pressure height.

  2. density height.

  3. height above mean sea level.

  4. height above ground level.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

At a non-towered aerodrome, you should not continue an approach beyond the threshold until a preceding light aeroplane, using the same runway has:

  1. landed, and has vacated the runway, irrespective of the runway length, and is taxiing away.

  2. landed, and is at least 1,800 metres from the landing threshold.

  3. taken off and is at least 200 AGL.

  4. taken off and is at least 600 metres ahead of the landing threshold.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

You are to operate from a non-towered aerodrome where there is no ATIS and no other way of knowing the latest QNH. Before take-off, you should:

  1. set the altimeter to read the aerodrome elevation.

  2. set the altimeter to read zero feet.

  3. set an approximate aerodrome pressure in the subscale.

  4. set 1013hPa on the subscale.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

One item which must be included in a passenger briefing prior to take-off is:

  1. a demonstration of the correct crash landing position.

  2. the use and location of fire extuingishers.

  3. the use and adjustment of seat belts.

  4. the demonstration of evacuation procedures.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

With regard to the rules of the air in CAR, which statement is correct?

  1. An aircraft that is overtaking another aeroplane, has right of way.

  2. If an aeroplane and a glider are approaching head-on at approximately the same height the aeroplane must give way to the glider.

  3. An aircraft that is within 70 degrees of the astern position of an aircraft ahead is considered an overtaking aircraft, if its speed is greater.

  4. An aircraft that is overtaking another aircraft must do so by altering its heading to the left.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

On which of the following types of flying is a passenger not permitted to be carried?

  1. An aircraft engaged in aerobatic flying.

  2. Flying training given to a person who has not passed the General Flying Progress Test (GFPT).

  3. An aircraft carrying out formation flying.

  4. An aircraft engaged in search and rescue (SAR) operations.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

You are to carry out a flight from Parafield (GAAP) to the training area in a Piper Arrow -- XYG. You are also in receipt of ATIS information "Charlie", indicating Runway 21 Right is being used. Your pre-taxi radiocall will be:

  1. Parafield Ground, X-ray Yankee Golf, Piper Arrow, received Charlie, VFR for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right.

  2. Parafield Ground, Piper Arrow X-ray Yankee Golf, for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right, taxi clearance, received Charlie.

  3. Parafield Ground, X-ray Yankee Golf, for the Training Area, received Charlie.

  4. Parafield Ground, Piper Arrow X-ray Yankee Golf, taxi clearance for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right, received Charlie.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

Area QNH is:

  1. the aerodrome pressure set in the altimeter before taxiing.

  2. the mean sea level pressure set in the altimeter before taxiing.

  3. the local aerodrome pressure set in the altimeter while on a navigation or cross-country flight.

  4. the mean sea level pressure set in the altimeter of the area over which the aircraft is flying while on a navigation or cross-country exercise.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

When the aerodrome QNH is set, during taxi, the altimeter should read:

  1. zero.

  2. airfield elevation.

  3. vertical distance AGL.

  4. vertical distance AAL.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

One of the basic rules following an engine failure immediately after take-off is:

  1. always try to restart the engine.

  2. immediately make a distress call.

  3. never turn back to the runway.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A hard pull up on the control column can cause an aeroplane to stall at almost any speed because:

  1. of reduced control effectiveness.

  2. the critical angle of attack can be exceeded.

  3. of decreased angle of attack.

  4. of reduced airspeed.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A white dumb-bell symbol has been placed adjacent the primary wind indicator on your airfield. This means:

  1. the airfield is completely unserviceable.

  2. poor surface this area, do not taxi here.

  3. parachute operations in progress.

  4. use hard surfaces only.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

An aircraft stall-warning device will:

  1. indicate that a stall has occurred.

  2. cause a light to come on and a horn to sound after the aircraft stalls.

  3. indicate that the aircraft is approaching the stall at any attitude.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

Answers

  1. the pilot when he/she is the sole pilot.

  2. the occupants of both control seats.

  3. all on board during climb and descent.

  4. two children when they occupy a single seat.

the pilot when he/she is the sole pilot.

  1. he/she has completed 2 hours as pilot in command.

  2. he/she has passed the General Flying Progress Test and flies within the student pilot area limits.

  3. he/she has completed 5 hours of cross-country flying.

he/she has passed the General Flying Progress Test and flies within the student pilot area limits.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

With local QNH set on a subscale, an altimeter will always read:

  1. pressure height.

  2. density height.

  3. height above mean sea level.

  4. height above ground level.

height above mean sea level.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

At a non-towered aerodrome, you should not continue an approach beyond the threshold until a preceding light aeroplane, using the same runway has:

  1. landed, and has vacated the runway, irrespective of the runway length, and is taxiing away.

  2. landed, and is at least 1,800 metres from the landing threshold.

  3. taken off and is at least 200 AGL.

  4. taken off and is at least 600 metres ahead of the landing threshold.

landed, and has vacated the runway, irrespective of the runway length, and is taxiing away.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

You are to operate from a non-towered aerodrome where there is no ATIS and no other way of knowing the latest QNH. Before take-off, you should:

  1. set the altimeter to read the aerodrome elevation.

  2. set the altimeter to read zero feet.

  3. set an approximate aerodrome pressure in the subscale.

  4. set 1013hPa on the subscale.

set the altimeter to read the aerodrome elevation.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

One item which must be included in a passenger briefing prior to take-off is:

  1. a demonstration of the correct crash landing position.

  2. the use and location of fire extuingishers.

  3. the use and adjustment of seat belts.

  4. the demonstration of evacuation procedures.

the use and adjustment of seat belts.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

With regard to the rules of the air in CAR, which statement is correct?

  1. An aircraft that is overtaking another aeroplane, has right of way.

  2. If an aeroplane and a glider are approaching head-on at approximately the same height the aeroplane must give way to the glider.

  3. An aircraft that is within 70 degrees of the astern position of an aircraft ahead is considered an overtaking aircraft, if its speed is greater.

  4. An aircraft that is overtaking another aircraft must do so by altering its heading to the left.

An aircraft that is within 70 degrees of the astern position of an aircraft ahead is considered an overtaking aircraft, if its speed is greater.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

On which of the following types of flying is a passenger not permitted to be carried?

  1. An aircraft engaged in aerobatic flying.

  2. Flying training given to a person who has not passed the General Flying Progress Test (GFPT).

  3. An aircraft carrying out formation flying.

  4. An aircraft engaged in search and rescue (SAR) operations.

Flying training given to a person who has not passed the General Flying Progress Test (GFPT).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

You are to carry out a flight from Parafield (GAAP) to the training area in a Piper Arrow -- XYG. You are also in receipt of ATIS information "Charlie", indicating Runway 21 Right is being used. Your pre-taxi radiocall will be:

  1. Parafield Ground, X-ray Yankee Golf, Piper Arrow, received Charlie, VFR for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right.

  2. Parafield Ground, Piper Arrow X-ray Yankee Golf, for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right, taxi clearance, received Charlie.

  3. Parafield Ground, X-ray Yankee Golf, for the Training Area, received Charlie.

  4. Parafield Ground, Piper Arrow X-ray Yankee Golf, taxi clearance for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right, received Charlie.

Parafield Ground, X-ray Yankee Golf, Piper Arrow, received Charlie, VFR for the Training Area, Runway 21 Right.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

Area QNH is:

  1. the aerodrome pressure set in the altimeter before taxiing.

  2. the mean sea level pressure set in the altimeter before taxiing.

  3. the local aerodrome pressure set in the altimeter while on a navigation or cross-country flight.

  4. the mean sea level pressure set in the altimeter of the area over which the aircraft is flying while on a navigation or cross-country exercise.

the mean sea level pressure set in the altimeter of the area over which the aircraft is flying while on a navigation or cross-country exercise.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

When the aerodrome QNH is set, during taxi, the altimeter should read:

  1. zero.

  2. airfield elevation.

  3. vertical distance AGL.

  4. vertical distance AAL.

airfield elevation.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

One of the basic rules following an engine failure immediately after take-off is:

  1. always try to restart the engine.

  2. immediately make a distress call.

  3. never turn back to the runway.

never turn back to the runway.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A hard pull up on the control column can cause an aeroplane to stall at almost any speed because:

  1. of reduced control effectiveness.

  2. the critical angle of attack can be exceeded.

  3. of decreased angle of attack.

  4. of reduced airspeed.

the critical angle of attack can be exceeded.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

A white dumb-bell symbol has been placed adjacent the primary wind indicator on your airfield. This means:

  1. the airfield is completely unserviceable.

  2. poor surface this area, do not taxi here.

  3. parachute operations in progress.

  4. use hard surfaces only.

use hard surfaces only.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

An aircraft stall-warning device will:

  1. indicate that a stall has occurred.

  2. cause a light to come on and a horn to sound after the aircraft stalls.

  3. indicate that the aircraft is approaching the stall at any attitude.

indicate that the aircraft is approaching the stall at any attitude.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Solo

Best angle of climb.

What is meant by Va?

Maximum maneuvering speed; speed of maximum application of a flight control.

What is meant by Vs0?

Stall speed in landing configuration; full flap, gear extended.

RPL,Self-made,Air Speeds

Vs0

Back to question
Airspeeds Exam self-made
RPL,Self-made,Air Speeds

What is meant by Vs1?

Stall speed in clean configuration; no flap, no gear.

Back to question
Airspeeds Exam self-made
RPL,Self-made,Air Speeds

What V-speed is stall speed in clean configuration?

Vs1

Back to question
Airspeeds Exam self-made
RPL,Self-made,Air Speeds

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1

Questions

Which of the following documents must always be carried by an Australian registered aircraft in flight within Australian territory?

  1. A list of passengers' names with places of embarkation and destination.

  2. The licences and medical certificates of the operating crew.

  3. The aircraft's certificate of registration.

  4. The cargo manifest.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Unless exempt, a pilot intending to operate within an ADIZ, must lodge flight notification

  1. At least 60 minutes prior to entry to the ADIZ.

  2. At least 30 minutes prior to entry to the ADIZ.

  3. but need not report departure.

  4. if electing not to report position to ATS when passing each position reporting point within the ADIZ.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Which of the following statements does NOT apply to the carriage of children and infants in Australian aircraft?

  1. Two children (aged between 3 and 13 years) whose combined weight does not exceed 77 kg may be seated on one passenger seat.

  2. An infant who has not reached the age of three years may be carried on the lap of an adult passenger providing that the seat belt is secured around the adult but not the infant.

  3. An infant may be carried in a bassinet provided that the bassinet is of an approved type and is restrained from all movement.

  4. Two children of any age and weight may occupy the one seat.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Located some eight miles to the west of Wagga airfield is an area designated 'R418'. One of the following statements relates to flight through that area.

  1. Flight through it is not permitted under any circumstances.

  2. Flight through it would be permitted under the terms of a clearance obtained from the controlling authority.

  3. You could fly through the area without specific approval provided that a good lookout was maintained inside the area.

  4. Only military aircraft would be permitted to fly through the area.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

On the final leg of a VFR flight, you elect to cruise at 8500ft. After departure you would change from the local aerodrome QNH to the area QNH on

  1. leaving the circuit area of the departure aerodrome.

  2. leaving 5000ft on climb.

  3. receipt of the area QNH from ATS.

  4. reaching 8500ft.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

You are approached by someone who asks if you would undertake a mercy flight to an aeroplane landing area -- which of the following statements is correct in relation to the declaration or conduct of a mercy flight.

  1. It can only be conducted into a government or licensed aerodrome and must be classified as a mercy flight by an approved CASA officer.

  2. It should only be classed as a mercy flight by the pilot and then only if it seems likely that some regulation would need to be broken.

  3. It can only be requested by a CASA officer.

  4. It should only be declared a mercy flight by a doctor if it is an urgent medical evacuation flight.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

After landing on a certified aerodrome or registered (licensed) aerodrome, your aircraft (on a private flight) strikes a kangaroo with the left wing -- the wing suffers minor damage and neither passengers nor pilot are injured. The appropriate action to take as a result of the above event would be to:

  1. forward a written notification (preferably on an ASAIR) to the ATSB within 48 hours.

  2. notify the ATSB by telephone since this is an 'immediately reportable matter'.

  3. forward a written notification (preferably on an ASAIR) to the ATSB within 72 hours.

  4. notify the ATSB by telephone since this is a 'routine reportable matter'.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Two aircraft are approaching each other in flight almost head-on, and there appears to be a risk of a collision. Under these circumstances,

  1. the larger aircraft must alter heading to the right.

  2. both aircraft shall turn left to avoid a collision.

  3. the smaller aircraft shall have right of way.

  4. both aircraft shall turn right to avoid a collision.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

For 'normal' operations at, or in the vicinity of, all non-controlled certified, registered (licensed) or military aerodromes (or controlled aerodromes where the tower is not manned),

  1. right-hand circuits apply.

  2. VHF radio is required but only by VFR aircraft.

  3. there is a requirement for the pilot to have a radiotelephone qualification.

  4. serviceable VHF radio is mandatory and the pilot must have a radiotelephone qualification.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Cloud tops are at 3000ft AMSL. The minimum altitude above the cloud tops at which an aircraft can cruise VFR in Class G airspace is:

  1. 3000ft.

  2. 4500ft or 5500ft depending on the track direction.

  3. 4000ft or 5000ft depending on the track direction.

  4. 3500ft.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aircraft is flying over open countryside, the general elevation of which is approximately 300ft. Except through stress of weather, the minimum altitude at which the aircraft can fly is ______ ft.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aircraft is flying in the circuit area of an aerodrome at which a control tower is in operation. The pilot observes a flashing red light from the control tower, directed towards his aircraft. The meaning of this signal is:

  1. Give way to other aircraft and continue circling.

  2. Aerodrome closed -- fly to another airfield for landing.

  3. Aerodrome unsafe -- do not land.

  4. Of no significance.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Flight notification for a local (brief duration) VFR flight intending to operate in controlled airspace:

  1. must be submitted by fax or phone to ATC in full, i.e., details as required for the Domestic Flight Notification form.

  2. must be submitted in writing to ATS in full, as for a SARTIME flight.

  3. can be submitted by radio to ATC in brief on departure.

  4. should be submitted by rado to ATS in full on departure.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

  2. S31.33 E149.23

  3. 3103'E 14923'S

  4. 3133'E 149.03'S

  1. 5 left

  2. 10 right

  3. 5 right

  4. 10 left

  1. The railway from Burren Junction to Bugilbone homestead.

extract of ROCKHAMPTON WAC (3235)

  1. 4 min later than originally planned.

  2. 2 min later than originally planned.

  3. 4 min earlier than originally planned.

  4. 2 min earlier than originally planned.

  2. at least 30 min before to at least 60 min after the planned ETA

  3. at least 30 min before to at least 30 min after the planned ETA

  4. at least 60 min before to at least 30 min after the planned ETA

  • Variation = 5W

  • TAS = 106kt

  • WV (from the ARFOR at the planned level) = 185/25

The heading and groundspeed respectively will be closest to

  1. 260M, 100kt

  2. 260T, 103kt

  3. 260M, 105kt

  4. 260T, 100kt

  1. 390 litres

  1. cloud with a coverage of 5 OKTA

  4. less than SCT cloud below a ceiling of 1500 feet

The latest ETD for a flight from 'A' (3110'S 14827'E) to 'B' (1512'S 15230'E) on the 18th January with a flight planned TI of 170 min, is ____ EST.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Supercharging can be achieved by utilising a centrifugal compressor that is driven by

  1. an electric motor.

  2. the engine (through gears) or driven by an exhaust gas turbine.

  3. the engine directly from the crankshaft.

  4. a hydraulic motor.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

In some autopilot systems, a preset clutch is built into the electrical servos to allow the pilot to 'overpower' or override the autopilot. Which of the following statements best describes the precautions associated with this action?

  1. Disengagement of the autopilot in this way at high airspeeds should be avoided as it may overstress and/or damage the control surfaces.

  2. Disengagement in this way may strip the clutch gears if done at high airspeeds.

  3. Once the autopilot is disconnected in this way, the pilot may not be able to re-engage it.

  4. The high control column force needed to 'trip' the clutch may produce a large, unwanted attitude change once the clutch disengages.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The factor(s) that take(s) account of aeroplane configuration and pilot technique on a takeoff weight chart is/are

  1. takeoff safety speed

  2. flap setting and power required

  3. power required, flap setting and takeoff safety speed

  4. power required, chart distance factor, flap setting and takeoff safety speed

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Apart from lean mixture and carburettor heat COLD, the power and height requirements for an aeroplane with a fixed pitch propellor to achieve maximum range are

  1. full-throttle height for power to maintain IAS[subscript MNM D]

  2. as low as possible with power to maintain IAS[subscript MNM P]

  3. full-throttle height for 50% MC power and IAs[subscript MNM D]

  4. as low as possible with power to maintain 0.76 of IAS[subscript MAX L/D]

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aircraft's heading is 320M and the relative bearing of an aerodrome from the aeroplane is 210. Therefore the magnetic bearing of the aerodrome (from the aeroplane) is ____M.

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

  1. 142 kg

  2. 313 kg

  3. 538 kg

  4. 1185 lb

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Piper `Romeo` loading system

Given:

  • Basic index units = -300

  • Basic empty weight = 1000 kg

  • Row 1 -- pilot and passenger = 140 kg

  • Row 2 -- forward facing passengers = 165 kg

  • Row 3 -- seat loaded baggage - 100 kg

  • Other baggage = 65 kg

Assuming no performance limits, the maximum fuel at takeoff is

  1. 348 L

  2. 163 kg

  3. 168 kg

  4. 356 L

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Cessna `Papa` loading system

Given:

A Cessna 'Papa' aeroplane weighs 2050 lb with full fuel tanks and all occupants loaded. The loaded 'Moment/1000 inch lb' is 88.5. The maximum baggage compartment load for 'normal' category operations is ____ kg.

The maximum baggage compartment load for 'normal' category operations is ____ kg.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Cessna `Papa` loading system

You plan to depart from an aerodrome under the following conditions:

  • Aerodrome elevation: 2050ft

  • QNH: 1030 hPa

  • Temperature: 20C

  • Runway direction: 35/17

  • Runway surface: long dry grass

  • Runway slope: 1.5% down to south

  • Wind: 360/15

  • Gross weight for takeoff: 1089kg

  • Flap setting: 10

The minimum required takeoff distance is ____ m

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Piper `Quebec` loading system

Given:

  • RWY: 08/26

  • Landing Distance Available: 1200m

  • Slope: 2% down to the east

  • Pressure Height: 5000ft

  • Wind: 090/10

  • Temperature: 30C

The landing distance required under these conditions is

  1. 580m with a MAX LDW of not more than 1040 kg.

  2. 580m.

  3. 725m.

  4. 725m with a MAX LDW of not more than 1040 kg.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The length of runway which is declared to be available and suitable for the ground landing run of an aeroplane is known as the

  1. Landing Distance Available

  2. TODA

  3. ASDA

  4. Declared Distance Available

PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

  1. a decrease in air temperature.

  2. an increase in headwind component.

  3. setting maximum power.

  4. an increase in air temperature.

  3. lift-off.

  4. a point halfway down the runway.

In a MET forecast, wind direction is related to

  1. true north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '00000KT'.

  2. magnetic north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '9999KT'.

  3. true north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '9999KT'.

  4. magnetic north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '00000KT'.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

In TAFs and METARs, cloud height refers to the:

  1. height of the cloud tops.

  2. height above mean sea level (AMSL).

  3. height of the lowest cloud.

  4. height above the aerodrome (AGL).

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aeroplane has a straight and level stall speed of 60kt. If the 'apparent' weight is increased by 50% i.e. the load factor is increased by 50%, the new stall speed will be ____kt

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Maximum angle of climb is achieved when an aeroplane is flown at maximum continuous power and an airspeed

  1. higher than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack greater than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  2. lower than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack greater than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  3. lower than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack less than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  4. higher than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack less than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

As the angle of attack is increased, lift

  1. increases until the stalling angle is reached, then decreases.

  2. decreases until the stalling angle is reached, then increases.

  3. increases until the angle of attack for maximum lift/drag ratio is reached.

  4. decreases until zero angle of attack is reached, then increases again.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

While maintaining a constant angle of bank and altitude in a coordinated turn, an increase in IAS will

  1. increase both the rate and radius of turn.

  2. increase both the radius of turn and load factor.

  3. decrease both the rate and radius of turn.

  4. decrease the rate of turn but increase the radius of turn.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

When full flap is lowered, the slower speed (and increased drag) during approach will

  1. increase the landing distance.

  2. steepen the approach path and increase the landing distance.

  3. reduce the approach angle and the landing distance.

  4. steepen the approach path and reduce the landing distance.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

If the rightaileron is deflected down and held (and no other controls are moved), the aeroplane will

  1. both roll and yaw to the right.

  2. initially roll to the left, then sideslip to the left and yaw to the left.

  3. initially sideslip to the left, then yaw to the right.

  4. initially roll to the right, then sideslip to the right and yaw to the right.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The stalling speed of an aeroplane is increased by an increase in

  1. IAS.

  2. load factor.

  3. angle of attack.

  4. lift.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Most autopilots can be disconnected

  1. only when 'interlock' logic circuits permit.

  2. only when the aircraft is properly trimmed.

  3. by any one of the three actions -- disengage switch, control column cut-out switch(es) or by flying control override.

  4. by either the disengage switch, or the control column cut-out switch(es).

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The longitudinal stability of an aeroplane will be increased if

  1. the load is increased and the centre of gravity stays in the same position.

  2. the load is decreased and the centre of gravity stays in the same position.

  3. the centre of gravity is moved forward.

  4. the centre of gravity is moved towards the rear.

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aeroplane climbing out of ground effect (with angle of attack and power setting constant) will suffer reduced climb-out performance. This is a result of

  1. decreased lift

  2. decreased lift and increased induced drag

  3. an increase in total drag

  4. reduced wingtip vortices

Answer
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1

Answers

Which of the following documents must always be carried by an Australian registered aircraft in flight within Australian territory?

  1. A list of passengers' names with places of embarkation and destination.

  2. The licences and medical certificates of the operating crew.

  3. The aircraft's certificate of registration.

  4. The cargo manifest.

The licences and medical certificates of the operating crew.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Unless exempt, a pilot intending to operate within an ADIZ, must lodge flight notification

  1. At least 60 minutes prior to entry to the ADIZ.

  2. At least 30 minutes prior to entry to the ADIZ.

  3. but need not report departure.

  4. if electing not to report position to ATS when passing each position reporting point within the ADIZ.

At least 60 minutes prior to entry to the ADIZ.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Which of the following statements does NOT apply to the carriage of children and infants in Australian aircraft?

  1. Two children (aged between 3 and 13 years) whose combined weight does not exceed 77 kg may be seated on one passenger seat.

  2. An infant who has not reached the age of three years may be carried on the lap of an adult passenger providing that the seat belt is secured around the adult but not the infant.

  3. An infant may be carried in a bassinet provided that the bassinet is of an approved type and is restrained from all movement.

  4. Two children of any age and weight may occupy the one seat.

Two children of any age and weight may occupy the one seat.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Located some eight miles to the west of Wagga airfield is an area designated 'R418'. One of the following statements relates to flight through that area.

  1. Flight through it is not permitted under any circumstances.

  2. Flight through it would be permitted under the terms of a clearance obtained from the controlling authority.

  3. You could fly through the area without specific approval provided that a good lookout was maintained inside the area.

  4. Only military aircraft would be permitted to fly through the area.

Flight through it would be permitted under the terms of a clearance obtained from the controlling authority.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

On the final leg of a VFR flight, you elect to cruise at 8500ft. After departure you would change from the local aerodrome QNH to the area QNH on

  1. leaving the circuit area of the departure aerodrome.

  2. leaving 5000ft on climb.

  3. receipt of the area QNH from ATS.

  4. reaching 8500ft.

reaching 8500ft.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

You are approached by someone who asks if you would undertake a mercy flight to an aeroplane landing area -- which of the following statements is correct in relation to the declaration or conduct of a mercy flight.

  1. It can only be conducted into a government or licensed aerodrome and must be classified as a mercy flight by an approved CASA officer.

  2. It should only be classed as a mercy flight by the pilot and then only if it seems likely that some regulation would need to be broken.

  3. It can only be requested by a CASA officer.

  4. It should only be declared a mercy flight by a doctor if it is an urgent medical evacuation flight.

It should only be classed as a mercy flight by the pilot and then only if it seems likely that some regulation would need to be broken.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

After landing on a certified aerodrome or registered (licensed) aerodrome, your aircraft (on a private flight) strikes a kangaroo with the left wing -- the wing suffers minor damage and neither passengers nor pilot are injured. The appropriate action to take as a result of the above event would be to:

  1. forward a written notification (preferably on an ASAIR) to the ATSB within 48 hours.

  2. notify the ATSB by telephone since this is an 'immediately reportable matter'.

  3. forward a written notification (preferably on an ASAIR) to the ATSB within 72 hours.

  4. notify the ATSB by telephone since this is a 'routine reportable matter'.

forward a written notification (preferably on an ASAIR) to the ATSB within 72 hours.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Two aircraft are approaching each other in flight almost head-on, and there appears to be a risk of a collision. Under these circumstances,

  1. the larger aircraft must alter heading to the right.

  2. both aircraft shall turn left to avoid a collision.

  3. the smaller aircraft shall have right of way.

  4. both aircraft shall turn right to avoid a collision.

both aircraft shall turn right to avoid a collision.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

For 'normal' operations at, or in the vicinity of, all non-controlled certified, registered (licensed) or military aerodromes (or controlled aerodromes where the tower is not manned),

  1. right-hand circuits apply.

  2. VHF radio is required but only by VFR aircraft.

  3. there is a requirement for the pilot to have a radiotelephone qualification.

  4. serviceable VHF radio is mandatory and the pilot must have a radiotelephone qualification.

serviceable VHF radio is mandatory and the pilot must have a radiotelephone qualification.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Cloud tops are at 3000ft AMSL. The minimum altitude above the cloud tops at which an aircraft can cruise VFR in Class G airspace is:

  1. 3000ft.

  2. 4500ft or 5500ft depending on the track direction.

  3. 4000ft or 5000ft depending on the track direction.

  4. 3500ft.

4500ft or 5500ft depending on the track direction.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aircraft is flying over open countryside, the general elevation of which is approximately 300ft. Except through stress of weather, the minimum altitude at which the aircraft can fly is ______ ft.

800ft

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aircraft is flying in the circuit area of an aerodrome at which a control tower is in operation. The pilot observes a flashing red light from the control tower, directed towards his aircraft. The meaning of this signal is:

  1. Give way to other aircraft and continue circling.

  2. Aerodrome closed -- fly to another airfield for landing.

  3. Aerodrome unsafe -- do not land.

  4. Of no significance.

Aerodrome unsafe -- do not land.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Flight notification for a local (brief duration) VFR flight intending to operate in controlled airspace:

  1. must be submitted by fax or phone to ATC in full, i.e., details as required for the Domestic Flight Notification form.

  2. must be submitted in writing to ATS in full, as for a SARTIME flight.

  3. can be submitted by radio to ATC in brief on departure.

  4. should be submitted by rado to ATS in full on departure.

can be submitted by radio to ATC in brief on departure.

Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1

Supercharging can be achieved by utilising a centrifugal compressor that is driven by

  1. an electric motor.

  2. the engine (through gears) or driven by an exhaust gas turbine.

  3. the engine directly from the crankshaft.

  4. a hydraulic motor.

the engine (through gears) or driven by an exhaust gas turbine.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

In some autopilot systems, a preset clutch is built into the electrical servos to allow the pilot to 'overpower' or override the autopilot. Which of the following statements best describes the precautions associated with this action?

  1. Disengagement of the autopilot in this way at high airspeeds should be avoided as it may overstress and/or damage the control surfaces.

  2. Disengagement in this way may strip the clutch gears if done at high airspeeds.

  3. Once the autopilot is disconnected in this way, the pilot may not be able to re-engage it.

  4. The high control column force needed to 'trip' the clutch may produce a large, unwanted attitude change once the clutch disengages.

The high control column force needed to 'trip' the clutch may produce a large, unwanted attitude change once the clutch disengages.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The factor(s) that take(s) account of aeroplane configuration and pilot technique on a takeoff weight chart is/are

  1. takeoff safety speed

  2. flap setting and power required

  3. power required, flap setting and takeoff safety speed

  4. power required, chart distance factor, flap setting and takeoff safety speed

power required, flap setting and takeoff safety speed

PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

  1. full-throttle height for power to maintain IAS[subscript MNM D]

  2. as low as possible with power to maintain IAS[subscript MNM P]

  3. full-throttle height for 50% MC power and IAs[subscript MNM D]

  4. as low as possible with power to maintain 0.76 of IAS[subscript MAX L/D]

full-throttle height for power to maintain IAS[subscript MNM D]

'ARFOR/TAF 1 -- Area 30'

'PCA'

The forecast wind direction and speed at 5000ft along the route between Wonthaggi (YWON) and Orbost (YORB) are:

  1. Variable at 10kt.

  2. 280M/15kt.

  3. 280T/15kt.

  4. 340M/15kt.

280T/15kt.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

At 0500 UTC over Benalla -- YBLA, the forecast type of cloud and the height of its base are:

  1. SCT AC/AS at 10000ft.

  2. Nil

  3. SCT SC at 3000ft.

  4. BKN AC/AS at 10000ft.

Nil

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Between 2300 UTC and 0300 UTC, the significant weather expected along the route from Mildura -- YMIA to Colac -- YOLA at 7500ft is

  1. ISOL rain.

  2. MOD icing in AC/AS.

  3. MOD turbulence in AC.

  4. Nil.

Nil.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

In a MET forecast, wind direction is related to

  1. true north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '00000KT'.

  2. magnetic north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '9999KT'.

  3. true north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '9999KT'.

  4. magnetic north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '00000KT'.

true north and if the wind is calm, it is encoded as '00000KT'.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

In TAFs and METARs, cloud height refers to the:

  1. height of the cloud tops.

  2. height above mean sea level (AMSL).

  3. height of the lowest cloud.

  4. height above the aerodrome (AGL).

height above the aerodrome (AGL).

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aeroplane has a straight and level stall speed of 60kt. If the 'apparent' weight is increased by 50% i.e. the load factor is increased by 50%, the new stall speed will be ____kt

72 2

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Maximum angle of climb is achieved when an aeroplane is flown at maximum continuous power and an airspeed

  1. higher than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack greater than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  2. lower than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack greater than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  3. lower than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack less than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

  4. higher than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack less than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

lower than the best rate of climb speed, i.e. at an angle of attack greater than the angle of attack for MAX L/D.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

As the angle of attack is increased, lift

  1. increases until the stalling angle is reached, then decreases.

  2. decreases until the stalling angle is reached, then increases.

  3. increases until the angle of attack for maximum lift/drag ratio is reached.

  4. decreases until zero angle of attack is reached, then increases again.

increases until the stalling angle is reached, then decreases.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

While maintaining a constant angle of bank and altitude in a coordinated turn, an increase in IAS will

  1. increase both the rate and radius of turn.

  2. increase both the radius of turn and load factor.

  3. decrease both the rate and radius of turn.

  4. decrease the rate of turn but increase the radius of turn.

decrease the rate of turn but increase the radius of turn.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

When full flap is lowered, the slower speed (and increased drag) during approach will

  1. increase the landing distance.

  2. steepen the approach path and increase the landing distance.

  3. reduce the approach angle and the landing distance.

  4. steepen the approach path and reduce the landing distance.

steepen the approach path and reduce the landing distance.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

If the rightaileron is deflected down and held (and no other controls are moved), the aeroplane will

  1. both roll and yaw to the right.

  2. initially roll to the left, then sideslip to the left and yaw to the left.

  3. initially sideslip to the left, then yaw to the right.

  4. initially roll to the right, then sideslip to the right and yaw to the right.

initially roll to the left, then sideslip to the left and yaw to the left.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The stalling speed of an aeroplane is increased by an increase in

  1. IAS.

  2. load factor.

  3. angle of attack.

  4. lift.

load factor.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Most autopilots can be disconnected

  1. only when 'interlock' logic circuits permit.

  2. only when the aircraft is properly trimmed.

  3. by any one of the three actions -- disengage switch, control column cut-out switch(es) or by flying control override.

  4. by either the disengage switch, or the control column cut-out switch(es).

by any one of the three actions -- disengage switch, control column cut-out switch(es) or by flying control override.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

The longitudinal stability of an aeroplane will be increased if

  1. the load is increased and the centre of gravity stays in the same position.

  2. the load is decreased and the centre of gravity stays in the same position.

  3. the centre of gravity is moved forward.

  4. the centre of gravity is moved towards the rear.

the centre of gravity is moved forward.

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

An aeroplane climbing out of ground effect (with angle of attack and power setting constant) will suffer reduced climb-out performance. This is a result of

  1. decreased lift

  2. decreased lift and increased induced drag

  3. an increase in total drag

  4. reduced wingtip vortices

decreased lift and increased induced drag

Back to question
Dyson Holland PPL Sample Exam No 1
PPL,Documentation,Dyson Holland

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7

Questions

The transfer of oxygen to the blood stream during respiration depends most directly upon

  1. the breathing rate

  2. the partial pressure of oxygen within the lungs

  3. the percentage of lung capacity achieved with each breath [depth of breathing]

  4. the volume of oxygen inhaled with each breath

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

If a pilot suspects that he/she is suffering the effects of hypoxia, the most appropriate remedy would be

  1. voluntarily increase the breathing rate to increase the oxygen uptake

  2. voluntarily increase the depth of breathing to induce more oxygen into the lungs

  3. voluntarily increase both the rate and depth of breathing

  4. use supplemental oxygen or descend immediately to a lower level

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is *not* normally a symptom of hypoxia?

  1. cyanosis

  2. a feeling of euphoria

  3. severe headache

  4. erratic behaviour

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

CAO 20.4.7 requries that supplemental oxygen be provided and used by the pilot at all times during flight above

  1. 20000 feet

  2. 10000 feet

  3. 14000 feet

  4. 8000 feet

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

One of the effects of hypoxia is a degradation of night vision. This effect begins at about

  1. 4000 feet

  2. 10000 feet

  3. 14000 feet

  4. 20000 feet

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Oxygen is transported around the body by

  1. haemoglobin

  2. white blood cells

  3. plasma

  4. the nervous system

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

A heavy smoker will suffer the effects of hypoxia at a lower altitude than a non-smoker. While flying at an altitude of 5000 feet, a heavy smoker could be experiencing the same degree of hypoxia as a non-smoker at

  1. 5000 feet

  2. 10000 feet

  3. 15000 feet

  4. 20000 feet

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hypoxia may be caused by

  1. flying with a head cold

  2. flying at an altitude where the partial pressure of oxygen is too low

  3. breathing too quickly and/or too deeply for the requirements of the body

  4. flying after a period of underwater diving

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Hypoxia is *always* accompanied by

  1. high temperature and vomiting

  2. dizziness

  3. profuse sweating

  4. a degradation in the performance of a pilot

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Cyanosis can be identified by

  1. rapid breathing

  2. a blue coloration of the fingernail beds and lips

  3. slurred speech

  4. difficult in maintaining balance

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7

Answers

The transfer of oxygen to the blood stream during respiration depends most directly upon

  1. the breathing rate

  2. the partial pressure of oxygen within the lungs

  3. the percentage of lung capacity achieved with each breath [depth of breathing]

  4. the volume of oxygen inhaled with each breath

the partial pressure of oxygen within the lungs

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 7
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

  1. voluntarily increase the breathing rate to increase the oxygen uptake

  2. voluntarily increase the depth of breathing to induce more oxygen into the lungs

  3. voluntarily increase both the rate and depth of breathing

  4. use supplemental oxygen or descend immediately to a lower level

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6

Questions

Lanes of entry are established to provide VFR aircraft with a:

  1. Traffic information service when entering or departing a general aviation control zone

  2. Discrete route for overflying a primary control zone

  3. Passage to and from a general aviation control zone without infringing controlled airspace

  4. Corridor in controlled airspace where ATC service is provide for entry to or departure from a general aviation control zone

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are ready to take-off at a non-controlled aerodrome from a runway 1000 metres in length. A twin-engine aircraft weighing over 2000 kg has just departed from the same runway. You should not commence your take-off until the other aircraft is at least:

  1. 1800 metres from your proposed take-off point

  2. 600 metres from your proposed take-off point

  3. 500 feet above ground level

  4. Crossing the upwind end of the runway

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are asked to fly a critically ill person to a major city hospital for urgent medical treatment. The patients doctor confirms that the flight is vital to save loss of life. You may declare the flight as a mercy flight only if:

  1. You will be unable to comply with applicable regulations and orders

  2. You have obtained clearance from the nearest airways operations unit

  3. The hospital is aware of the flight

  4. You have confirmed that the aeroplane is authorised to conduct aerial work or charter

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which condition applies to flights within Restricted Areas:

  1. Flights within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

  2. Flights by civil aircraft within these areas is not permitted

  3. Prior approval to enter these areas is not necessary, but flights must proceed in accordance with specific procedures

  4. Flights within these areas are not permitted under any circumstances

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is an example of a latent threat:

  1. Committing a check list to memory

  2. A poorly written checklist

  3. Engine failure in flight

  4. An encounter with rime ice

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A prohibited area is defined as airspace in which flights by civil aircraft is:

  1. Not permitted without prior approval

  2. Not permitted during daylight hours

  3. Not permitted between 10pm and 6am local time

  4. Not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When is the pilot in command reqiuired to inspect and test the aircrafts fuel system for the presence of water?:

  1. Before the first flight of the day and after each flight

  2. Before each flight

  3. Before and after each refuelling

  4. Before the first flight of the day and after each refuelling

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot who is running well behind schedule for the day, forgets to turn on the anti-icing system and consequently suffers severe airframe icing. This situation demonstrates:

  1. A latent threat leading to handling error

  2. A latent threat leading to a communication error

  3. An internal threat leading to a handling error

  4. An anticipated threat leading to a procedural error

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You and your friends are planning a shooting trip in a hired aircraft that you pilot as a Private flight. Which of the following conditions apply to the carriage of firearms:

  1. Unloaded firearms may be carried but the carriage of ammunition is prohibited by IATA (or OCAO) regulations

  2. No special conditions apply if the firearms are licensed and you obtain permission from the aircraft owner or operator

  3. Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

  4. Unloaded firearms and ammunition must be packed in accordance with IATA (or ICAO) technical instructions and carried in baggage compartment

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

One condition applying to the carriage of a stretcher patient in an aircraft is that:

  1. A mercy flight must be declared

  2. The patient must be accompanied by a nurse

  3. The stretcher must be secured to the aircraft

  4. The aircraft must be an ambulance aircraft

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the vicinity of an aerodrome within an ADIZ an aircraft is intercepted and is directed to land at the aerodrome. To show that this is understood and will be complied with the pilot of the intercepted aircraft should, by day:

  1. Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft

  2. Rock the aircrafts wings and follow the intercepting aircraft

  3. Raise the aircraft landing gear while passing over the runway at a height of between 1000 and 2000 ft. and circle the aerodrome

  4. Activate the aircrafts transponder identification function

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following passenger safety precautions must be taken while refuelling an aircraft with Avgas:

  1. Passengers may remain on board but the a/c must be tied down

  2. Passengers shall not embark or disembark

  3. The cabin doors must be kept shut

  4. Passengers shall not remain on board

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Figure 3 (page 6, Work Booklet). Given the following details: * Runway = 05/23 * Take-off distance available = 1300 metres * Surface = Long Wet Grass * Slope = Level * Pressure height = 3000 ft * Wind = 230/10 kts * Temperature = +15 Degrees C * Take-off Weight = 1055 kg The Take-off distance required is closest to:

  1. 1030 metres

  2. 750 metres

  3. 1180 metres

  4. 830 metres

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to loading system CHARLIE (pages 14, 15 and 16, Work Booklet). Given: * Aircraft empty weight = 689 kg * Empty aircraft index units = 19522 * Oil = 7 kg * Row 1 (pilot and passenger) = 110 kg * Baggage (baggage compartment) = 75 kg * Fuel (Litres) = 140 Lts The maximum passenger weight, in kg, that may be carried in Row 2 at take-off is closest to:

  1. 110 kg

  2. 154 kg

  3. 135 kg

  4. 94 kg

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to loading system ALPHA (pages 10 and 11, Work Booklet). Given: * Basic index units = -200 * Basic empty weight = 1015 kg * Row 1 (pilot and passenger) = 160 kg * Row (forward facing passengers) = 145 kg * Nose baggage compartment = 45 kg * Rear baggage compartment = 45 kg The maximum weight of fuel, in kg, that may be carried at take-off is closest to:

  1. 223 kg

  2. 252 kg

  3. 210 kg

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given: * Pressure height = 6000 feet * OAT = +20 degrees C * CAS = 120 kts Determine the TAS:

  1. 135 kts

  2. 125 kts

  3. 130 kts

  4. 106 kts

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You plan to conduct a PVT VFR flight by day from TOWNSVILLE (QLD) (1915S 14646E) to SPRINGCREEK (QLD) (1838S 14433E) to INGHAM (QLD) (1840S 14609E). For the total flight, which ARFOR are required:

  1. 45

  2. 44

  3. 40

  4. 43

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (TOWNSVILLE) WAC 3219 (page 27) Work Booklet). What is the position (Latitude and Longitude) of ROLLINGSTONE (approximately 25 nm NW of Townsville):

  1. 19 03S 146 23E

  2. 19 30S 146 52E

  3. 18 58S 146 23E

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (TOWNSVILLE) WAC 3219 (page 27, Work Booklet). At 2342 UTC you set course over ROLLINGSTONE (approximately 25 nm NW of TOWNSVILLE), to track direct to SPRING CREEK (1838S 14433E). Hdg 270 (M) is maintained until you pinpoint your position over Mt Lyall (south of Camel Creek Landing Area) at 0003 UTC. The HDG required to track direct to SPRING CREEK from this position is closest to:

  1. 248 degrees

  2. 292 degrees

  3. 286 degrees

  4. 281 degrees

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The beginning of daylight in UTC at FORREST WA (3050S 12807E) on the 7th February is closest to:

  1. 062035 UTC

  2. 062107 UTC

  3. 072035 UTC

  4. 070507 UTC

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer (BOURKE) WAC 3356 (page 30, Work Booklet). You plan to fly from NARRABRI (YNBR) (3019S 14950E) direct to ST GEORGE (YSGE) 2803S 14836E). To avoid clouds after departing YNBR you divert left of planned TR along the YNBR WALGETT railway line. At WEE WAA township (approximately 20 nm WNW YNBR) you decide to track direct to YSGE. The ARFOR wind for your cruise level is 100/20 kts, and your TAS is 140 kts. The HDG (M) to steer to YSGE is closest to:

  1. 330 degrees

  2. 322 degrees

  3. 348 degrees

  4. 338 degrees
