Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The following message was issued during a pre-flight briefing: METAR YMLT 2300UTC 0001 25004KT 9999 SCT025 SCT035 18/12 Q 1020. The message is:

  1. An aerodrome forecast

  2. A routine aerodrome meteorological report

  3. An aerodrome report issued when conditions have deteriorated below specified limits

  4. A trend type forecast

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the take-off configuration with the landing gear extended an aeroplane with a maximum take-off weight not exceeding 5700 kg shall have the ability to achieve a minimum climb gradient of:

  1. 4.5%

  2. 6.0%

  3. 1.0%

  4. 3.2%

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Soon after lifting off from the runway at the take-off safety speed an aeroplane experiences a sudden loss of both lift and airspeed. This could be caused by:

  1. Climbing out of ground effect

  2. A sudden decrease in headwind component

  3. A sudden increase in headwind component

  4. Entering ground effect

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given the following: Beginning of daylight HAY (3432S 14450E) is 0615LMT; End of daylight AYERS ROCK (2515S 13059E) is 1715LMT; Planned landing time is 30 minutes before end of daylight. What is the approximate time available, for a VFR flight from HAY to AYERS ROCK:

  1. 11 hr 25 min

  2. 11 hr 55 min

  3. 12 hr 35 min

  4. 11 hr 00 min

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given: W/V = 250(M)/30 kts. Runways available = 03/21 and 09/27. Which runway has the greatest headwind component for landing:

  1. 09

  2. 21

  3. 03

  4. 27

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

This question relates to a VFR flight by day proceeding more than 50 nm from the departure aerodrome. The maximum permitted crosswind component in the aeroplanes flight manual is 15 kt. Which of the following weather conditions forecast for the destination at the ETA would necessitate the provision of an alternate:

  1. Visibility of 8 km

  2. 3/8 cloud with a 1400 ft ceiling

  3. 15 kt steady crosswind

  4. 30% probability of visibility restricted to 7 km

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

What is the approximate time available for a VFR flight on 5th January, from PORT HEDLAND (YPPD) WA (2023S 11838E) to CEDUNA (YCDU) SA (3208S 13343E) if: The beginning of daylight YPPD is 0500 LMT. The end of daylight YCUD is 1938 LMT. You plan to land YCUD 20 minutes before the end of daylight:

  1. 10 hr

  2. 14 hr 15 min

  3. 13 hr 15 min

  4. 12 hr 45 min

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Given: W/V = 050(M)/30 kts. What crosswind component would you expect for a landing on runway 35:

  1. 26 kt from the left

  2. 15 kt from the left

  3. 26 kt from the right

  4. 15 kt from the right

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer figure 31 (page 36, Work Booklet). Where "D" = 30 nm, Track error = 6 degrees. If a constant HDG has been maintained since 0300 (at "A") and the pilot alters HDG 9 degrees left at time 0318 (at "B"), what time should the pilot expect to intercept track:

  1. 0354

  2. 0412

  3. 0336

  4. 0327

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer figure 34 (page 37, Work Booklet). Where D1 = 60nm, D2 = 20 nm. The aeroplane is estimated to arrive at C at 0215. It is on time at A but 3 minutes late at check point X. The revised estimate C is:

  1. 0219

  2. 0218

  3. 0221

  4. 0216

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer: ARFOR/TAF 2 (page 46 Work Booklet). Depart YSWG 0200 YSCB arrive YMER 0350. The freezing level and visibility forecast for the YSWG-YSCB route segment of the flight is:

  1. Freezing level 12000 ft, visibility 10 km or more reducing to 5000M in showers/rain and reducing to 3000M in thunderstorms

  2. Freezing level 12000 ft, visibility 5000M reducing to 3000M in thunderstorms

  3. Freezing level 9500 ft, visibility 10 km or more reducing to 5000M in showers/rain and reducing to 3000M in thunderstorms

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer: ARFOR/TAF 4 (page 48 Work Booklet). Depart YSWG 0000 YSCB arrive YMER 0200. The forecast wind velocity for arrival in the circuit area YMER is:

  1. 260 Deg (T), 25 kts

  2. 290 Deg (M), 15 kts

  3. 290 Deg (T), 15 kts

  4. 280 Deg (T), 10 kts

  5. 260 Deg (M), 25 kts

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

What effect does an increase in angle of bank have on stalling speed:

  1. Stalling speed increases

  2. Stalling speed decreases

  3. Stalling speed remains the same

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In a climb from level flight, the altimeter reading remains unchanged. A likely cause is a blocked:

  1. Vacuum pump

  2. Static vent

  3. Pitot tube

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The stalling speed of an aeroplane is decreased by an increase in:

  1. Headwind component

  2. Angle of bank

  3. Load factor

  4. Power

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

After being distracted by difficult radio communications, you deviate from your assigned level in controlled airspace. A countermeasure which would most likely have avoided this situation would be called:

  1. a planning countermeasure requiring the carriage of a second radio

  2. an execution countermeasure requiring you manage the workload

  3. a review countermeasure that would have allowed you to ignore the height and concentrate on the radio

  4. a procedural countermeasure that would have dealt with the radio problem

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. Col

  2. High

  3. Ridge

  4. Low

  4. A review countermeasure

  4. Spreads back over most of the aerofoil section

Which of the following conditions would give the best indication of an abnormally low oil level:

  2. High oil temperature and low oil pressure

  3. Low oil temperature and low oil pressure

  4. Low oil temperature and high oil pressure

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6

  1. A reduction in gross weigh

  2. An increase in air density

  3. A reduction in power

  4. An increase in altitude

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following effects will result from moving the centre of gravity aft:

  1. The stalling angle will increase

  2. The indicated stalling speed will increase

  3. Greater elevator deflection is required to achieve a given change in attitude

  4. Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

  1. The speed requiring minimum power

  2. The speed requiring minimum thrust

  3. The speed which gives the best lift-drag ratio

  4. The lowest possible speed

  1. Increase stalling angle

  3. Decrease the rate of descent

  3. High rate of turn

  4. Nose attitude

  1. Range remains the same, if angle of attack is maintained

  2. Range increases, if IAS is reduced

  3. Range remains the same, if IAS is maintained

  4. Range reduces, if angle of attack is maintained

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Consider the turn performance of two aeroplanes with different gross weights. If they both execute turns at the same IAS, altitude, and bank, the heavier aeroplane will have:

  1. A greater turn rate than the lighter aeroplane

  2. The same turn rate and radius as the lighter aeroplane

  3. A greater turn radius than the lighter aeroplane

  4. A lower turn rate and greater turn radius than the lighter aeroplane

Answer

PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following would indicate a sudden decrease in headwind component during a descent:

  1. A decrease in indicated airspeed and an increase in rate of descent

  2. An increase in indicated airspeed and decrease in rate of descent

  3. An increase in both indicated airspeed and rate of descent

  4. A decrease in both indicated airspeed and rate of descent

Answer

  1. IAS will decrease; flight path will be steeper

  2. IAS will increase; flight path will be shallower

  3. IAS will decrease; flight path will be shallower

  4. IAS will increase; flight path will be steeper

  1. Decrease then increase

  2. Increase then decrease

  3. Decrease continually

  4. Increase continually

  4. They contain ephedrine, which may cause vision problems when flying at altitude

  1. A procedural error

  2. A handling error

  3. A communication error

  4. A planning error

Answer
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6

Answers

Lanes of entry are established to provide VFR aircraft with a:

  1. Traffic information service when entering or departing a general aviation control zone

  2. Discrete route for overflying a primary control zone

  3. Passage to and from a general aviation control zone without infringing controlled airspace

  4. Corridor in controlled airspace where ATC service is provide for entry to or departure from a general aviation control zone

Passage to and from a general aviation control zone without infringing controlled airspace

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are ready to take-off at a non-controlled aerodrome from a runway 1000 metres in length. A twin-engine aircraft weighing over 2000 kg has just departed from the same runway. You should not commence your take-off until the other aircraft is at least:

  1. 1800 metres from your proposed take-off point

  2. 600 metres from your proposed take-off point

  3. 500 feet above ground level

  4. Crossing the upwind end of the runway

Crossing the upwind end of the runway

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are asked to fly a critically ill person to a major city hospital for urgent medical treatment. The patients doctor confirms that the flight is vital to save loss of life. You may declare the flight as a mercy flight only if:

  1. You will be unable to comply with applicable regulations and orders

  2. You have obtained clearance from the nearest airways operations unit

  3. The hospital is aware of the flight

  4. You have confirmed that the aeroplane is authorised to conduct aerial work or charter

You will be unable to comply with applicable regulations and orders

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which condition applies to flights within Restricted Areas:

  1. Flights within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

  2. Flights by civil aircraft within these areas is not permitted

  3. Prior approval to enter these areas is not necessary, but flights must proceed in accordance with specific procedures

  4. Flights within these areas are not permitted under any circumstances

Flights within these areas are normally only permitted outside the hours of activity or with prior approval

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following is an example of a latent threat:

  1. Committing a check list to memory

  2. A poorly written checklist

  3. Engine failure in flight

  4. An encounter with rime ice

A poorly written checklist

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A prohibited area is defined as airspace in which flights by civil aircraft is:

  1. Not permitted without prior approval

  2. Not permitted during daylight hours

  3. Not permitted between 10pm and 6am local time

  4. Not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

Not permitted at any time and under any circumstances

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When is the pilot in command reqiuired to inspect and test the aircrafts fuel system for the presence of water?:

  1. Before the first flight of the day and after each flight

  2. Before each flight

  3. Before and after each refuelling

  4. Before the first flight of the day and after each refuelling

Before the first flight of the day and after each refuelling

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot who is running well behind schedule for the day, forgets to turn on the anti-icing system and consequently suffers severe airframe icing. This situation demonstrates:

  1. A latent threat leading to handling error

  2. A latent threat leading to a communication error

  3. An internal threat leading to a handling error

  4. An anticipated threat leading to a procedural error

A latent threat leading to handling error

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You and your friends are planning a shooting trip in a hired aircraft that you pilot as a Private flight. Which of the following conditions apply to the carriage of firearms:

  1. Unloaded firearms may be carried but the carriage of ammunition is prohibited by IATA (or OCAO) regulations

  2. No special conditions apply if the firearms are licensed and you obtain permission from the aircraft owner or operator

  3. Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

  4. Unloaded firearms and ammunition must be packed in accordance with IATA (or ICAO) technical instructions and carried in baggage compartment

Specific written permission of CASA is required for the carriage of firearms and ammunition

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

One condition applying to the carriage of a stretcher patient in an aircraft is that:

  1. A mercy flight must be declared

  2. The patient must be accompanied by a nurse

  3. The stretcher must be secured to the aircraft

  4. The aircraft must be an ambulance aircraft

The stretcher must be secured to the aircraft

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

In the vicinity of an aerodrome within an ADIZ an aircraft is intercepted and is directed to land at the aerodrome. To show that this is understood and will be complied with the pilot of the intercepted aircraft should, by day:

  1. Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft

  2. Rock the aircrafts wings and follow the intercepting aircraft

  3. Raise the aircraft landing gear while passing over the runway at a height of between 1000 and 2000 ft. and circle the aerodrome

  4. Activate the aircrafts transponder identification function

Lower the aircrafts landing gear and follow the intercepting aircraft

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. Passengers may remain on board but the a/c must be tied down

  2. Passengers shall not embark or disembark

  3. The cabin doors must be kept shut

  4. Passengers shall not remain on board

Passengers shall not remain on board

Back to question

PPL,Curtis Aviation

1030 metres

6.0%

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  1. Climbing out of ground effect

  2. A sudden decrease in headwind component

  3. A sudden increase in headwind component

  4. Entering ground effect

A sudden decrease in headwind component

11 hr 25 min

What effect does an increase in angle of bank have on stalling speed:

  1. Stalling speed increases

  2. Stalling speed decreases

Stalling speed increases

  1. Vacuum pump

  2. Static vent

  3. Pitot tube

Static vent

The stalling speed of an aeroplane is decreased by an increase in:

  1. Headwind component

  2. Angle of bank

  3. Load factor

  4. Power

Power

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

After being distracted by difficult radio communications, you deviate from your assigned level in controlled airspace. A countermeasure which would most likely have avoided this situation would be called:

  1. a planning countermeasure requiring the carriage of a second radio

  2. an execution countermeasure requiring you manage the workload

  3. a review countermeasure that would have allowed you to ignore the height and concentrate on the radio

  4. a procedural countermeasure that would have dealt with the radio problem

an execution countermeasure requiring you manage the workload

Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Fig 48 (page 44 Work Booklet). The pressure pattern about the point C (in western Queensland) is known as a:

  1. Col

  2. High

  3. Ridge

  4. Low

Col

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot who resorts to assertiveness to address a problem in flight is employing:

  1. An execution countermeasure

  2. A planning countermeasure

  3. A handling countermeasure

  4. A review countermeasure

A review countermeasure

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A characteristic of Rime ice, which may be hazardous to aircraft, is that it:

  1. Is the most difficult type to remove

  2. May block the pitot tube

  3. Is likely to lock the control surfaces

  4. Spreads back over most of the aerofoil section

May block the pitot tube

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Fig 49 (page 44 Work Booklet) The line P R (west of Townsville) indicates the position of a:

  1. Ridge

  2. Front

  3. Trough

  4. Line of equal pressure

Trough

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Flying conditions above a layer of small cumulus clouds are likely to be:

  1. Smooth but with strong updraughts

  2. Smooth

  3. Very Turbulent

  4. Bumpy

Smooth

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following conditions would give the best indication of an abnormally low oil level:

  1. High oil temperature and high oil pressure

  2. High oil temperature and low oil pressure

  3. Low oil temperature and low oil pressure

  4. Low oil temperature and high oil pressure

High oil temperature and low oil pressure

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Select the variable which would reduce the indicated stalling speed of an aeroplane in level flight:

  1. A reduction in gross weigh

  2. An increase in air density

  3. A reduction in power

  4. An increase in altitude

A reduction in gross weigh

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following effects will result from moving the centre of gravity aft:

  1. The stalling angle will increase

  2. The indicated stalling speed will increase

  3. Greater elevator deflection is required to achieve a given change in attitude

  4. Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

Longitudinal stability will deteriorate

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

At which IAS should a piston-engine aeroplane be flown to achieve maximum endurance in level flight:

  1. The speed requiring minimum power

  2. The speed requiring minimum thrust

  3. The speed which gives the best lift-drag ratio

  4. The lowest possible speed

The speed requiring minimum power

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

One effect of fully lowering plain flaps is to:

  1. Increase stalling angle

  2. Increase the climb angle

  3. Decrease the rate of descent

  4. Decrease the stall speed

Decrease the stall speed

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following indications would positively confirm that an aeroplane is established in a spin and not in a spiral dive:

  1. Increasing airspeed

  2. Low airspeed

  3. High rate of turn

  4. Nose attitude

Low airspeed

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which statement correctly describes the effect of an increase in weight on the maximum glide range in still air:

  1. Range remains the same, if angle of attack is maintained

  2. Range increases, if IAS is reduced

  3. Range remains the same, if IAS is maintained

  4. Range reduces, if angle of attack is maintained

Range remains the same, if angle of attack is maintained

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Consider the turn performance of two aeroplanes with different gross weights. If they both execute turns at the same IAS, altitude, and bank, the heavier aeroplane will have:

  1. A greater turn rate than the lighter aeroplane

  2. The same turn rate and radius as the lighter aeroplane

  3. A greater turn radius than the lighter aeroplane

  4. A lower turn rate and greater turn radius than the lighter aeroplane

The same turn rate and radius as the lighter aeroplane

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following would indicate a sudden decrease in headwind component during a descent:

  1. A decrease in indicated airspeed and an increase in rate of descent

  2. An increase in indicated airspeed and decrease in rate of descent

  3. An increase in both indicated airspeed and rate of descent

  4. A decrease in both indicated airspeed and rate of descent

A decrease in indicated airspeed and an increase in rate of descent

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An aeroplane takes off in calm conditions and climbs through a wind shear where it encounters a strong tail wind. What initial effect will this change in W/V have on IAS and flight path:

  1. IAS will decrease; flight path will be steeper

  2. IAS will increase; flight path will be shallower

  3. IAS will decrease; flight path will be shallower

  4. IAS will increase; flight path will be steeper

IAS will decrease; flight path will be shallower

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

During a climb at maximum power, the IAS is progressively reduced from the maximum rate of climb speed to the stalling speed. The effect on the angle of climb is that it will:

  1. Decrease then increase

  2. Increase then decrease

  3. Decrease continually

  4. Increase continually

Increase then decrease

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

An increase in which of the parameters listed below will always in an increase in Induced drag:

  1. L/D ratio

  2. Angle of attack

  3. Aspect ratio

  4. IAS

Angle of attack

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When is turbulence associated with thunderstorm most severe:

  1. During the mature stage

  2. During the dissipating stage

  3. During the growing or cumulus stage

  4. Just before the mature stage

During the mature stage

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The cloud type which is indicative of mountain waves, when seen above a mountain range is:

  1. Cirrus

  2. Lenticular

  3. Stratus

  4. Cumulus

Lenticular

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which hazard to flight is most likely in the rotor zone associated with mountain waves:

  1. Icing

  2. Line squall

  3. Severe turbulence

  4. Hail

Severe turbulence

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Squall lines are most often associated with:

  1. Mountain waves

  2. Heavy continuous rain

  3. Thunderstorms

  4. Sea breezes

Thunderstorms

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

When mountain waves exist, rotor zones may occur and are most commonly found:

  1. Beneath the crests of the waves

  2. Just above the crests of the waves

  3. In the troughs of the waves

  4. Directly above the mountain range

Beneath the crests of the waves

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The onset of a light wind during the formation of a radiation inversion will cause the inversion to:

  1. Increase in depth

  2. Become stronger

  3. Decrease in depth

  4. Dissipate

Increase in depth

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

What is the major hazard to a landing aircraft associated with a microburst:

  1. Reduced visibility

  2. Heavy precipitation

  3. Wind shear and updraughts

  4. Wind shear and down draughts

Wind shear and down draughts

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following conditions will cause hypoxia:

  1. When the ratio of helium to nitrogen pressure at high altitudes increases

  2. When carbon dioxide levels in the lungs are lower than normal

  3. When the partial pressure of oxygen at high altitude decreases

  4. When the carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is excessive

  5. When nitrogen content of the air at high altitude decreases

When the partial pressure of oxygen at high altitude decreases

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following statements is true for many types of cold cures:

  1. They may have side effects which strain the heart when flying at altitude

  2. They may inflame the Eustachian tube, possibly leading to middle ear infections

  3. They contain anti-histamine, which may cause drowsiness and impair performance

  4. They contain ephedrine, which may cause vision problems when flying at altitude

They contain anti-histamine, which may cause drowsiness and impair performance

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Which of the following would be an example of an unexpected environmental threat:

  1. Take-off from an aerodrome with a high density altitude

  2. Operation from an aerodrome with a high density altitude

  3. Operating at an unfamiliar aerodrome

  4. An encounter with hoar frost on descent in clear air

An encounter with hoar frost on descent in clear air

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Responsibilities of Flight Service towards a SARTIME aircraft operating B050 would include the:

  1. Provision of traffic separation

  2. Receipt of SARWATCH cancellation

  3. Receipt of position reports

  4. Provision of traffic information

Receipt of SARWATCH cancellation

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot who has failed to apply carburettor heat during a glide has committed:

  1. Handling error

  2. Procedural error

  3. Communication error

  4. Execution countermeasure

Handling error

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

The cloud type most likely to be associated with heavy continuous rain is:

  1. Stratus

  2. Cumulonimbus

  3. Nimbostratus

  4. Altostratus

Nimbostratus

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

You are planning a flight in a four (4) seater dual control aeroplane with the following passengers: 2 adults and 2 children aged 5 and 8 weighing 20 kg and 40 kg respectively. Assuming aircraft weight limitations will not be exceeded, which of the following limitations apply and why:

  1. Four passengers may be carried because the children weigh less than 77 kg and can occupy one seat

  2. Only two passengers may be carried because a passenger shall not occupy a control seat

  3. Only three passengers may be carried because there are only four seats

Four passengers may be carried because the children weigh less than 77 kg and can occupy one seat

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

Refer to Fig 48 (page 44 Work Booklet). The line J K (just to the east of Melbourne) indicates the position of a:

  1. Warm Front

  2. Stationary Front

  3. Cold Front

  4. Occluded Front

Cold Front

Back to question
Curtis Aviation Private Pilot Licence Trial Examination 6
PPL,Curtis Aviation

A pilot who has planned to cruise at 5500 feet is given an initial clearance to climb to 4500 feet in CTA. Because of poor radio reception, he reads back 5500 feet. This is an example of:

  1. A procedural error

  2. A handling error

  3. A communication error

  4. A planning error

A communication error

Back to question

PPL,Curtis Aviation

  3. More left rudder to centre the ball

  4. More left aileron to centre the ball

  1. Pull back firmly to stop the descent

  2. Level the wings, reduce power, pull out of dive

  3. Reduce power to idle, pull nose up, roll wings level

  4. Apply spin recovery technique

  4. Rate of climb will increase, but angle will decrease

  1. create more drag to oppose the thrust

  2. improve forward visibility

  3. increase the lift/drag ratio

  4. raise the stall speed

  2. commence an orbit and rejoin base

  3. overshoot final approach before rejoining final to provide extra space

  4. reduce your speed below the normal approach speed

  2. a problem with your squelch adjustment

  3. normal interference as a result of solar radiation flares

  4. the electrical system in the aircraft is failing

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If your engine fails shortly after take-off while on the upwind leg you should:

  1. execute an immediate turn back towards the runway you departed from

  2. lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed and choose a landing site that requires minimal turning

  3. raise the nose to extend your glide performance and select a field within range

  4. transmit a MAYDAY call immediately with details of your situation then decide upon a plan of action

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are on a taxiway and another aircraft approaches you head on. You must:

  1. move to the right and pass with care

  2. move only if you are the smaller aircraft

  3. move to the left and pass with care

  4. hold your position and flash your taxi light

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The runway is occupied and you are required to go-around. The most correct sequence of actions is:

  1. Raise the nose to a climbing attitude, apply full power, retract the flaps

  2. Retract the flaps, raising the nose with power application

  3. Raise the nose to a climbing attitude, retract the flaps to reduce drag, apply full power

  4. Apply full power while raising the nose to a climbing attitude, raising the flap slowly when climbing

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Compared to an approach at full flap, an approach with no flaps at the same IAS will require:

  1. a lower nose attitude and steeper approach path

  2. a lower nose attitude and flatter approach path

  3. a higher nose attitude and steeper approach path

  4. a higher nose attitude and flatter approach path

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. started to turn towards the runway exit

  2. stopped on the runway

  3. vacated the runway and is taxiing away

  4. passed beyond where you feel your aircraft will be airborne

airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. Low power setting and falling nose attitude

  2. Low airspeed, sluggish controls, high nose attitude

  3. Low nose attitude at higher than normal power setting

  4. Aircraft tending to want to drop a wing at high power

  4. You are unsure of your position with 2 hours fuel remaining

  1. the required aircraft attitude is maintained when the controls are released

  2. the wings are level

  3. the trim position indicator is in the neutral position

  4. the aircraft is maintaining attitude

airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. power off, wings level, lower the nose

  2. add full power rapidly

  3. reduce power and raise the nose

  4. add power and lower the nose

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. the aerodrome is completely unserviceable

  2. gliding operations are in progress

  3. unsealed surfaces should not be used

  4. CTAF procedures are in force

  1. 1000 ft AGL

  2. 1300 ft AMSL

  3. 1000 ft AMSL

  4. 1500 ft AGL

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. The propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder and vertical fin

  2. Engine torque

  3. The coriolis effect

  4. Both slipstream and torque as listed above

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. zero feet

  2. height above sea level

  3. height in a standard atmosphere

  4. 250 feet

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. It is dependant on the amount you drink, you must not return a blood alcohol reading of more than 0.02

  2. 1:00am Saturday and ensure you are not affected by alcohol at the time of your flight

  3. You must not drink the day before your flight

  4. 11:00pm Friday and ensure you are not affected by alcohol at the time of your flight

airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

  1. that are larger than your aircraft

  2. on your right and those exiting a runway

  3. on your right or any aircraft displaying strobes

  4. on your left and those exiting a runway

  4. the minimum IAS at which flaps may be retracted

  3. 70 KIAS

  4. 55 KIAS

55 KIAS

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

What effect will turning have on climb performance?

  1. Both angle and rate of climb will decrease

  2. Angle of climb will increase, but rate will decrease

  3. Both angle and rate of climb will increase

  4. Rate of climb will increase, but angle will decrease

Both angle and rate of climb will decrease

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If an aircraft has a stall speed (Vs) of 40 KIAS in level flight the stall speed during a level 60 degree angle of bank turn with all other variables remaining unchanged would be closest to:

  1. 45 KIAS

  2. 80 KIAS

  3. 70 KIAS

  4. 55 KIAS

55 KIAS

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Under what circumstances is carburettor ice likely to form?

  1. Temperatures below 25 degrees C at low power

  2. In cold and moist air at low power

  3. Only below a temperature of 0 degrees C

  4. Only if the aircraft is flying in rain

Temperatures below 25 degrees C at low power

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Which of the following instruments might be affected by a vacuum system failure?

  1. Altimeter

  2. Attitude Indicator

  3. Vertical Speed Indicator

  4. Airspeed Indicator

Attitude Indicator

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Which of the following would result in a decreased rate of climb?

  1. An increase in headwind component

  2. A reduction in engine power

  3. A reduction in weight

  4. A decrease in headwind component

A reduction in engine power

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If a fuel gauge indicates 12 US gallons in a fuel tank and it is properly calibrated you would expect to see how many litres on your dipstick?

  1. 54 litres

  2. 48 litres

  3. 45 litres

  4. 36 litres

45 litres

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If the elevator control is abruptly pulled fully aft at cruise speed - how does the aeroplane respond?

  1. A stall will occur at a higher speed than normal

  2. A stall will occur at a lower speed than normal

  3. A stall will occur at the same speed but at a higher angle of attack than normal

  4. The aircraft will not stall as it's flying faster than Vs, the aircraft climbs rapidly

A stall will occur at a higher speed than normal

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

In what circumstance would it be most appropriate to transmit a PAN call?

  1. One of your passengers just threw up on the back seat!

  2. Your engine has failed and you are planning on ditching in to water

  3. You are experiencing a rough running engine but have enough power to maintain level flight

  4. Your vertical speed indicator has failed in flight

You are experiencing a rough running engine but have enough power to maintain level flight

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Unless assigned a discrete code by ATC for your transponder you should squawk which code when flying VFR?

  1. 1200

  2. 7700

  3. 2100

  4. 7600

1200

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Which of the following is a VHF frequency?

  1. 281 KHz

  2. 12.010 MHz

  3. 13075 MHz

  4. 124.55 MHz

124.55 MHz

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Which factor listed below has no impact on the stalling IAS of an aeroplane?

  1. Weight

  2. Wind

  3. Power setting

  4. Loading (CG)

Wind

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

During a glide approach at the recommended IAS for your aeroplane type if you were to raise the nose and slow the aeroplane in nil wind your gliding range would:

  1. decrease and a steeper approach path would be flown

  2. remain the same and approach path would be relatively unchanged

  3. increase and a flatter approach path would be flown

  4. remain the same however the slower speed would ensure the aeroplane remained airborne longer

decrease and a steeper approach path would be flown

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When climbing, if one magneto was unserviceable, the effect on climb performance would be:

  1. Reduced angle of climb, rate unaffected

  2. Reduced rate of climb, angle unaffected

  3. Reduced rate and angle of climb

  4. No effect

Reduced rate and angle of climb

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

VNE (Velocity Never Exceed) is indicated on an airspeed indicator by:

  1. the end of the green arc

  2. not indicated - only found in flight manual or on cockpit placard

  3. the end of the yellow arc

  4. a red line

a red line

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When slowing down on downwind in the circuit to follow a slower aircraft flap may be applied. This is primarily to:

  1. create more drag to oppose the thrust

  2. improve forward visibility

  3. increase the lift/drag ratio

  4. raise the stall speed

improve forward visibility

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are in the circuit flying the base leg. You find yourself too close to an aircraft also on the base leg. The best course of action is to:

  1. go-around from the base leg

  2. commence an orbit and rejoin base

  3. overshoot final approach before rejoining final to provide extra space

  4. reduce your speed below the normal approach speed

go-around from the base leg

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If an aircraft had a fuel consumption for planning purposes of 35 litres per hour what is the minimum flight fuel required for a flight of 1 hour and 15 minutes including the mandatory fuel reserve?

  1. 44 litres

  2. 62 litres

  3. 70 litres

  4. 79 litres

70 litres

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

An aircraft must be established on a straight final approach path by:

  1. at a distance determined to be sensible by the pilot

  2. 500 feet AGL

  3. 500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

  4. there is no restriction

500 feet AGL

  1. ERSA

  2. AIP-MAP

  3. CAO

  4. VFG

ERSA

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When must the flying controls be checked for full, free and correct movement on an aircraft?

  1. Before engine start

  2. During the take-off roll

  3. After engine start

  4. Immediately before take-off

Immediately before take-off

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are listening to a radio transmission and hear the first part clearly, while the second part is a loud squealing noise. The most likely cause is:

  1. two stations transmitting at the same time

  2. a problem with your squelch adjustment

  3. normal interference as a result of solar radiation flares

  4. the electrical system in the aircraft is failing

two stations transmitting at the same time

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If your engine fails shortly after take-off while on the upwind leg you should:

  1. execute an immediate turn back towards the runway you departed from

  2. lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed and choose a landing site that requires minimal turning

  3. raise the nose to extend your glide performance and select a field within range

  4. transmit a MAYDAY call immediately with details of your situation then decide upon a plan of action

lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed and choose a landing site that requires minimal turning

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are on a taxiway and another aircraft approaches you head on. You must:

  1. move to the right and pass with care

  2. move only if you are the smaller aircraft

  3. move to the left and pass with care

  4. hold your position and flash your taxi light

move to the right and pass with care

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The runway is occupied and you are required to go-around. The most correct sequence of actions is:

  1. Raise the nose to a climbing attitude, apply full power, retract the flaps

  2. Retract the flaps, raising the nose with power application

  3. Raise the nose to a climbing attitude, retract the flaps to reduce drag, apply full power

  4. Apply full power while raising the nose to a climbing attitude, raising the flap slowly when climbing

Apply full power while raising the nose to a climbing attitude, raising the flap slowly when climbing

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Compared to an approach at full flap, an approach with no flaps at the same IAS will require:

  1. a lower nose attitude and steeper approach path

  2. a lower nose attitude and flatter approach path

  3. a higher nose attitude and steeper approach path

  4. a higher nose attitude and flatter approach path

a higher nose attitude and flatter approach path

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are lining up behind another aircraft that has just landed on the runway you are planning to take-off from. You must not commence your take-off roll until the landing aircraft has:

  1. started to turn towards the runway exit

  2. stopped on the runway

  3. vacated the runway and is taxiing away

  4. passed beyond where you feel your aircraft will be airborne

vacated the runway and is taxiing away

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

During an approach to land what would the symptoms of an impending stall be?

  1. Low power setting and falling nose attitude

  2. Low airspeed, sluggish controls, high nose attitude

  3. Low nose attitude at higher than normal power setting

  4. Aircraft tending to want to drop a wing at high power

Low airspeed, sluggish controls, high nose attitude

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

In which of the following situations would you transmit a MAYDAY call?

  1. There is a sick passenger on board who asks you to land as soon as possible

  2. A bird strikes your aircraft causing minor damage

  3. The engine has failed in flight

  4. You are unsure of your position with 2 hours fuel remaining

The engine has failed in flight

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

A pilot can establish that the elevator is correctly trimmed when:

  1. the required aircraft attitude is maintained when the controls are released

  2. the wings are level

  3. the trim position indicator is in the neutral position

  4. the aircraft is maintaining attitude

the required aircraft attitude is maintained when the controls are released

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Airspeed has been allowed to drop significantly such that the pilot suspects a stall may be imminent. The immediate actions to rectify this situation are:

  1. power off, wings level, lower the nose

  2. add full power rapidly

  3. reduce power and raise the nose

  4. add power and lower the nose

add power and lower the nose

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

At the windsock of an aerodrome a double cross marker is displayed, this means:

  1. the aerodrome is completely unserviceable

  2. gliding operations are in progress

  3. unsealed surfaces should not be used

  4. CTAF procedures are in force

gliding operations are in progress

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The circuit height at an aerodrome for a light piston engine aircraft by convention is:

  1. 1000 ft AGL

  2. 1300 ft AMSL

  3. 1000 ft AMSL

  4. 1500 ft AGL

1000 ft AGL

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

During take-off in no wind it is necessary to apply right rudder in most aircraft to maintain a straight path on the runway - why is this?

  1. The propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder and vertical fin

  2. Engine torque

  3. The coriolis effect

  4. Both slipstream and torque as listed above

Both slipstream and torque as listed above

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When setting QNH on the altimeter while parked on an aerodrome the altimeter will read:

  1. zero feet

  2. height above sea level

  3. height in a standard atmosphere

  4. 250 feet

height above sea level

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are heading for a night out at the pub on Friday. You have a flying lesson booked for 7am Saturday morning, when must you stop drinking alcohol?

  1. It is dependant on the amount you drink, you must not return a blood alcohol reading of more than 0.02

  2. 1:00am Saturday and ensure you are not affected by alcohol at the time of your flight

  3. You must not drink the day before your flight

  4. 11:00pm Friday and ensure you are not affected by alcohol at the time of your flight

11:00pm Friday and ensure you are not affected by alcohol at the time of your flight

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When taxiing you must always give way to aircraft

  1. that are larger than your aircraft

  2. on your right and those exiting a runway

  3. on your right or any aircraft displaying strobes

  4. on your left and those exiting a runway

on your right and those exiting a runway

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The high speed end of the white arc on an airspeed indicator (ASI) shows:

  1. the maximum IAS at which flaps may be lowered

  2. the preferred speed for approach and landing

  3. VNE - velocity never exceed

  4. the minimum IAS at which flaps may be retracted

the maximum IAS at which flaps may be lowered

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Pre-Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1

Questions

The most common cause of pilot incapacitation during flight is

  1. heart attack

  2. dehydration

  3. blocked sinus passages

  4. food or drink poisoning [gastro-intestinal disorders]

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The symptoms of dehydration include

  1. profuse sweating

  2. drying of the nasal passages and a prickly sensation in the eyes

  3. 'runny' eyes and nose

  4. stomach cramps and a high temperature

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The CASA has recommended a period on the ground after making a blood donation of at least

  1. six hours

  2. twenty-four hours

  3. twelve hours

  4. forty-eight hours

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

CAR 256 requires *total* abstinence by all pilots from *any* alcohol for a period of

  1. eight hours before departure

  2. 24 hours before departure

  3. eight hours before commencing duty

  4. 12 hours before departure

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Which of the following is true of drugs taken by pilots for medical reasons before flight?

  1. any drugs that are available 'over the counter' can be considered safe

  2. drugs can be considered safe if they are prescribed by a doctor

  3. drugs can be considered safe unless there is a warning on the packet

  4. the opinion of a DAME should be sought before using *any* drug

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Discomfort or pain in the ears or sinuses is *most likely* during

  1. long periods of cruising flight at high altitude

  2. high rates of descent in unpressurised aircraft

  3. high rates of climb in unpressurised aircraft

  4. long slow descents in unpressurised aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

If an otherwise healthy pilot suffers a bout of dizzy spells, the appropriate action required by CAR 6.16 would be

  1. notify a DAME and refrain from all flying until cleared

  2. notify a DAME and refrain from all commercial flying until cleared

  3. notify a DAME and refrain from all instrument flying until cleared

  4. resume flying providing there is no recurrence within twenty-four hours

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Pilots can best assist airsick passengers by

  1. warning them that they will have to clean up the mess if they vomit

  2. descending quickly to land before they become sick

  3. reassuring them that airsickness is nothing to worry about

  4. flying as smoothly as possible and making all manoeuvres and descents gentle

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Too much salt in the diet can lead to

  1. excessive sweating

  2. increased chance of catching cold

  3. high blood pressure

  4. low blood pressure

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Foods most likely to produce intestinal gases are

  1. salty foods

  2. green vegetables

  3. foods high in sugar

  4. chicken

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 1

Answers

  1. heart attack

  2. dehydration

  3. blocked sinus passages

  4. food or drink poisoning [gastro-intestinal disorders]

food or drink poisoning [gastro-intestinal disorders]

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4

Questions

The two difference types of light sensitive elements on the retina are classified as

  1. rods which are sensitive to colour and cones which work best in dim light

  2. cones which are sensitive to colour and rods which work best in dim light

  3. rods and cones both of which respond equally to all lighting conditions

  4. rods and cones both of which are responsible for colour vision

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The blind spot is

  1. the area of the lens which is screened by the iris

  2. the black spot in the centre of the coloured section of the eye

  3. at the junction of the optic nerve and the retina

  4. an area on the cornea which does not respond to light

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

If a pilot whose eyes have fully adapter to darkness is exposed to a bright flash of light, the time required for dark adaptation to be re-established is most likely to be

  1. 3 minutes

  2. 5 minutes

  3. 15 minutes

  4. 30 minutes

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The maximum distance at which a healthy eye in good lighting and contrast could identifiy a circle one metre in diameter is approximately

  1. one kilometre

  2. five kilometres

  3. 2 nautical miles

  4. five hundred metres

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

In level flight, a collision risk exists if a converging aircraft viewed from your cockpit appears to be

  1. on the horizon and maintaining a constant position in your windscreen

  2. below the horizon and moving closer to the centre of your windscreen

  3. on the horizon and moving away from the centre of your windscreen

  4. on the horizon

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

The most effective way to scan the sky for other aircraft during level flight is to

  1. move the head in continuous arc from side to side

  2. keep the head still and move the eyes continuously from side to side

  3. do not look anywhere but straight ahead unless you detect movement

  4. move the head about 20deg or 30deg at a time, pausing after each movement to allow the peripheral vision to detect any movement

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Heavy rain may have the effect of making objects viewed through the windscreen appear,

  1. further away than they actually are

  2. closer than they actually are

  3. larger than they actually are

  4. brighter than they actually are

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4
RPL,Bob Tait,Human Factors

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Human Performance 4

Answers

The two difference types of light sensitive elements on the retina are classified as

  1. rods which are sensitive to colour and cones which work best in dim light

  2. cones which are sensitive to colour and rods which work best in dim light

  3. rods and cones both of which respond equally to all lighting conditions

  4. rods and cones both of which are responsible for colour vision

cones which are sensitive to colour and rods which work best in dim light

Back to question

  1. the area of the lens which is screened by the iris

  2. the black spot in the centre of the coloured section of the eye

  3. at the junction of the optic nerve and the retina

  4. an area on the cornea which does not respond to light

  4. brighter than they actually are

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8

Questions

What are the appropriate frequencies to listen out when operating in Class G airspace?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

List five items which are strictly prohibited for use in radio transmissions.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8

Answers

What are the appropriate frequencies to listen out when operating in Class G airspace?

The CTAF/MULTICOM, FIA or SIS frequency appropriate to that part of Class G airspace in which you are operating.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

List five items which are strictly prohibited for use in radio transmissions.

Calls containing: profane or obscene language; deceptive or false information; improper use of callsigns of other aircraft; non-operational requirements; and calls of a personal nature.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 8
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo

Questions

A number of factors affect the stalling IAS of an aircraft. Which is not a factor?

  1. Power

  2. Load factor (G)

  3. Altitude

  4. Aircraft weight

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are flying in the training area at 1,800ft. What is the minimum requirements to ensure you remain in Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC)?

  1. Clear of cloud with 5km visibility

  2. 1,000ft clear of cloud vertically with 5km visibility

  3. 1,000ft clear of cloud vertically with 8km visibility

  4. Whatever seems appropriate to the pilot

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Induced drag acting on an aircraft during straight and level flight is:

  1. greatest when airspeed is low and the aircraft is light

  2. greatest when airspeed is low and the aircraft is heavy

  3. greatest when airspeed is high and the aircraft is light

  4. greatest when airspeed is high and the aircraft is heavy

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Detonation of an aircraft engine is most likely to occur when?

  1. During a full power climb with the mixture set lean

  2. During descent at idle power

  3. During the cruise with a mixture too rich

  4. During take-off with the mixture at full rich

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If you are flying late in the afternoon. You must ensure you plan to land how long before the end of daylight?

  1. 0 minutes - simply ensure you last before dark

  2. 30 minutes

  3. 5 minutes

  4. 10 minutes

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

After take-off the altimeter fails to climb, what is the most likely cause?

  1. A blocked static port

  2. The QNH was set incorrectly

  3. A blocked pitot tube

  4. An electrical failure in the instrument panel

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When would carburettor ice be most difficult to detect?

  1. During the cruise in freezing rain

  2. During a descent at low power

  3. During take-off at full power

  4. During a cruise climb at an intermediate power setting

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

What is the legal minimum requirement with respect to performing a fuel system inspection?

  1. Before each and every flight

  2. Before the first flight of the day and after refueling

  3. Only after refueling

  4. Before the first flight of the day

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are carrying out a level turn of 60 degrees angle of bank. Which of the following is correct?

  1. Lift is equal to weight

  2. Lift is 3.0 times weight

  3. Lift is 2.0 times weight

  4. Lift is 1.4 times weight

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Your aircraft has been filled with JET A1 (AVTUR) instead of AVGAS as specified in the flight manual. Which of the following statements is correct?

  1. There would be power loss and rough running or engine failure - you should not depart

  2. The performance of your aircraft would increase substantially when running on jet fuel

  3. There would be no performance impact and you would be safe to proceed with your planned flight

  4. There would be a slight reduction in power however you could proceed with your planned flight

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are climbing with one magneto that is unserviceable. What is the effect on climb performance?

  1. Reduced angle of climb

  2. Reduced rate of climb

  3. Reduced rate and angle of climb

  4. No effect as the other magneto is still operating

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The maximum speed an aircraft is permitted to fly is abbreviated as:

  1. VNE

  2. VNO

  3. VA

  4. VMAX

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

During a level steep turn, the load factor:

  1. Decreases due to increased power being used

  2. Increases with increasing angle of bank

  3. Remains unchanged

  4. Increases due to increasing angle of attack

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

An increase in parasite drag would result from which of the following actions?

  1. Increasing the IAS

  2. Decreasing the IAS

  3. Reducing or raising the flaps

  4. Retracting the undercarriage

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

In your before takeoff checks you notice that there is no RPM drop when carburettor heat is moved to "ON". What is the most likely cause?

  1. The engine is not yet to normal operating temperature

  2. Carburettor ice is present

  3. The outside air temperature (OAT) is high and we do not expect a drop

  4. The carburettor heat mechanism is defective

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The load factor (G force) that an average person might start to "grey out" is:

  1. 3.5 G

  2. 5.0 G

  3. 2.0 G

  4. 7.0 G

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

One of the early symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning is a:

  1. Loss of vision

  2. Slight headache

  3. Severe headache

  4. Loss of muscular power

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

What colour is AVGAS 100LL when sampled?

  1. Green

  2. Blue

  3. Clear

  4. Yellow

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

As a student pilot (pre-GFPT) how many hours are you permitted to fly solo before a dual check must be carried out?

  1. 1.0 hour

  2. 5.0 hours

  3. 3.0 hours

  4. 2.0 hours

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You're in flight and there is a glider approaching on your right at the same level, you should:

  1. Turn right to pass behind the glider

  2. Climb over and above the glider

  3. Expect the glider to give way

  4. Descend beneath the glider

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You have mishandled the aircraft and are experiencing a load factor (G force) of over +5 G's. After a short period of time you black-out, this means that:

  1. You have tunnel vision and are seeing in shades of grey only

  2. You have passed out

  3. You have lost all vision however you are still conscious and able to move the controls

  4. You have lost all vision however you are still conscious and able to move the controls

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If there was a small quantity of water present in your fuel tank how would it be presented when sampling your avgas?

  1. Clear blobs of water at the base of your fuel sample

  2. The blue tint of the 100LL avgas would be lighter than usual

  3. The water mixes with the avgas and it's not possible to detect

  4. Clear blobs of water at the top of your fuel sample

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

While taxiing for take-off another aeroplane approaches head-on, you would:

  1. Continue to taxi, expecting the other aircraft to move

  2. Continue to taxi, moving to pass on the right

  3. Continue to taxi, moving to pass on the left

  4. Pull over to the left and stop.

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

On a visual terminal chart (VTC), major built up areas, such as a city, are shown in which colour?

  1. Yellow

  2. Brown

  3. Green

  4. Purple

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When gliding for maximum distance it would be best to glide:

  1. In to wind

  2. Across the wind

  3. At the best glide speed - wind has no bearing on glide distance

  4. With the wind behind you

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

How often should a direction indicator (DI) be aligned with the magnetic compass?

  1. Every 10-15 minutes

  2. Before take-off only

  3. At least every 5 minutes

  4. Approximately every 30 minutes

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

When flying in the training area you must not fly lower than:

  1. 500ft AGL

  2. 1,000ft AGL over populated areas and 500ft AGL elsewhere

  3. 1,500ft AGL over populated areas and 1,000ft AGL elsewhere

  4. 1,000ft unless on approach to land

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Which of the following would result in a decreased rate of climb?

  1. An increase in headwind component

  2. A reduction in engine power

  3. A reduction in weight

  4. A decrease in headwind component

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If a fuel gauge indicates 24 US gallons in a fuel tank and it is properly calibrated you would expect to see how many litres on your dipstick?

  1. 108 litres

  2. 96 litres

  3. 90 litres

  4. 72 litres

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

The ATIS reports that the QNH is 1015 and temperature is 25 degrees C at an airport where the elevation is 250ft. When QNH is set on the subscale of your altimeter it should:

  1. Indicate airport elevation

  2. Indicate zero feet

  3. Indicate higher than the airport elevation due to the temperature

  4. Indicate lower than the airport elevation due to the temperature

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If an aeroplane is stalling and a wing drops at the moment of stall, then the pilot should do what to prevent the wing drop dropping further?

  1. Use ailerons to stop the wing from falling further

  2. Use ailerons to level the wings

  3. Use rudder in the opposite direction to the wing drop to prevent further yaw

  4. Use rudder in the same direction to the wing drop to prevent further yaw

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are climbing at your best rate of climb airspeed (Vy), if you start a turn your rate of climb will:

  1. Decrease with increasing angle of bank

  2. Decrease due to asymmetric propeller effect

  3. Remain the same regardless of angle of bank

  4. Increase if turning in to a headwind

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If during engine start you suspect a fire in the engine compartment, the best course of action initially is to:

  1. Turn off the ignition switch

  2. Continue trying to start the engine with the starter

  3. Evacuate the aeroplane without delay

  4. Put out the fire with the onboard fire extinguisher

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

An area shown on a visual terminal chart (VTC) is marked "R580 - SFC-1500". This indicates that you may not over fly this area without a clearance:

  1. Below 1,500ft AMSL

  2. Below 1,500ft AGL

  3. Above 1,500ft AMSL

  4. Above 1,500ft AGL

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Indications of carburettor icing in an aeroplane with a fixed pitch propeller could be:

  1. Decreased fuel consumption

  2. A rise in RPM due to resulting richer mixture.

  3. Decreased exhaust gas temperature

  4. Rough running and a drop in RPM

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Spot heights on a visual terminal chart (VTC) are:

  1. Never higher than the surrounding hyposometric tint

  2. Measured in metres above mean sea level

  3. Measured in feet above the surrounding terrain

  4. Measured in feet above mean sea level

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

A centre-zero ammeter indicates zero in flight, this most likely indicates:

  1. The battery is completely flat

  2. The battery is fully charged

  3. The alternator has failed

  4. The magnetos are running off the battery

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You have experienced a radio failure while operating in the circuit. ATC have realised this and display light signals to communicate with you. A steady red light while you are airborne indicates:

  1. Aerodrome unsafe, do not land

  2. Give way to other aircraft and continue circling

  3. Radio failure acknowledged, cleared to land

  4. No significance

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You should plan to land with how many minutes of fixed reserve fuel in your tank(s)?

  1. 20 minutes

  2. 30 minutes

  3. 45 minutes

  4. 60 minutes

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If you had a wake turbulence encounter having flown near the path of a heavy aircraft you would most likely experience:

  1. A violent roll

  2. A violent yaw

  3. A violent pitch

  4. A violent pitch and roll

Answer
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo

Answers

A number of factors affect the stalling IAS of an aircraft. Which is not a factor?

  1. Power

  2. Load factor (G)

  3. Altitude

  4. Aircraft weight

Altitude

Back to question

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You are flying in the training area at 1,800ft. What is the minimum requirements to ensure you remain in Visual Meteorological Conditions (VMC)?

  1. Clear of cloud with 5km visibility

  2. 1,000ft clear of cloud vertically with 5km visibility

  3. 1,000ft clear of cloud vertically with 8km visibility

  4. Whatever seems appropriate to the pilot

Clear of cloud with 5km visibility

airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Induced drag acting on an aircraft during straight and level flight is:

  1. greatest when airspeed is low and the aircraft is light

  2. greatest when airspeed is low and the aircraft is heavy

  3. greatest when airspeed is high and the aircraft is light

  4. greatest when airspeed is high and the aircraft is heavy

greatest when airspeed is low and the aircraft is heavy

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Detonation of an aircraft engine is most likely to occur when?

  1. During a full power climb with the mixture set lean

  2. During descent at idle power

  3. During the cruise with a mixture too rich

  4. During take-off with the mixture at full rich

During a full power climb with the mixture set lean

  3. Lift is 2.0 times weight

  4. Lift is 1.4 times weight

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Your aircraft has been filled with JET A1 (AVTUR) instead of AVGAS as specified in the flight manual. Which of the following statements is correct?

  1. There would be power loss and rough running or engine failure - you should not depart

  2. The performance of your aircraft would increase substantially when running on jet fuel

  3. There would be no performance impact and you would be safe to proceed with your planned flight

  4. There would be a slight reduction in power however you could proceed with your planned flight

There would be power loss and rough running or engine failure - you should not depart

  2. Reduced rate of climb

  3. Reduced rate and angle of climb

  4. No effect as the other magneto is still operating

Reduced rate and angle of climb

  1. Use ailerons to stop the wing from falling further

  2. Use ailerons to level the wings

  3. Use rudder in the opposite direction to the wing drop to prevent further yaw

  4. Use rudder in the same direction to the wing drop to prevent further yaw

Use rudder in the opposite direction to the wing drop to prevent further yaw

  1. Decrease with increasing angle of bank

  2. Decrease due to asymmetric propeller effect

  3. Remain the same regardless of angle of bank

  4. Increase if turning in to a headwind

  1. Turn off the ignition switch

  2. Continue trying to start the engine with the starter

  3. Evacuate the aeroplane without delay

  4. Put out the fire with the onboard fire extinguisher

Continue trying to start the engine with the starter

  1. Below 1,500ft AMSL

  2. Below 1,500ft AGL

  3. Above 1,500ft AMSL

  4. Above 1,500ft AGL

RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

You should plan to land with how many minutes of fixed reserve fuel in your tank(s)?

  1. 20 minutes

  2. 30 minutes

  3. 45 minutes

  4. 60 minutes

45 minutes

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

If you had a wake turbulence encounter having flown near the path of a heavy aircraft you would most likely experience:

  1. A violent roll

  2. A violent yaw

  3. A violent pitch

  4. A violent pitch and roll

A violent roll

Back to question
airborne-aviation.com.au Area Solo
RPL,Solo,Airborne Aviation

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1

Questions

What is the unit of frequency called, and what is its abbreviation?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

A frequency of 1,000 hertz can also be described as one (kilohertz/megahertz/microhertz).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Sketch a typical wave and label it with wavelength and amplitude.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In your own words, define wavelength and amplitude.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Radio waves travel at the speed of (light/sound).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Light waves travel (slower than/the same speed as/faster than) sound waves.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If the transmit button becomes stuck in the transmit position or is not released after a transmission, will other transmissions be affected? Will it block that frequency?

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The VOR radio navaid operates in a range of frequencies within the (VHF/MF/UHF) band.

What equipment enables an air traffic radar controller to identify your aircraft by receiving coded signals?

For long-range voice communications, some aircraft are fitted with (UHF/MF/HF) radio equipment.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1

Answers

What is the unit of frequency called, and what is its abbreviation?

Hertz, Hz

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

A frequency of 1,000 hertz can also be described as one (kilohertz/megahertz/microhertz).

Kilohertz.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Sketch a typical wave and label it with wavelength and amplitude.

Refer to figure A2-1.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In your own words, define wavelength and amplitude.

Wavelength is the length of one cycle of the wave; amplitude is the maximum extent of an oscillation as measured from the position of equilibrium.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Radio waves travel at the speed of (light/sound).

Light.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Light waves travel (slower than/the same speed as/faster than) sound waves.

Faster than.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What is the preferred frequency band for aeronautical radio communication?

VHF.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The range of VHF transmissions (increases/decreases) with gain of height.

Increases.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What control is used on VHF-COM radio sets to minimise unwanted background noise?

Squelch.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When transmitting on a particular frequency, can other people in the vicinity be transmitting on that frequency simultaneously?

No.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

If the transmit button becomes stuck in the transmit position or is not released after a transmission, will other transmissions be affected? Will it block that frequency?

Yes. Yes.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The VOR radio navaid operates in a range of frequencies within the (VHF/MF/UHF) band.

VHF.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

In which frequency bands do the NDB radio beacons operate?

LF and MF.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What equipment enables an air traffic radar controller to identify your aircraft by receiving coded signals?

Transponder.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 1
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

HF.

Back to question
