Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo

Questions

Which of the following is true of VHF radio transmissions?

  1. more than one transmission can be received at the same time without interference

  2. distant stations can be received even when the aircraft is on the ground

  3. the signals travel by 'line of sight' and are shielded by the curvature of the earth

  4. the signals travel further over land than it does over water

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following is a VHF frequency?

  1. 124.7 MHz

  2. 6166 MHz

  3. 12.47 MHz

  4. 616.6 MHz

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

When the VHF radio is turned on, a loud hissing noise is heard. Which control should be adjusted to eliminate the noise?

  1. the volume control

  2. the frequency selector

  3. the speaker phones selector switch

  4. the squelch control

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You hear the first part of a radio message clearly then a loud squeal drowns out the remainder. The most likely cause would be

  1. the station transmitting has a faulty microphone

  2. your squelch control is not properly set

  3. another station has transmitted on your frequency

  4. your receiver is set to the incorrect frequency

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The number 7500 would be transmitted as

  1. seven thousand five hundred

  2. seven and a half thousand

  3. seven five zero zero

  4. seventy-five hundred

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following situations would warrant the transmission of a MAYDAY call in a single engine aeroplane?

  1. the engine fails during a flight in your training area

  2. a passenger becomes very ill and obviously requires medical attention

  3. a passenger becomes air sick and asks you to land as soon as possible

  4. you encounter severe turbulence in the circuit area

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the choices would warrant the transmission of a PAN call?

  1. the engine fails during a flight in your training area

  2. a passenger becomes very ill and obviously requires medical attention

  3. a passenger becomes air sick and asks you to land as soon as possible

  4. you encounter severe turbulence in the circuit area

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Another aircraft calls to advise that he estimates your aerodrome at three five. This means that

  1. he will be overflying your aerodrome at three thousand five hundred feet

  2. he is presently thirty-five miles from your aerodrome

  3. he expects to arrive in your circuit area at five minutes past three

  4. he expects to arrive in your circuit area at thirty-five minutes past the current hour

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What procedures apply at your local aerodrome if the radio fails while you are doing circuits?

  1. *Check with your instructor for the appropriate procedures for your aerodrome.*

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

List the radio calls that apply at your aerodrome for the situations below * At the commencement of taxiing * Before crossing the holding point * Before take-off * Downwind * Base

  1. *Check with your instructor for the calls that apply at your aerodrome.*

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following types of aircraft motion combine to produce a spiral dive?

  1. pitch and roll

  2. pitch and yaw

  3. roll and yaw

  4. roll and further roll

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The best way for a pilot to assess the aircraft's attitude in space is to

  1. look at the wing tips in relation to the natural horizon

  2. look straight ahead to relate the nose of the aircraft to the natural horizon

  3. look at the artificial horizon

  4. check the power setting and the resulting airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A pilot knows that the aircraft is correctly trimmed when

  1. it is not losing or gaining any height

  2. the wings are level and the 'skid ball' is centred

  3. the trim position indicator indicates zero

  4. the required nose attitude is maintained even after the controls are released

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

As airspeed decreases [eg during the float before touch-down],

  1. forward visibility improves

  2. a larger degree of control deflection is required to maintain a given attitude

  3. a given attitude can be maintained with less control deflection

  4. full back elevator should be applied to prevent the aircraft sinking

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The most important recovery action required if an aircraft has entered a spiral dive is

  1. level the wings

  2. lower the nose to increase the airspeed

  3. apply full power to assist the recovery

  4. pull firmly back on the elevator controls to raise the nose above the horizon

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If airspeed has been allowed to decay to the point where the pilot suspects that a stall is imminent, the most important actions required are

  1. apply full power and lift the nose

  2. lower the nose and reduce the power

  3. reduce the power and lift the nose

  4. add power and lower the nose

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

In the event of an engine failure during the climb-out after take-off in a single engine aircraft, the most important immediate action required is

  1. lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed

  2. raise the nose to maintain a safe airspeed

  3. commence a turn back towards the field

  4. maintain the nose attitude to prevent an excessive build-up of airspeed

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A change in which of the following factors has no effect on the stalling IAS of an aeroplane?

  1. weight

  2. wind

  3. power

  4. flap

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If it becomes necessary to commence a go-around during a landing approach, which of the following is the correct sequence of actions to ensure a safe transition to the climb?

  1. raise the flap, raise the nose to the climbing attitude and apply full power

  2. raise the nose to the climbing attitude, raise the flap and apply full power

  3. apply full power while raising the nose to the climbing attitude and raise the flap

  4. raise the flap while applying full power then raise the nose to the climbing attitude

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following combination of symptoms would indicate an approaching stall during final approach to land?

  1. low airspeed, sluggish control response and high nose attitude

  2. low power setting, high approach path and low nose attitude

  3. low airspeed and low nose attitude

  4. flatter than normal approach and high power setting

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If an aircraft which is about to stall suffers a wing drop, the pilot should

  1. lower the nose, keep straight with rudder and use no aileron until the speed increases

  2. lower the nose, keep straight with aileron and use no rudder until the speed increases

  3. raise the nose and apply opposite aileron

  4. raise the nose, keep straight with rudder and use no aileron until the speed increases

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During take-off in conditions of no wind, it is normally necessary to apply right rudder to maintain a straight take-off path. This is necessary because of

  1. the propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder

  2. engine torque pushing the left wheel harder onto the runway surface

  3. the lower airspeed over the ailerons during the take-off run

  4. Both the propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder and engine torque pushing the left wheel harder onto the runway surface

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Compared to a normal approach, during a flapless approach at a given IAS the pilot will notice

  1. a higher nose attitude and a flatter approach path

  2. a lower nose attitude and a flatter approach path

  3. a higher nose attitude and a steeper approach path

  4. a lower attitude and a steeper approach path

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During an approach on a windy day the pilot notices that the windsock is indicating frequent changes in surface wind speed and direction. In these conditions the pilot should

  1. approach at a lower IAS and higher nose attitude than normal

  2. be prepared to add power to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

  3. be prepared to lower the nose to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

  4. be prepared to add power and lower the nose to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During a glide approach in no wind at the recommended gliding IAS, raising the nose slightly will result in a slower approach speed but a flatter approach angle

  1. the statement is true

  2. the statement is false

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The indication on the balance indicator *with ball to the left of centre* would require the pilot to

  1. apply more right aileron

  2. apply more right rudder

  3. apply more left aileron

  4. apply more left rudder

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the aerodrome ground marker *with two adjacent unfilled plus signs* is displayed near the wind sock of an uncontrolled aerodrome it indicates that

  1. gliding operations are in progress

  2. the aerodrome is closed to all operations

  3. all unsealed areas are unserviceable

  4. the aerodrome is suitable for light aircraft only

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

By convention the downwind leg of the circuit for piston engine aeroplanes is flown at a height of

  1. 1000ft AMSL

  2. 1500ft AMSL

  3. 1000ft AGL

  4. 1500ft AGL

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

What is the minimum height at which an aeroplane may commence a turn in the direction of the circuit after take-off

  1. 1000ft AGL

  2. 1500ft AGL

  3. 500ft AGL

  4. 200ft AGL

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the pilot sets the QNH while on the ground at an aerodrome, the altimeter will read

  1. height above the aerodrome

  2. height above sea-level

  3. height in the standard atmosphere

  4. height above terrain

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You are lining up to take off behind another aircraft which has just landed on the same runway. You may not commence your take off run until that aircraft has

  1. finished its landing run and stopped

  2. commenced a turn towards a taxiway exit

  3. vacated the runway and is taxiing away

  4. passed a point 600m ahead of your present position

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A landing aeroplane must be established on a straight final approach path by

  1. 500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

  2. 500 feet AGL

  3. 800 feet AGL

  4. 1500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A taxiway leading into a runway *has a transverse solid white line and immediately subsequent transverse dashed white line*. What is the significance of the solid and dashed white lines across the taxiway?

  1. Aircraft taxiing in *that direction* must hold short and check before entering the runway

  2. No significance providing you are taxiing in the direction of the arrow

  3. Aircraft vacating the runway must hold at this point and check that the taxiway is clear

  4. Runway edge marker -- no significance to taxiing aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You observe another aircraft approaching head on at your level. The correct action to take is

  1. dive to pass beneath the approaching aircraft

  2. climb to pass above the approaching aircraft

  3. turn to your left toavoid the approaching aircraft

  4. turn to your right to avoid the approaching aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

After you turn onto final approach at an uncontrolled aerodrome you notice another aircraft below you and slightly ahead of you on approach to the same runway. You should

  1. continue the approach because the lower aircraft must give way

  2. descend beneath the other aircraft and land to one side of it

  3. remain above the other aircraft and land to one side of it

  4. commence a go-around and give way to the lower aircraft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You intend to fly in the morning at 6.00 am. What is the latest time at which you may have an alcoholic drink prior to this flight?

  1. midnight before the flight

  2. 10pm on the evening before the flight

  3. 5.00 am on the morning of the flight

  4. 24 hours before the proposed flight

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The top of the white arc on an Airspeed Indicator marks

  1. the lowest IAS at which an approach to land should be made

  2. the highest IAS at which the aircraft should be permitted to remain on the ground during the take-off run

  3. the IAS which will produce the best rate of climb

  4. the maximum IAS at which flaps should be lowered

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is taxiing toward you on a taxiway. What is the correct procedure to adopt to pass the other aircraft?

  1. move to the left side of the taxiway

  2. move to the right side of the taxiway

  3. the smaller aircraft should pull off the taxiway and allow the bigger one to pass

  4. move to whichever side of the taxiway is closest to you at the time

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

  2. immediately after start-up

  3. before taxiing commences

  4. immediately before take-off

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo

Answers

Which of the following is true of VHF radio transmissions?

  1. more than one transmission can be received at the same time without interference

  2. distant stations can be received even when the aircraft is on the ground

  3. the signals travel by 'line of sight' and are shielded by the curvature of the earth

  4. the signals travel further over land than it does over water

the signals travel by 'line of sight' and are shielded by the curvature of the earth

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following is a VHF frequency?

  1. 124.7 MHz

  2. 6166 MHz

  3. 12.47 MHz

  4. 616.6 MHz

124.7 MHz

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

When the VHF radio is turned on, a loud hissing noise is heard. Which control should be adjusted to eliminate the noise?

  1. the volume control

  2. the frequency selector

  3. the speaker phones selector switch

  4. the squelch control

the squelch control

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You hear the first part of a radio message clearly then a loud squeal drowns out the remainder. The most likely cause would be

  1. the station transmitting has a faulty microphone

  2. your squelch control is not properly set

  3. another station has transmitted on your frequency

  4. your receiver is set to the incorrect frequency

another station has transmitted on your frequency

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The number 7500 would be transmitted as

  1. seven thousand five hundred

  2. seven and a half thousand

  3. seven five zero zero

  4. seventy-five hundred

seven thousand five hundred

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following situations would warrant the transmission of a MAYDAY call in a single engine aeroplane?

  1. the engine fails during a flight in your training area

  2. a passenger becomes very ill and obviously requires medical attention

  3. a passenger becomes air sick and asks you to land as soon as possible

  4. you encounter severe turbulence in the circuit area

the engine fails during a flight in your training area

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the choices would warrant the transmission of a PAN call?

  1. the engine fails during a flight in your training area

  2. a passenger becomes very ill and obviously requires medical attention

  3. a passenger becomes air sick and asks you to land as soon as possible

  4. you encounter severe turbulence in the circuit area

a passenger becomes very ill and obviously requires medical attention

Back to question

RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

  1. he will be overflying your aerodrome at three thousand five hundred feet

  2. he is presently thirty-five miles from your aerodrome

  3. he expects to arrive in your circuit area at five minutes past three

  4. he expects to arrive in your circuit area at thirty-five minutes past the current hour

he expects to arrive in your circuit area at thirty-five minutes past the current hour

Which of the following types of aircraft motion combine to produce a spiral dive?

  1. pitch and roll

  2. pitch and yaw

  3. roll and yaw

  4. roll and further roll

roll and yaw

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The best way for a pilot to assess the aircraft's attitude in space is to

  1. look at the wing tips in relation to the natural horizon

  2. look straight ahead to relate the nose of the aircraft to the natural horizon

  3. look at the artificial horizon

  4. check the power setting and the resulting airspeed

look straight ahead to relate the nose of the aircraft to the natural horizon

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A pilot knows that the aircraft is correctly trimmed when

  1. it is not losing or gaining any height

  2. the wings are level and the 'skid ball' is centred

  3. the trim position indicator indicates zero

  4. the required nose attitude is maintained even after the controls are released

the required nose attitude is maintained even after the controls are released

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

As airspeed decreases [eg during the float before touch-down],

  1. forward visibility improves

  2. a larger degree of control deflection is required to maintain a given attitude

  3. a given attitude can be maintained with less control deflection

  4. full back elevator should be applied to prevent the aircraft sinking

a larger degree of control deflection is required to maintain a given attitude

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The most important recovery action required if an aircraft has entered a spiral dive is

  1. level the wings

  2. lower the nose to increase the airspeed

  3. apply full power to assist the recovery

  4. pull firmly back on the elevator controls to raise the nose above the horizon

level the wings

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If airspeed has been allowed to decay to the point where the pilot suspects that a stall is imminent, the most important actions required are

  1. apply full power and lift the nose

  2. lower the nose and reduce the power

  3. reduce the power and lift the nose

  4. add power and lower the nose

add power and lower the nose

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

In the event of an engine failure during the climb-out after take-off in a single engine aircraft, the most important immediate action required is

  1. lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed

  2. raise the nose to maintain a safe airspeed

  3. commence a turn back towards the field

  4. maintain the nose attitude to prevent an excessive build-up of airspeed

lower the nose to maintain a safe airspeed

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A change in which of the following factors has no effect on the stalling IAS of an aeroplane?

  1. weight

  2. wind

  3. power

  4. flap

wind

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If it becomes necessary to commence a go-around during a landing approach, which of the following is the correct sequence of actions to ensure a safe transition to the climb?

  1. raise the flap, raise the nose to the climbing attitude and apply full power

  2. raise the nose to the climbing attitude, raise the flap and apply full power

  3. apply full power while raising the nose to the climbing attitude and raise the flap

  4. raise the flap while applying full power then raise the nose to the climbing attitude

apply full power while raising the nose to the climbing attitude and raise the flap

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Which of the following combination of symptoms would indicate an approaching stall during final approach to land?

  1. low airspeed, sluggish control response and high nose attitude

  2. low power setting, high approach path and low nose attitude

  3. low airspeed and low nose attitude

  4. flatter than normal approach and high power setting

low airspeed, sluggish control response and high nose attitude

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If an aircraft which is about to stall suffers a wing drop, the pilot should

  1. lower the nose, keep straight with rudder and use no aileron until the speed increases

  2. lower the nose, keep straight with aileron and use no rudder until the speed increases

  3. raise the nose and apply opposite aileron

  4. raise the nose, keep straight with rudder and use no aileron until the speed increases

lower the nose, keep straight with rudder and use no aileron until the speed increases

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During take-off in conditions of no wind, it is normally necessary to apply right rudder to maintain a straight take-off path. This is necessary because of

  1. the propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder

  2. engine torque pushing the left wheel harder onto the runway surface

  3. the lower airspeed over the ailerons during the take-off run

  4. Both the propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder and engine torque pushing the left wheel harder onto the runway surface

Both the propeller slipstream pushing on the left side of the rudder and engine torque pushing the left wheel harder onto the runway surface

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

Compared to a normal approach, during a flapless approach at a given IAS the pilot will notice

  1. a higher nose attitude and a flatter approach path

  2. a lower nose attitude and a flatter approach path

  3. a higher nose attitude and a steeper approach path

  4. a lower attitude and a steeper approach path

a higher nose attitude and a flatter approach path

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During an approach on a windy day the pilot notices that the windsock is indicating frequent changes in surface wind speed and direction. In these conditions the pilot should

  1. approach at a lower IAS and higher nose attitude than normal

  2. be prepared to add power to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

  3. be prepared to lower the nose to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

  4. be prepared to add power and lower the nose to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

be prepared to add power and lower the nose to restore IAS if wind shear is encountered

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

During a glide approach in no wind at the recommended gliding IAS, raising the nose slightly will result in a slower approach speed but a flatter approach angle

  1. the statement is true

  2. the statement is false

the statement is false

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The indication on the balance indicator *with ball to the left of centre* would require the pilot to

  1. apply more right aileron

  2. apply more right rudder

  3. apply more left aileron

  4. apply more left rudder

apply more left rudder

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the aerodrome ground marker *with two adjacent unfilled plus signs* is displayed near the wind sock of an uncontrolled aerodrome it indicates that

  1. gliding operations are in progress

  2. the aerodrome is closed to all operations

  3. all unsealed areas are unserviceable

  4. the aerodrome is suitable for light aircraft only

gliding operations are in progress

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

By convention the downwind leg of the circuit for piston engine aeroplanes is flown at a height of

  1. 1000ft AMSL

  2. 1500ft AMSL

  3. 1000ft AGL

  4. 1500ft AGL

1000ft AGL

What is the minimum height at which an aeroplane may commence a turn in the direction of the circuit after take-off

  1. 1000ft AGL

  2. 1500ft AGL

  3. 500ft AGL

  4. 200ft AGL

500ft AGL

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

If the pilot sets the QNH while on the ground at an aerodrome, the altimeter will read

  1. height above the aerodrome

  2. height above sea-level

  3. height in the standard atmosphere

  4. height above terrain

height above sea-level

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You are lining up to take off behind another aircraft which has just landed on the same runway. You may not commence your take off run until that aircraft has

  1. finished its landing run and stopped

  2. commenced a turn towards a taxiway exit

  3. vacated the runway and is taxiing away

  4. passed a point 600m ahead of your present position

vacated the runway and is taxiing away

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A landing aeroplane must be established on a straight final approach path by

  1. 500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

  2. 500 feet AGL

  3. 800 feet AGL

  4. 1500 metres from the aerodrome boundary

500 feet AGL

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

A taxiway leading into a runway *has a transverse solid white line and immediately subsequent transverse dashed white line*. What is the significance of the solid and dashed white lines across the taxiway?

  1. Aircraft taxiing in *that direction* must hold short and check before entering the runway

  2. No significance providing you are taxiing in the direction of the arrow

  3. Aircraft vacating the runway must hold at this point and check that the taxiway is clear

  4. Runway edge marker -- no significance to taxiing aircraft

Aircraft taxiing in *that direction* must hold short and check before entering the runway

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You observe another aircraft approaching head on at your level. The correct action to take is

  1. dive to pass beneath the approaching aircraft

  2. climb to pass above the approaching aircraft

  3. turn to your left toavoid the approaching aircraft

  4. turn to your right to avoid the approaching aircraft

turn to your right to avoid the approaching aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

After you turn onto final approach at an uncontrolled aerodrome you notice another aircraft below you and slightly ahead of you on approach to the same runway. You should

  1. continue the approach because the lower aircraft must give way

  2. descend beneath the other aircraft and land to one side of it

  3. remain above the other aircraft and land to one side of it

  4. commence a go-around and give way to the lower aircraft

commence a go-around and give way to the lower aircraft

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

You intend to fly in the morning at 6.00 am. What is the latest time at which you may have an alcoholic drink prior to this flight?

  1. midnight before the flight

  2. 10pm on the evening before the flight

  3. 5.00 am on the morning of the flight

  4. 24 hours before the proposed flight

10pm on the evening before the flight

Back to question
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Pre-Circuit Solo
RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

The top of the white arc on an Airspeed Indicator marks

  1. the lowest IAS at which an approach to land should be made

  2. the highest IAS at which the aircraft should be permitted to remain on the ground during the take-off run

  3. the IAS which will produce the best rate of climb

  4. the maximum IAS at which flaps should be lowered

the maximum IAS at which flaps should be lowered

RPL,Bob Tait,Solo

An aircraft is taxiing toward you on a taxiway. What is the correct procedure to adopt to pass the other aircraft?

  1. move to the left side of the taxiway

  2. move to the right side of the taxiway

  3. the smaller aircraft should pull off the taxiway and allow the bigger one to pass

  4. move to whichever side of the taxiway is closest to you at the time

move to the right side of the taxiway

  4. immediately before take-off

immediately before take-off

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4

Questions

What are the two fundamental types of airspace?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Information to flights in Class G airspace is provided by (air traffic control/FLIGHTWATCH).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the two divisions of controlled airspace?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the types of control zones?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The abbreviation CTR stands for (control zone/control area/controlled terminal radar).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At aerodromes in Class G airspace, traffic advisory frequencies have been established. What are these?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The abbreviation FIA stands for (flight information aerodrome/flight information area).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When inbound to a non-towered aerodrome, pilots should make a broadcast on the CTAF by what distance?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Outside tower hours of operation, may controlled aerodromes revert to non-towered aerodromes with mandatory carriage and use of radio?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where a discrete CTAF frequency is not listed for a non-towered aerodrome, broadcasts should be made on what frequency?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Carriage of radio (is/is not) mandatory at a CERT aerodrome.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the broadcasts you must make at a CERT or REG non-towered aerodrome?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At a CTAF (UNCR), the carriage of radio (is/is not) mandatory.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When a Class D control zone is deactivated after tower hours of operation, the zone can/cannot become a CTAF with mandatory radio.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At a REG aerodrome, the clearance to taxi (is/is not) required.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Before taking off from a registered aerodrome with a CTAF, is an airways clearance required?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When operating in Class G airspace, not near a CTAF, you should listen out on appropriate (ATC centre frequency/FIA frequency/UNICOM frequency).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the two types of air traffic clearances which can be issued for operating in controlled airspace?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

List the classes of airspace and explain what each means.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What facilities are provided to you in a flight information area (FIA)?

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4

Answers

What are the two fundamental types of airspace?

Controlled and non-controlled airspace.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Information to flights in Class G airspace is provided by (air traffic control/FLIGHTWATCH).

FLIGHTWATCH

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the two divisions of controlled airspace?

Control areas and control zones.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the types of control zones?

Civil (Class C and D), and military.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The abbreviation CTR stands for (control zone/control area/controlled terminal radar).

Control zone.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At aerodromes in Class G airspace, traffic advisory frequencies have been established. What are these?

Common traffic advisory frequencies or CTAF.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

The abbreviation FIA stands for (flight information aerodrome/flight information area).

Flight information area (FIA).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When inbound to a non-towered aerodrome, pilots should make a broadcast on the CTAF by what distance?

10 nm or broadcast area boundary whichever is greater.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Outside tower hours of operation, may controlled aerodromes revert to non-towered aerodromes with mandatory carriage and use of radio?

Yes, CERT, REG or MIL aerodromes on CTAF.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Where a discrete CTAF frequency is not listed for a non-towered aerodrome, broadcasts should be made on what frequency?

126.7MHz

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Carriage of radio (is/is not) mandatory at a CERT aerodrome.

Is.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the broadcasts you must make at a CERT or REG non-towered aerodrome?

Taxiing, entering runway, clear of runway, when entering the vicinity of the aerodrome, intending to make a straight-in approach, joining Base.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At a CTAF (UNCR), the carriage of radio (is/is not) mandatory.

Not mandatory for UNCR aerodromes, but radio-equipped aircraft should still make broadcasts (taxiing, entering the runway, inbound and joining the circuit).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When a Class D control zone is deactivated after tower hours of operation, the zone can/cannot become a CTAF with mandatory radio.

Can.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

At a REG aerodrome, the clearance to taxi (is/is not) required.

Is not.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Before taking off from a registered aerodrome with a CTAF, is an airways clearance required?

Not if going into Class G.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

When operating in Class G airspace, not near a CTAF, you should listen out on appropriate (ATC centre frequency/FIA frequency/UNICOM frequency).

FIA frequency.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What are the two types of air traffic clearances which can be issued for operating in controlled airspace?

Clearances (to taxi, cross a runway, takeoff and land) and airways clearances (to operate in controlled airspace).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

List the classes of airspace and explain what each means.

Class A - high altitude. Class C - controlled airspace, below FL600, including Class C CTRs. Class D - non-radar aerodrome CTRs (below 4,500 feet). Class E - controlled airspace with radar coverage between 8,500ft and FL125. Class G - all non-controlled airspace.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

What facilities are provided to you in a flight information area (FIA)?

Flight information and SAR alerting services.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Flight Radio Operator Licence 4
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Flight Radio Operator Licence

Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Questions

Where the refuelling equipment is not mobile, the Civil Aviation Orders require that an aeroplane being refuelled shall:

  1. have no persons on board.

  2. have a fire extuingisher on board.

  3. have all electrical systems switched off.

  4. be so placed that it can rapidly be moved to a place of safety if needed.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane's fuel must be checked for the presence of water:

  1. prior to every flight.

  2. prior to the first flight of the day and at each change of pilots.

  3. prior to the first flight of the day and following each refuelling.

  4. after each refuelling and/or change of pilots.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Follow an incident, an Air Safety Incident Report shall be submitted:

  1. within 48 hours of the completion of the flight.

  2. within 72 hours of the completion of the incident occurring.

  3. within 24 hours of the completion of the incident occurring.

  4. immediately.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which of the following would justify the use of a Mayday call?

  1. You need navigational assistance.

  2. You sight a capsized yacht off the coast.

  3. A passenger becomes ill and you need to land for medical assistance.

  4. You have an engine failure on a training flight.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane must not fly over a populated area at a height lower than:

  1. 1,500ft AMSL.

  2. 1,000ft on the area QNH.

  3. 1,000ft AGL.

  4. 500ft AGL.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Increasing power when flying straight and level at normal cruise speed will cause:

  1. an increase in airspeed and a decrease in drag.

  2. an increase in airspeed and an increase in drag.

  3. a decrease in airspeed and a decrease in drag.

  4. a decrease in airspeed and an increase in drag.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What is the effect of lowering full flap?

  1. An increase in lift and a decrease in drag.

  2. A decrease in lift and a decrease in drag.

  3. A increase in lift and an increase in drag.

  4. An increase in lift and an increase in drag.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Stalling speed is increased if:

  1. weight is increased.

  2. weight is decreased.

  3. load factor is decreased.

  4. angle of attack is increased.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What do we call the angle between the chord line of an aerofoil and the relative airflow?

  1. Angle of incidence.

  2. Stalling angle.

  3. Sweepback.

  4. Angle of attack.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Increasing the load factor will:

  1. decrease the stalling speed.

  2. increase the stalling speed.

  3. increase the stalling angle.

  4. decrease the stalling angle.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What happens to the lift and drag as the angle of attack approaches the stalling angle?

  1. Lift increases and drag increases.

  2. Lift increases and drag decreases.

  3. Lift decreases and drag decreases.

  4. Lift decreases and drag increases.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane is descending at the best gliding speed. Raising the nose will:

  1. decrease the gliding range.

  2. increase the gliding range.

  3. decrease the glide angle.

  4. decrease the rate of descent.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If a tailwind is encountered during a glide descent, when compared with a glide in still-air conditions, the:

  1. aeroplane pitch angle will be shallower.

  2. flightpath over the ground will be steeper.

  3. distance over the ground will be greater.

  4. rate of descent will be less.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

When compared to the stall IAS at 1,000ft, the stall IAS at 10,000ft will:

  1. increase by approximately 40%.

  2. decrease by approximately 40%.

  3. be the same.

  4. vary according to the actual density at 10,000ft.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

When in a 30 degree banked level turn, the load factor:

  1. is the same as in straight and level flight.

  2. decreases by a factor of 15%.

  3. will increase to 1.15g.

  4. will be limited by the airspeed.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What are the VMC requirements for a VFR flight conducted in Class G airspace between 3,000ft AMSL (or 1,000ft AGL if higher), and 10,000ft AMSL?

  1. Visibility 5km, clear of cloud.

  2. Visibility 8km, 1,000 metres horizontally from cloud, 1,000ft above or below cloud.

  3. Visibility 5,000 metres, 1,500 metres horizontally from cloud, and 1,000ft vertically from cloud.

  4. Visibility 8,000 metres, clear of cloud.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

A cold front is likely to produce:

  1. cumiliform clouds with smooth flying conditions.

  2. stratiform clouds with smooth flying conditions.

  3. cumiliform clouds with turbulent conditions.

  4. stratiform clouds with turbulent flying conditions.

  4. expected to last less than 30 minutes.

  4. aerodrome level.

  3. 290 degrees True.

  4. 260 degrees Magnetic.

Magnetic variation is:

  1. the angular difference between magnetic north and compass north.

  2. the direction in which all compass errors occur.

  3. always expressed in degrees, either east or west.

  4. the angular difference between true north and compass north.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

A line of longitude on a WAC is:

  1. drawn north-south and represents true north and true south.

  2. drawn east-west and represents magnetic north and magnetic south.

  3. sometimes referred to as in isogonal.

  4. drawn parallel to the next meridian.

  1. is unlikely to form.

  2. will form with maximum power set.

  3. is likely to form with normal cruise power set.

  4. is highly likely to form with low power set.

  2. For safety and for improved combustion.

  3. For improved combustion even though safety is not increased.

  4. To spread the load between each of the spark plugs in a cylinder.

  1. rich.

  2. chemically correct for the power setting being used.

  3. lean.

  4. having a fuel/air ratio of 100%.

  4. It will lean the mixture.

  1. There will be an immediate increase in engine rpm as soon as carburettor heat is applied.

  2. The engine will start to run roughly with a further decrease in engine rpm.

  3. The engine will remain constant.

  4. The engine rpm will decrease and then increase.

  1. It is more prone to starting problems and is less susceptible to fuel contamination.

  2. It is easier to start when hot and is more responsive to throttle movement.

  3. It is less likely to have icing problems and is more efficient.

  4. It requires greater care in throttle handling and is more susceptible to fuel contamination.

Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Fuel that appears to be uncoloured or a very pale yellow is:

  1. 100LL low-lead AVGAS for piston engines.

  2. 100/130 AVGAS for piston engines.

  3. MOGAS.

  4. AVTUR (kerosene) for turbine engines (i.e. jet or prop-jet engines).

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

To improve engine cooling during a maximum power climb, you should:

  1. fly at a higher IAS.

  2. fly at a lower IAS.

  3. lean the fuel-air mixture.

  4. apply carburettor heat.

Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

The correct sequence of the various strokes in a four-stroke engine is:

  1. intake, compression, power, exhaust.

  2. intake, exhaust, power, compression.

  3. intake, power, compression, exhaust.

  4. intake, power, exhaust, compression.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which statement concerning carburettor ice do you consider most accurate?

  1. Carburettor ice is most likely to form when the air temperature is in the range -10 degrees celsius to +20 degrees celsius with visible moisture or high humidity.

  2. The carburettor heater is a de-icing device that heats the air after it leaves the carburettor.

  3. Carburettor ice will always form when the temperature is below freezing.

  4. The first indication of carburettor icing in an aeroplane with a fixed-pitch propeller is an increase in rpm.

  2. higher than the actual IAS.

  3. lower than the actual IAS.

  4. correctly.

  4. the ASI, VSI and altimeter.

  1. being too tired to concentrate.

  2. having balance difficulties and sinus pain.

  3. becoming dehydrated.

  4. developing hypoxia.

Answer
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Atmospheric pressure variations affect the human body. These pressure changes are:

  1. minimum at low level so we generally don't need to worry about them.

  2. minimum at high altitude.

  3. maximum at high altitude so we need pressurisation and oxygen supplied.

  4. maximum at low level so we need to understand their adverse effects.

  1. Antibiotics.

  2. Analgesics.

  3. Antihistamines.

  4. Amphetamines.

  5. None of the above.

  1. be very unstable longitudinally.

  2. have a very short moment arm.

  3. be very unstable about the normal axis.

  4. be very nose heavy and difficult to rotate on take-off.

  3. behind any aeroplane which is flying at high speed.

As you approach to land the wind is gusting. You increase your approach speed by 5kt to ensure a margin of safety. This means:

  1. the approach path flown will be steeper.

  2. climbing for a go-around would not be possible.

  3. the LDR will be greater.

  4. descent will be much more rapid.

  1. 1,800ft.

  2. 1,980ft.

  3. 2,260ft.

  4. 2,240ft.

Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Answers

Where the refuelling equipment is not mobile, the Civil Aviation Orders require that an aeroplane being refuelled shall:

  1. have no persons on board.

  2. have a fire extuingisher on board.

  3. have all electrical systems switched off.

  4. be so placed that it can rapidly be moved to a place of safety if needed.

be so placed that it can rapidly be moved to a place of safety if needed.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane's fuel must be checked for the presence of water:

  1. prior to every flight.

  2. prior to the first flight of the day and at each change of pilots.

  3. prior to the first flight of the day and following each refuelling.

  4. after each refuelling and/or change of pilots.

prior to the first flight of the day and following each refuelling.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Follow an incident, an Air Safety Incident Report shall be submitted:

  1. within 48 hours of the completion of the flight.

  2. within 72 hours of the completion of the incident occurring.

  3. within 24 hours of the completion of the incident occurring.

  4. immediately.

immediately.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which of the following would justify the use of a Mayday call?

  1. You need navigational assistance.

  2. You sight a capsized yacht off the coast.

  3. A passenger becomes ill and you need to land for medical assistance.

  4. You have an engine failure on a training flight.

You have an engine failure on a training flight.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane must not fly over a populated area at a height lower than:

  1. 1,500ft AMSL.

  2. 1,000ft on the area QNH.

  3. 1,000ft AGL.

  4. 500ft AGL.

1,000ft AGL.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Increasing power when flying straight and level at normal cruise speed will cause:

  1. an increase in airspeed and a decrease in drag.

  2. an increase in airspeed and an increase in drag.

  3. a decrease in airspeed and a decrease in drag.

  4. a decrease in airspeed and an increase in drag.

an increase in airspeed and an increase in drag.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What is the effect of lowering full flap?

  1. An increase in lift and a decrease in drag.

  2. A decrease in lift and a decrease in drag.

  3. A increase in lift and an increase in drag.

  4. An increase in lift and an increase in drag.

An increase in lift and an increase in drag.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Stalling speed is increased if:

  1. weight is increased.

  2. weight is decreased.

  3. load factor is decreased.

  4. angle of attack is increased.

weight is increased.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What do we call the angle between the chord line of an aerofoil and the relative airflow?

  1. Angle of incidence.

  2. Stalling angle.

  3. Sweepback.

  4. Angle of attack.

Angle of attack.

Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Increasing the load factor will:

  1. decrease the stalling speed.

  2. increase the stalling speed.

  3. increase the stalling angle.

  4. decrease the stalling angle.

increase the stalling speed.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What happens to the lift and drag as the angle of attack approaches the stalling angle?

  1. Lift increases and drag increases.

  2. Lift increases and drag decreases.

  3. Lift decreases and drag decreases.

  4. Lift decreases and drag increases.

Lift increases and drag increases.

Back to question

An aeroplane is descending at the best gliding speed. Raising the nose will:

  1. decrease the gliding range.

  2. increase the gliding range.

  3. decrease the glide angle.

  4. decrease the rate of descent.

increase the gliding range.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If a tailwind is encountered during a glide descent, when compared with a glide in still-air conditions, the:

  1. aeroplane pitch angle will be shallower.

  2. flightpath over the ground will be steeper.

  3. distance over the ground will be greater.

  4. rate of descent will be less.

distance over the ground will be greater.

  1. increase by approximately 40%.

  2. decrease by approximately 40%.

  3. be the same.

  4. vary according to the actual density at 10,000ft.

be the same.

  2. decreases by a factor of 15%.

  3. will increase to 1.15g.

  4. will be limited by the airspeed.

will increase to 1.15g.

  3. Visibility 5,000 metres, 1,500 metres horizontally from cloud, and 1,000ft vertically from cloud.

Visibility 5,000 metres, 1,500 metres horizontally from cloud, and 1,000ft vertically from cloud.

Magnetic variation is:

  1. the angular difference between magnetic north and compass north.

  2. the direction in which all compass errors occur.

  3. always expressed in degrees, either east or west.

  4. the angular difference between true north and compass north.

always expressed in degrees, either east or west.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

A line of longitude on a WAC is:

  1. drawn north-south and represents true north and true south.

  2. drawn east-west and represents magnetic north and magnetic south.

  3. sometimes referred to as in isogonal.

  4. drawn parallel to the next meridian.

drawn north-south and represents true north and true south.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

On a day when the temperature is 30 degrees and the relative humidity is 30%, carburettor ice:

  1. is unlikely to form.

  2. will form with maximum power set.

  3. is likely to form with normal cruise power set.

  4. is highly likely to form with low power set.

is unlikely to form.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Why do most aeroplane piston engines have dual ignition systems?

  1. For the sole reason of safety in the event of the failure of one magneto.

  2. For safety and for improved combustion.

  3. For improved combustion even though safety is not increased.

  4. To spread the load between each of the spark plugs in a cylinder.

For safety and for improved combustion.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If, following combustion, there is unburned fuel remaining in the cylinders, then the mixture is described as:

  1. rich.

  2. chemically correct for the power setting being used.

  3. lean.

  4. having a fuel/air ratio of 100%.

rich.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What do we call explosive, spontaneous combustion in the cylinders?

  1. Run-on.

  2. Detonation.

  3. Pre-ignition.

  4. Normal combustion.

Detonation.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

What is one effect of applying carburettor heat?

  1. It will result in more air immediately going through the carburettor.

  2. It will not affect the fuel-air mixture.

  3. It will enrich the mixture.

  4. It will lean the mixture.

It will enrich the mixture.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which flight instrument gives a pilot a direct reading of the bank angle?

  1. Direction indicator.

  2. Attitude indicator.

  3. Turn coordinator.

  4. Magnetic compass.

Attitude indicator.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

You are cruising in an aeroplane with a fixed-pitch propeller and notice a slight drop in engine rpm. You suspect carburettor icing and apply full carburettor heat. Which one of the following statements most correctly indicates that ice was present?

  1. There will be an immediate increase in engine rpm as soon as carburettor heat is applied.

  2. The engine will start to run roughly with a further decrease in engine rpm.

  3. The engine will remain constant.

  4. The engine rpm will decrease and then increase.

The engine rpm will decrease and then increase.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

When compared with an engine fitted with a carburettor, which of the following applies to a fuel-injected engine?

  1. It is more prone to starting problems and is less susceptible to fuel contamination.

  2. It is easier to start when hot and is more responsive to throttle movement.

  3. It is less likely to have icing problems and is more efficient.

  4. It requires greater care in throttle handling and is more susceptible to fuel contamination.

It is less likely to have icing problems and is more efficient.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Fuel that appears to be uncoloured or a very pale yellow is:

  1. 100LL low-lead AVGAS for piston engines.

  2. 100/130 AVGAS for piston engines.

  3. MOGAS.

  4. AVTUR (kerosene) for turbine engines (i.e. jet or prop-jet engines).

AVTUR (kerosene) for turbine engines (i.e. jet or prop-jet engines).

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

To improve engine cooling during a maximum power climb, you should:

  1. fly at a higher IAS.

  2. fly at a lower IAS.

  3. lean the fuel-air mixture.

  4. apply carburettor heat.

fly at a higher IAS.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

The correct sequence of the various strokes in a four-stroke engine is:

  1. intake, compression, power, exhaust.

  2. intake, exhaust, power, compression.

  3. intake, power, compression, exhaust.

  4. intake, power, exhaust, compression.

intake, compression, power, exhaust.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which statement concerning carburettor ice do you consider most accurate?

  1. Carburettor ice is most likely to form when the air temperature is in the range -10 degrees celsius to +20 degrees celsius with visible moisture or high humidity.

  2. The carburettor heater is a de-icing device that heats the air after it leaves the carburettor.

  3. Carburettor ice will always form when the temperature is below freezing.

  4. The first indication of carburettor icing in an aeroplane with a fixed-pitch propeller is an increase in rpm.

Carburettor ice is most likely to form when the air temperature is in the range -10 degrees celsius to +20 degrees celsius with visible moisture or high humidity.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If the static vent ices over during a descent, the airspeed indicator will then read:

  1. zero.

  2. higher than the actual IAS.

  3. lower than the actual IAS.

  4. correctly.

higher than the actual IAS.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

With battery and generator switches ON, what is the probable reason for a zero reading on a left-zero ammeter?

  1. The battery is fully charged.

  2. The alternator is still charging the battery.

  3. The battery is completely flat.

  4. The alternator has failed.

The alternator has failed.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

The pitot-static system supplies pressure for:

  1. the ASI only.

  2. the ASI, artificial horizon and VSI.

  3. the ASI, turn and slip indicator and altimeter.

  4. the ASI, VSI and altimeter.

the ASI, VSI and altimeter.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If you decide to fly when you have a cold or flu, you put yourself at risk of:

  1. being too tired to concentrate.

  2. having balance difficulties and sinus pain.

  3. becoming dehydrated.

  4. developing hypoxia.

having balance difficulties and sinus pain.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Atmospheric pressure variations affect the human body. These pressure changes are:

  1. minimum at low level so we generally don't need to worry about them.

  2. minimum at high altitude.

  3. maximum at high altitude so we need pressurisation and oxygen supplied.

  4. maximum at low level so we need to understand their adverse effects.

maximum at low level so we need to understand their adverse effects.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which of the following drugs are considered acceptable for flying?

  1. Antibiotics.

  2. Analgesics.

  3. Antihistamines.

  4. Amphetamines.

  5. None of the above.

None of the above.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

If an aeroplane is loaded in such a way that the centre of gravity is outside the forward limit, it will:

  1. be very unstable longitudinally.

  2. have a very short moment arm.

  3. be very unstable about the normal axis.

  4. be very nose heavy and difficult to rotate on take-off.

be very nose heavy and difficult to rotate on take-off.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Along which axis of the aeroplane is the centre of gravity computed?

  1. Lateral.

  2. Normal.

  3. Longitudinal.

  4. All of the above.

Longitudinal.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

An aeroplane must not be operated at a weight in excess of the maximum certificated gross weight because:

  1. structural limitations will be exceeded.

  2. an overloaded aeroplane is excessively stable in flight.

  3. flight in excess of certificated weights is not possible.

  4. fuel consumption will be greater.

structural limitations will be exceeded.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Which of the following factors improves take-off performance?

  1. The runway sloping upwards.

  2. A tailwind.

  3. A crosswind.

  4. Low atmospheric pressure.

  5. Low atmospheric temperature.

Low atmospheric temperature.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Vno is defined as the:

  1. maximum indicated airspeed for extending flaps.

  2. true airspeed beyond which flight is not permitted.

  3. maximum indicated airspeed for normal operations in smooth conditions.

  4. indicated airspeed beyond which flight is not permitted.

maximum indicated airspeed for normal operations in smooth conditions.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

Strong wake turbulence produced by wingtip vortices is most likely to form:

  1. behind a heavy aeroplane which is flying slowly just after take-off.

  2. behind any aeroplane which is flying slowly with full flap extended.

  3. behind any aeroplane which is flying at high speed.

  4. only behind aeroplanes powered by turbo-jet engines.

behind a heavy aeroplane which is flying slowly just after take-off.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

As you approach to land the wind is gusting. You increase your approach speed by 5kt to ensure a margin of safety. This means:

  1. the approach path flown will be steeper.

  2. climbing for a go-around would not be possible.

  3. the LDR will be greater.

  4. descent will be much more rapid.

the LDR will be greater.

Back to question
Aviation Theory Centre Basic Aeronautical Knowledge
RPL,Aviation Theory Centre,Basic Aeronautical Knowledge

To load an aeroplane, where would you find the weight and balance details for that aircraft?

  1. In the maintenance release.

  2. On the passenger manifest.

  3. In your flight instructors handbook.

  4. In the aircraft flight manual.

In the aircraft flight manual.

The weight of 230 litres of AVGAS is closest to:

  1. 128kg.

  2. 145kg.

  3. 163kg.

  4. 172kg.

  5. 180kg.

163kg.

  1. 62 litres.

  2. 88 litres.

  3. 100 litres.

  4. 123 litres.

  5. 135 litres.

123 litres.

  2. weight 890kg, arm 2,933mm.

weight 932kg, arm 2,960mm.

*Using the following performance data:* * Elevation: `1,890ft` * Runways: * `17/35 sealed TODA 3,000 metres (slope: level)` * `12/30 short grass TODA 1,000 metres (slope: 1% down to SE)` * ATIS * `Terminal Information Delta` * `Runway 12` * `Wind: 150/15` * `QNH 1,010 * Temperature: 15 degrees * Cloud `FEW 3000` * `Runway wet` * `Works in progress Runway 17/35` The pressure altitude of this airfield is:

  1. 1,800ft.

  2. 1,980ft.

  3. 2,260ft.

  4. 2,240ft.

1,980ft.

Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology

Questions

Which conditions are most likely to produce radiation fog?

  1. thin overcast with no wind

  2. broken cloud with no wind

  3. nil cloud and light wind

  4. scattered cumulus with light wind

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

During what stage of a thunderstorm would lightning be most frequent?

  1. before any precipitation

  2. during the most rapid growth

  3. at the mature stage

  4. during the dissipating stage

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The lifting of fog may be caused by

  1. a fall of temperature

  2. the formation of upper cloud

  3. an increase in wind strength

  4. an increase in humidity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Which phenomena in a thunderstorm causes low level wind shear at some distance away from the cell?

  1. updraft

  2. downdraft

  3. hail

  4. turbulence

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Where are tornadoes most likely to be encountered?

  1. over hot desert country

  2. with mountain waves

  3. strong low pressure systems

  4. wide spread severe thunderstorm activity

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Which process is involved in the formation of hoar frost?

  1. accumulation of ice crystals suspended in the atmosphere

  2. liquid water freezing on impact with the aircraft surface

  3. deposition of ice directly from the water vapour mixed with the air

  4. freezing of large supercooled water droplets

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The condition most likely to produce advection fog is

  1. cold air passing over a cold surface

  2. warm air passing over a warm surface

  3. cold air passing over a warm surface

  4. warm air passing over a cold surface

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

One of the prerequisites for the formation of a thunderstorm is

  1. the presence of moist air through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

  2. a rapid drop in surface temperature with an increase in wind strength

  3. a gradual increase in cloud cover above 20000ft

  4. a cold isothermal later through a considerable depth of the atmosphere

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Advection fog forms when

  1. cold air passes over a cold surface

  2. cold air passes over a warm surface

  3. warm air passes over a warm surface

  4. warm air passes over a cold surface

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Dust storms are most likely to produce which of the following hazards?

  1. severe visibility restriction in a localised area below 10000ft

  2. severe visibility restriction over a widepsread area below 10000ft

  3. severe visibility restriction over a widepsread area to heights above 10000ft

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The most dangerous effect of a mature thunderstorm is

  1. turbulence

  2. lightning

  3. hail

  4. icing

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

Slant visibility in fog causes

  1. reduced visibility towards the sun

  2. the runway is visible from 'over the top' but not in the circuit area or on final

  3. better visibility looking up than down

  4. runway visual range is less than meteorological visibility

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

The runway at a coastal aerodrome runs parallel to the coast. When would the crosswind component be likely to be strongest?

  1. early in the morning

  2. late at night

  3. in the early afternoon

  4. at sunset

Answer
Bob Tait RPL Study Guide Chapter Revision Meteorology
RPL,Meteorology,Bob Tait

  2. broken cloud with no wind

  3. nil cloud and light wind

  4. scattered cumulus with light wind

nil cloud and light wind

  3. at the mature stage
